5041 978-0-674-05288-8 $35.00 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
The Great Heart of the Republic: St. Louis and the Cultural Civil war Arenson
column2: Adam			"<h3>Interview with Adam Arenson
column3: Professor of History at the University of Texas at El Paso

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview

column2: Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Adam Arenson
column3: Professor of History at University of Texas at El Paso about his recent work
column4: The Great Heart of the Republic: St. Louis and the Cultural Civil War. Professor Arenson
column5: I appreciate you taking the time to speak with us.

column1: CWBR: I was struck by your timeline. How did you decide to begin your narrative in the 1840s and conclude with the St. Louis World’s Fair and Olympic Games in 1904?

AA: I found that they actually match very well with these national events that we often think of as the beginning and ending of the Civil War era: the end of the U.S. war with Mexico in 1848 and the Tilden-Hayes Election that is over with the semi-compromise of 1877. It was fascinating to see how these local and national events were in conversation
column2: for example
column3: the fire in 1849.  That’s a random event; in May 1849 there is a spark that catches from one steamboat to another and burns down a lot of downtown in St. Louis.  But that turns out to be a great thing for the merchants of St. Louis because they are able to change their trade patterns from being about a North-South trade to New Orleans and old French patterns into a new East-West trade that takes advantage of their new position as a gateway to the West.  Similarly
column4: with Forest Park
column5: the fact that Governor Tilden of New York is in St. Louis in 1876 to be named the Democratic national nominee at the National Convention
column6: that fact that they take a break from that convention to go out and dedicate Forest Park
column7: I think it tied together these two moments where the national conversation is shifting very dramatically and the fact that both the Tilden-Hayes Election and the election to split the city and county of St. Louis end up very contested.  There is a lot of discussion of fraud and they are basically both decided by extra-electoral decision making
column8: that was another thing that helped me to see that these events could be tied together and help close the story.

column1: CWBR: You discussed how insurance policies helped businessmen and women rebuild St. Louis after the great fire of 1849
column2: describing the fire as their opportunity to start anew. How common were insurance policies during the period and how significantly did the decision to purchase insurance on one’s business and inventory play into the rebuilding of St. Louis?
right at the top or northern part of the waterfront
column3: what you have is a number of the city’s most wealthy individuals.  They’re French fur-trading families and they have a lot of investments in various places and I think
column4: because they were well-connected to other trading centers
column5: to the uncertainties of the steamboat trade
column6: and to the fur trade rendezvous
column7: they seemed to be better connected to the insurance markets.  My analysis shows that
column8: on the southern part of the fire
column9: that was the area where it was more working-class
column10: in modern terms.  And those individuals
column11: not only were they not able to save their belongings
column12: because the whole city had rushed to save the northern part of the city
column13: but they also were not people who were insured.  And that area is emptied out
column14: not because they’re able to rebuild with insurance money
column15: but because they have to go live with relatives or other people.  So
column16: there’s two sets of change happening along the river: the northern part that is able to capitalize on the fact of the fire and the southern part who are really victims of it. And so it was interesting to see these two effects of the fire right in two different neighborhoods along the riverfront.

column1: CWBR: It seemed to me that Thomas Hart Benton had a pretty firm grasp on the future and he understood the consequences of politics and the future of slavery? How was this insight possible and what did it mean for his career?

AA: Benton was born in North Carolina but at an early age he had moved west and he saw a rise of the West as the thing that would raise his fortunes in the country. He was instrumental in the statehood debate and the Missouri Compromise that allowed Missouri to join as a state and then
column2: from 1821
column3: he was in the U.S. Senate representing Missouri and what he understood was the interest of the greater West.  The introduction of the book talks about the three sides of the Civil War and this effort to see North
column4: South
column5: and West
column6: not just North and South.  That is something that Benton really exemplifies along with a lot of other figures who we often think of as being on opposite sides: people like Abraham Lincoln
column7: Jefferson Davis
column8: and Henry Clay.  Some of them ended up in different political parties but there is kind of a western agenda that all of them are pushing
column9: thinking that the railroad
column10: if it reaches out
column11: first if they gain the continent
column12: as they do in 1848 and then
column13: once they can reach the Pacific
column14: once they build that railroad
column15: the politics
column16: economics
column17: and culture of the country will change pretty dramatically because of the differences in the West.  They’re not so worried about slavery; they’re not so worried about tariffs and some of these eastern concerns because they think
column18: once the mining riches of the West and the natural riches of the West
column19: and certain other interests out on the Pacific become the center of national attention
column20: then the West will really rise and these eastern concerns will matter a lot less.  I think Benton is probably the person in American history who embodies that in one of the most powerful ways
column21: especially for a politician rather than someone who is an adventurer
column22: someone like Kit Carson.

column1: CWBR: How did city leaders reconcile their desire that St. Louis be a beacon for growth
column2: progress
column3: and the American ideal in the future with the fact that immigrants from Europe were flooding the city and fueling this growth in the first place? Was St. Louis another “city on a hill?”

column1: AA: This is another area where the unusual demographics of St. Louis play in. It’s a city that has a large northern population and also a growing German population who are often free labor
column2: free soil advocates
column3: yet it’s a large city on the border of slavery and freedom in a slave state
column4: in this exceptional geographic location of Missouri after the Missouri Compromise.  And so you have individuals from all of the different communities investing in the railroad; you have French fur-trading families who often held slaves investing in the railroad.  You have the Germans; you have those from the Northeast.  And part of what they thought is
column5: like we can see later with Stephen Douglas and the Kansas-Nebraska Act
column6: is that they saw the building of the railroad as linked to something that would dramatically change the way that slavery would function.  And so I see some of their support for popular sovereignty-the idea that
column7: as you move into the territory
column8: the people of the territory themselves will determine if slavery is necessary or not-I think that they see that
column9: as railroads are this transformative technology
column10: they’re going to change the reality of living in these communities and only then will we know if slavery needs to continue or not.  Looking back
column11: we know that’s a little optimistic
column12: that slavery was a little more entrenched than they seemed to believe
column13: but I think that really motivated their policy; they really thought the railroad would solve all.

column1: CWBR: How were the slavery debates problematic for the supporters of the Transcontinental Railroad in St. Louis? Was this an indication that some semblance of unity is necessary to achieve national goals?
AA: There’s definitely language that puts forth St. Louis as this great national city
column2: this place that the whole country should look to.  The most prominent moment where that happens is the founding of Washington University as this national
column3: non-sectarian
column4: non-political driven place that would be a beacon to education in the country.  They talk of themselves as being the Harvard or Yale of the West
column5: two years after they’re founded
column6: before they even have a building.  Later
column7: during Reconstruction
column8: there’s also an effort to move the national capital to St. Louis and they think that’s
column9: among other things
column10: a nice gesture of sectional reconciliation.  It will be in a place that is North
column11: South
column12: and West and not in Washington which they see as peripheral to the newly continental nation.  So there are definitely ways in which St. Louis is trying to put forward itself as a global city.  One of the pamphlets that’s written for the Capital Removal Campaign
column13: is called “St. Louis: The Future Great City of the World” and so they are very much embracing the German immigrants
column14: the Irish immigrants
column15: and others as coming to a city that’s on the rise
column16: that they’re willing to take the best of the world and make it into what they see as the promise of the United States for the whole continent and then trade with the world as well.

column1: CWBR: On Page 138 you make the statement that “Missouri’s condition was so stable that the principles for postwar government could already be considered in June 1862.” What
column2: if anything
column3: did President Lincoln and his administration learn from their experiences in St. Louis?

column1: AA: What you see in St. Louis is
column2: in May 1861 there is a skirmish at Camp Jackson as the Confederate-leaning state militia gather and then Union troops
column3: along with a number of German volunteers
column4: surround them and get them to surrender.  That’s really the only kind of battle in St. Louis.  What you see after that is the building of gunboats
column5: the training of troops
column6: including lots of U.S. Colored Troops
column7: the caring for wounded and refugees from both sides
column8: as well as new schools for African Americans
column9: and a pretty strong presence for the Provost Marshall to keep the Confederate sympathizers at bay
column10: but also not to expel them
column11: not to remove them from the economy.  So I think that balancing act
column12: that effort to make sure the city is still a place of North
column13: South
column14: and West is what makes it an interesting model for thinking about wartime reconstruction.   What does Lincoln gain from it
column15: on the other hand?  I think a lot of the examples are in the negative.  General Fremont puts forward a proclamation in his efforts to deal with the Confederates in the western Missouri
column16: where he is going to start emancipating slaves in 1861.  Lincoln immediately shuts that down; Fremont is eventually removed.  There are other examples where St. Louis gets ahead of what Lincoln thinks is prudent for the whole country and so he wants to be a little more cautious of it.  On the other hand
column17: Fremont works with William Greenleaf Eliot to create the Western Sanitary Commission and its as active as the U.S. Sanitary Commission out of Philadelphia in being the relief organization for the sick and wounded and refugees.  And so that’s an important part of the picture and the Sanitary Fair that they hold in 1864 gathers signatures and mementoes from heroes and notables all through
column18: not only the West
column19: but the country as a whole.  Nelly Grant
column20: General Grant’s daughter is instrumental in selling a number of raffle tickets for important items too.  So that’s an interesting moment that thinks about how the home front notables
column21: in ways
column22: were connected to the military leaders as well.

column1: CWBR: What were some of the challenges that St. Louisans faced that made their Reconstruction experience unique to the rest of the country?
AA: They had been a Union city in a border state
column2: sort of nervously held for the Union so they’re dealing with the aftermath of a slave society as much as the South is
column3: but the city is not destroyed.  They hadn’t been a place of battles in a way that Richmond and other places were so you have some of the political issues that faced the former Confederacy but the economic possibility that the North and South are experiencing during Reconstruction.  You have the mix of things going on and so I highlight both the success of people linked to St. Louis in creating Lincoln University
column4: which is the school for African Americans founded by ex-U.S. Colored Troops
column5: really a unique case in that way and also the first permanent memorial to Abraham Lincoln anywhere in the country.  On the other hand
column6: this capital removal effort
column7: though it looks like something that is trying to bring everyone together and bring the national attention to St. Louis
column8: as it falls apart
column9: very quickly it becomes clear that these are individuals who are willing to leave African-American civil rights question behind as they think about ways to reintegrate ex-Confederates and they sort of reinvigorate the Democratic Party through people like Frank Blair and Benjamin Gratz Brown
column10: Missourians become very active in what ends up stalling
column11: and eventually reversing
column12: the advances of Reconstruction.

column1: CWBR: You close your book with the quote
column2: describing St. Louis as “impossible or visionary
column3: unfortunate or impractical
column4: ” and suggest that this might be a broad model for the general cultural civil war at the center of U.S. history. What can we take from your analysis of St. Louis that we can apply to our broader understanding of American history?

column2: the period
column3: I would say following
column4: even the War of 1812 forward to the firing on Fort Sumter
column5: that period is a period of really vast dreams for the United States.  You have people like Ralph Waldo Emerson and Walt Whitman making poetic or artistic goals but you also have people like Thomas Hart Benton or the filibusterer
column6: William Walker
column7: making territorial goals
column8: thinking about this is what we’re going to do when we integrate the West
column9: this is what we are going to do when we integrate Nicaragua
column10: Cuba
column11: or other places that the United States doesn’t take in this period.  So
column12: there are so many wild dreams and
column13: the fact that many of them succeed
column14: we often don’t think of how impossible some of these goals were.  When the question over slavery becomes paramount and the war begins
column15: you begin to see a recalculation of how people think about the role of these broad ideas in their own lives. In a book like Louis Menand’s The Metaphysical Club you see the effect of the fighting on some of the deepest thinkers in the country. What I’m trying to do is bring the political story and the cultural story together in that way. You see the success of some wild dreams in St. Louis-their work on the railroad
column16: the success of Washington University-but you also see their failure of something like the moving of the national capital and the way in which they set up a large urban park that doesn’t really allow them to recapture the national imagination quite as they hoped. And I think that those contradictions between really broad claims and the realities of the society that is dealing with the end of slavery is really something that shapes much of nineteenth-century U.S. history in places far beyond St. Louis.

column1: CWBR: That concludes our interview for this issue. Professor Arenson
column2: thank you for joining us today and discussing The Great Heart of the Republic: St. Louis and the Cultural Civil War.

column1:
AA: Thank you; I’ve enjoyed it.

" Buman
column2: Nathan Winter 2012 2012-02-01 Interview Harvard University Press ""

column1:
4827 978-0-8078-3436-7 $35.00 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVEW:
Creating a Confederate Kentucky: the Lost Cause and Civil War Memory in a Border State Marshall
column2: Anne			"<h3>Interview with Anne Marshall
column3: Assistant Professor of History at Mississippi State University

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview

column2: Civil War Book Review is pleased to talk with Anne Marshall
column3: author of a brand-new work
column4: Creating a Confederate Kentucky: The Lost Cause and Civil War Memory in a Border State. Professor Marshall
column5: thank you for joining me this afternoon.

column1: Anne Marshall (AM): Well thank you so much for having me.
CWBR: What inspired you to look at the Civil War and Civil War memory and how did you come to choose Kentucky as the focus for your study?

AM: Well I really chose Kentucky because it sort of chose me I guess. I grew up in Kentucky; I had always sort of noticed as I was growing up that there was some real sort of dissonance between the sort of standard history of the state and its Civil War experience that I learned in fourth grade Kentucky history. And then the sort of public commemoration that I saw all around me
column2: whether in historical markers or monuments or sort of the public dialog about the war and so when I got to graduate school this is right around the time when there was just a lot of great work about historical memory and the Civil War coming out and this was right when David Blight’s book came out and I just thought
column3: you know
column4: this would be a really great angle at which to study the question of why Kentucky supposedly succeeded after the Civil War and that's really how I came to the topic.

column1: CWBR: James McPherson has written on the motivations of soldiers and
column2: more recently
column3: in light of important books by Chandra Manning and Gary Gallagher
column4: what can your analysis of wartime Kentucky say about why soldiers fought? Did the Emancipation Proclamation shift the ways in which Confederate and Unionist soldiers and residents in Kentucky viewed the conflict?

column2: it definitely did and I think in a way different from that which these scholars sort of point to
column3: I think that the general consensus (at least the question that they sort of hold up) is whether or not
column4: and to what extent
column5: the Emancipation Proclamation served as a real motivation for northern troops who had been fighting to preserve the union.  And for Kentuckians who were (white Kentuckians at least) who were fighting to preserve the union the Emancipation Proclamation really had a negative effect.  This was certainly not what some Union troops that were from Kentucky were fighting for and
column6: in fact
column7: many of them became incredibly disenchanted with the war effort; they had sort of seen the writing on the wall
column8: of course
column9: as Lincoln had been offering compensated emancipation to Kentucky before he issued the Emancipation Proclamation.  So they sort of understood what was happening and then
column10: of course
column11: Kentucky was exempt from that proclamation but they were very dismayed because for them turning the war for union into a war to end slavery was antithetical to the entire reason they had decided to fight for the union to begin with
column12: and I do think that another important difference between Kentucky (white Kentucky) and its rational for fighting
column13: in terms of nationalism
column14: I think it’s important to consider how many Kentuckians didn’t fight.  About 71% of white Kentuckians decided not to fight.  Many
column15: many Kentuckians evaded Lincoln’s draft so really it’s not so much in many ways a question of I think Kentucky’s experience shows that for many loyal citizens that loyalty didn’t necessarily translate into a commitment to actually don a uniform and go off and fight.

column1: CWBR: That's interesting and I wonder shifting towards the years after the civil war. I wonder if the violence and lawlessness during 1865-1885 if that makes Kentucky unique or were these problems and challenge did they present a problem for residents in federally-reconstructed states as well? What might Kentucky’s experience say about the effectiveness of Federal forces in southern states?
AM: I think that’s a great question because I think that as we know the South was a very violent place after the Civil War
column2: but I think with states like Kentucky
column3: and also Missouri to even greater extent
column4: tell us is that the border states were particularly violent and I think that this was an effect of the kind of fighting that had been so prevalent: the kind of guerrilla conflict
column5: if you will
column6: that had been so prevalent in the state during the Civil War.  And also the fact that they weren’t federally constructed
column7: as you say. They really didn’t have any
column8: there wasn’t this official military occupation in most places. There was really no apparatus outside of the state government to quell the violence in these states and so I think that it does point to the fact that in other southern states certainly federal forces had an effect in terms of quelling violence.

column1: CWBR: well you mentioned earlier the unionists that were able to keep their state out of the confederacy and who fought for the union army in times. I wonder why did former Unionists
column2: who successfully kept the state out of the Confederacy during the war
column3: why did they fail to garner enough support to combat the conservative violent factions that you spoke about just a second ago in the post-bellum period?

column1: AM: Yeah well that’s another great question and what happened was a lot of these former Unionists were the conservatives. They weren’t necessarily these leaders
column2: former Unionist leaders who were able to use their pulls to keep Kentucky out of the Confederacy in the Union
column3: weren’t necessarily the ones condoning the violence.  And in many cases they deplored the violence; they were also conservative and I think that after the war
column4: and certainly the fact that the war had turned from a war of union into a war of emancipation
column5: affected their conservative terms after the war and there’s no question that
column6: in spite of the fact that many of them did deplore the means (the violent means) that the violence was an effective way of bringing about political ends that really suited them.  And on the ground the violence really sort of served their interest of their constituency
column7: at least as far as their constituencies saw this
column8: and that this violence against African Americans was used by lower-class whites to maintain their ideas about white supremacy.  And also their access to labor
column9: they were using violence to keep African Americans away from the polls but also away from jobs
column10: so really these conservatives
column11: it’s not that they condoned the violence
column12: but they certainly were aware of the fact that
column13: in some ways
column14: the violence served their interests and I think that that made them sort of politically ineffectual to some extent when it came to quelling the violence.  Although
column15: there were certainly calls from
column16: not only former Unionists
column17: but former Confederates
column18: especially people like Henry Watterson who was the editor of the Louisville Courier
column19: journalists at that time to crack down on the violence.

column1: CWBR: Shifting to one of the key phrases in the title of the book the lost cause. Some scholars have looked at this stating that perhaps the strength of the Lost Cause in New Orleans resulted from their relatively early and easy falling to Federal forces and inherit guilt in the city that helped them to embrace Confederate celebrations after the war. How does the experience in Kentucky compare to a place like New Orleans or perhaps other areas that failed to become Confederate strongholds during the war like Unionist Tennessee?

column2: well I think that it’s
column3: rather than focusing on the experiences of those places during the war
column4: it’s interesting to sort of see an effect that historians cite the guilt factor in New Orleans is a little bit like the fact that they tend to focus on the political crack-down under martial law and the federal forces in Kentucky late in the war as sort of a factor of turning Kentuckians against the Union once and for all in the end.  And this
column5: according to a lot of scholars of Kentucky
column6: was the spring board for the Lost Cause
column7: but I think what’s interesting in all of these case whether we look at postwar Kentucky
column8: postwar New Orleans
column9: postwar East Tennessee
column10: is the fact that no matter what the particular situation during the war
column11: that southerners of all political stripes could really find a lot in the Lost Cause that suited their modern (their contemporary) political imperative during the postwar era.  I really think that there really probably is some truth to the idea of guilt or the idea of (in Kentucky) of the poor treatment at the hands of the federal officials during the war.  But what really makes the Lost Cause resonate for so long in these places is that it really carries with it a set of values in the postwar era that suits people all over the South and in the North in some places as well.  So I think that that’s really where I would place the power of the Lost Cause and reason that southerners
column12: no matter what their wartime experience was or their sentiments were
column13: can really sort of grab on to it in the postwar era.

column1: CWBR: earlier you mentioned the importance of David Blight in sort of setting the foundation in the way you looked at the post bellum period when you began your studies. Thinking about the recent scholarship of David Blight and Heather Cox Richardson and the ways in which they examine how whites reconciled nationally by pushing blacks to the margins
column2: might Kentucky be indicative of a broader trend and how does your study illustrate reconciliation in a national context?
I think that one of the points that I
column3: from the beginning of this project
column4: saw as a both being and engaging with those notions that David Blight and Heather Cox Richardson put out there that are very important in telling the story in terms of narrative and reconciliation and having to push.  In the case of David Blight
column5: he argues that essentially northern whites relegated this
column6: sort of emancipation narrative as he calls it
column7: to the dust bin in order to reconcile with southern whites.  And I think that this is a really resonant argument but one thing that I found in Kentucky is that
column8: if you look at it and you look at what the Civil War soldiers were saying the during the war and you look at what the Civil War meant for all of these pro-slavery Unionists
column9: what becomes apparent is that this emancipationist narrative was really never viable to begin with.  So in essence
column10: I guess
column11: that means that what Kentucky can show us is that some Unionists never pushed African Americans to the margin after the war because they had always pushed them to the margin; they were never part of that vision of what the Civil War meant except for the fact that that meant the end of slavery and that was a bad thing.  So I think that that really crippled white unionist memory in Kentucky for a long time and so I do think that that this really does illustrate
column12: in terms of reconciliation
column13: because I think that it shows that there are lots of narratives out there and that in many ways white Kentuckians show this reconciliation happening much more quickly than it does nationally
column14: which we tend to focus on national reconciliation happening in the 1890s
column15: but I think in Kentucky's case whites reconciled in Kentucky much
column16: much earlier over these questions of race.

column1: CWBR: That’s really interesting and in terms of reconciliation it’s my understanding from reading your book that GAR reunions play a large role in the reconciliation and I wonder
column2: do you have any sense if African Americans had been incorporated into northern Grand Army of the Republic reunions and encampments before the Louisville meeting in 1895 or were the challenges that organizers faced to incorporate African-American veterans more commonplace?
actually African Americans had been regular part of GAR meetings in may northern chapters.  They were integrated so African Americans and whites joined alike
column3: they met alike
column4: they remembered the war in some common ways and actually there’s a great book out about this
column5: Barbara Gannon’s
column6: The Won Cause where she actually refutes some of what David Blight argues as well in terms of war memories and she uses the GAR membership and the integrated GAR membership to really show this. And so I think
column7: in that sense
column8: Louisville was presented a sort of new challenge: how were these northern
column9: integrated chapters going to come in as equals; they come to the South and suddenly African Americans and white members were supposed to be segregated and have different accommodations and sit in separate places and really
column10: in that sense
column11: the Louisville experience was different.

column1: CWBR: What did the southern literature during the period
column2: specifically Annie Fellows Johnston who sold millions of copies of The Little Colonel (later becoming a movie)
column3: what did that do for the image of the South in a national context
column4: as we are looking at southern literature and sort of the popularity of things like gone with the wind and what not in popular culture in giving an impression of southern culture?

column2: well I would say that the Little Colonel series had a similar effect to the works of Joel Chandler Harris or Thomas Nelson Page in that it really sort of spun these tales even though the Little Colonel was set in the New South
column3: it was actually set at the turn of the century
column4: which is when Annie Fellows Johnston was writing.  It really evoked a sort of Old South gentility; it gave northerners a way to sort of look at the South and the post-Civil War South which carried according to Annie Fellows Johnston a lot of the same conventions in terms of that the Old South had carried
column5: for example
column6: the African-American characters were not slaves but they were devoted servants
column7: still
column8: who had chosen to remain with their former owners because they were well-treated and happy.  And there was a lot this air of the Old South
column9: that was sort of positioned in the New South and that gave northerners (people all over the world as a matter of fact) a way to look at the South with this sort of sense of nostalgia
column10: a sense that sort of gave it a comforting elegant gentile setting and a world that was increasingly tumultuous. This was a time of increasing industrialization and increasing immigration and a lot of white Americans all over the nation were really sort of unsure about what was happening to their increasingly urbanized world. And so being able to go and read these books that evoked this sense of Old South/New South gentility was sort of a form of escapism that was really very appealing to many Americans.

column2: how does looking at the ways in which Kentucky emerged from the war inform or shape our understanding of current events in a state like Kentucky versus other states like South Carolina
column3: Alabama
column4: or Pennsylvania?

column2: well I’m not sure that we can sort of trace a direct lineage in terms of a sort of causes and effects of Kentucky’s war experiences and its sort of contemporary realities of Kentucky.  But I certainly think if we're thinking about identity which is something I wrote a lot about in this book
column3: not only just looking at the Civil War narrative that that came out of Kentucky's Civil War experience in the aftermath
column4: but I was also looking at
column5: in a general the way
column6: that these Civil War narratives sort of created an identity for the state as a whole.  And I certainly think that the way that Kentucky's identity developed after the war
column7: the things that made it seem like a former Confederate state have stuck with it in a lot of different ways
column8: it still has this reputation for being sort of simultaneously poor but also having a sort of patina of wealth to it which we can associate with the Old South.  Some of what Annie Fellows Johnston was trying to create in her books
column9: for example
column10: and it still has a reputation for being a sort of violent state
column11: so I think that there are still some elements there that are.  Certainly the racism that existed in postwar Kentucky that informed a lot of this identity is still there; I’m not sure that it’s any greater of an extent in Kentucky than it is in certainly in other southern places
column12: and perhaps even in northern places today
column13: but there’s still elements of that there so I think
column14: in those ways
column15: some of this identity is still sticking with Kentucky.

column1: CWBR: Well it’s interesting you mention identity and I have to ask why has it taken so long to incorporate African Americans and even Abraham Lincoln into the historical analysis of the Civil War in Kentucky and turning to the future and the present as well how has the Civil War Sesquicentennial celebration encouraged engaging and incorporating groups like these groups?

AM: Well I think in terms of African Americans I think Kentucky is sort of where a lot of other southern and formerly Confederate states are on this sort of public acknowledgement of African-American history in general. But also the history of slavery
column2: the history of slavery’s influence on Kentucky's Civil War experience
column3: and also the impact that African Americans have had on Kentucky's Civil War experience in that its sort of come in the aftermath of the Civil Rights Movement where people were connecting present fights for African-American rights in the 1960s and on into the 1970s with the deprivation of those rights that had come out of the aftermath of slavery.  And then had the promise of those rights had not been fulfilled in the Reconstruction era
column4: I think that in this sense it’s sort of similar to the national narrative and it’s just really been in the last 20 or 25 years or so that really African-American groups have really been at the forefront of trying to gain recognition for their role in the state’s history and to insert their experiences into the Civil War narrative of the state’s history.  And the Lincoln question is really interesting because he was of course a Kentuckian and was hated in his home state for so long
column5: getting less than 2% of the popular vote in 1860
column6: and then he really didn’t gain any popularity among the states whites after the war
column7: so what’s really been interesting of course that the Lincoln bicentennial
column8: which those events were carried out mostly in 2009
column9: and the state sort of did a whole 180 on this one and embraced Abraham Lincoln and had a couple of years of celebrations really where they focused on every aspect no matter how small every connection that Lincoln had in the state.  And I think that that’s really also a realization of Lincoln’s legacy and buying into this finally saying Kentucky is buying into this David Blight emancipationist narrative 150 years later to I think that the sesquicentennial was sort of
column10: in essence
column11: took off the tone for the sesquicentennial remembrance have come out of the Lincoln bicentennial in the sense that
column12: with the sort of events the state is highlighting this year
column13: they are trying to sell a broader story of the Civil War that incorporates Confederates
column14: white Unionists
column15: African Americans so I think that this sort of evolution of historical memory and public history as well.

column2: thank you so much for joining us this afternoon and discussing your new book
column3: Creating a Confederate Kentucky: The Lost Cause and Civil War Memory in a Border State.

column1:
AM: Well thank you so much for having me.

" Buman
column2: Nathan Spring 2011 2011-05-01 Interview University of North Carolina Press ""

column1:
5928 9781469617770 $35.00 CWBR Author Interview:
Through the Heart of Dixie: Sherman's March and American Memory Rubin
column2: Anne Sarah			"<h3>Interview with Anne Sarah Rubin
column3: Associate Professor of History at the University of Maryland
column4: Baltimore County

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is excited to speak with Anne Sarah Rubin
column2: associate professor of history at the University of Maryland Baltimore County. Professor Rubin previously authored
column3: <i>A Shattered Nation: The Rise and Fall of the Confederacy
column4: 1861-1868. Today we get to discuss her most recent book
column5: Through the Heart of Dixie: Sherman's March and American Memory. Professor Rubin
column6: thank you for joining us today.

column1: Anne Sarah Rubin (ASR): Thank you very much for having me.
CWBR: So just to start we always like to hear
column2: what lead you to this project?

column1: ASR: I decided to write about Sherman's march and the place of Sherman's march in American culture a long time actually before I started the book. It was a kind of confluences of things that happened during graduate school
column2: things that I read and things that I saw. I had read Charles Royster's The Destructive War
column3: which is a fascinating dual biography of Sherman and Stonewall Jackson and it looks in the way of how Americans became more comfortable with this kind of destruction and devastation. All around that same time was the first time I saw the Ross McElwee movie Sherman's March where he
column4: in the early 1980's goes down South and he was planning to write a documentary about the legacy of Sherman's March. He wound up having all these romantic problems
column5: so what the movie really becomes is him trying to figure out why he can't have a girlfriend and Sherman's March is a metaphor. I thought that was really interesting and unusual. Also
column6: right around that time I saw references in a documentary then read James Reston's book Sherman’s March in Vietnam
column7: where Reston tries to make a connection between Sherman's march and the destructiveness and devastation that Americans wreaked in Vietnam. Somehow it all kind of came together. There was something special about Sherman's march that made it unlike other Civil War campaigns and that gave it a sort of greater cultural power than other campaigns and events had
column8: so that's why I decided to start exploring it.

column1: CWBR: It's interesting that what draws you in is the cultural power of the march and we see that even in the name
column2: because it's “Sherman's March to the Sea” but we really don't have a good name for it. It seems like we ought to at least add “Sherman's March to the Sea
column3: and Back
column4: ” right?

column2: exactly and what happens
column3: what I think is really interesting and what I was not very aware of in the beginning was how important the Carolinas campaign actually is. First of all
column4: Sherman thought that Carolinas campaign was more important and I think at one point he refers to the march to the sea to a mere change of base. It's the Carolinas campaign that is in fact even more devastating and destruction than the Georgia portion of the march. There's a real since of anger and vengeance in South Carolina in the part of the men and Sherman is very disingenuous about this in his memoir he writes
column5: “Well somehow the men got the idea that South Carolina was the cause of all their troubles and the cause of this war. They wanted to be harder on South Carolina and I felt like I couldn’t restrain them less they sort of loose their fighting edge and their vigor.”  He lets them loose on South Carolina and there is much more destruction of personal property of houses as opposed to outbuildings. I'm not minimizing what happens in Georgia only saying that it's actually worse than South Carolina and yet it's much less well known. Then in North Carolina the men are supposed to put the gloves back on
column6: because of Unionism in North Carolina because of the unionist population there. They don't quite do it to the degree I think that Sherman would have wanted them to do. That's why the book in its entirety is about Sherman's march and I felt really strongly about how it had to be more than just the Georgia piece.

column1: CWBR: Why is it you think that Georgia--and it seems like it happened fairly quickly by the early twentieth century—Georgia and Atlanta specifically kind of manages to claim the effects of that march almost all to itself and it seems like especially the South Carolina story is sort of lost outside of South Carolina. Why do you think that happened so quickly?

ASR: It is really a curious thing and I think it happened for a couple of reasons. I think there is sort of narrative tidiness to the Georgia piece of it that it's the march to the sea. It's got this kind of inherent drama or destination
column2: you're going to the sea. I think that's why
column3: for example
column4: it holds more cultural power
column5: meaning
column6: and people remember its violence more than the Shenandoah Valley Campaign or something like that in terms of how it blocks everything out. Also
column7: a lot of it actually is the impact of Gone with the Wind
column8: so that's a little later than what you're saying. It's the 1930's
column9: 1936 is the novel and the movie is 1939. Gone with the Wind just exerts so much influence and defined Sherman's march for generations of Americans. One of the things that's pretty important to understand about Gone with the Wind is that Margaret Mitchell had grown up hearing stories about Sherman's march. It had happened to her grandparents and she also did a lot of research. She's very very careful in the book to be as scrupulously accurate as she can about all the military maneuvers. She writes in a letter at one point saying
column10: ""I don't want anybody coming to me and saying that I got it wrong."" True confession time
column11: I had seen Gone With the Wind for the first time in the 8th grade history class
column12: and I always like to add unironically.  I actually grew up in the North too
column13: this was right outside New York City. Then I had read the book
column14: which I was about thirteen at the time and it was the longest book I had ever read
column15: I was so enamored by the romance and all the reasons Gone with the Wind is a great novel and movie. Then when I became a historian and a southern historian then I started to realize how much was problematic about Gone with the Wind--the way it treats race and reconstruction. I moved away from it for a while but when I started looking at it again for this book
column16: I sat down and reread the novel. For the first night I thought I'd just skim it and wound up literally staying up until two in the morning reading it. I was sort of sucked back into it again. Now I see that Gone with the Wind is this really powerful document. If you want an illustration of what white southerners thought about the Civil War and reconstruction in the 1920's and 30's read Gone with the Wind. It's straight out the Dunning School. For all of those reasons I think Gone with the Wind has a huge impact.

column1: CWBR: Do you think the timing of Gone with the Wind is also sort of critical? It emerges right about the same time that a lot of these actual Union veterans of the march
column2: the “bummers
column3: ” a lot of them are in their later years or gone. Do you think that the timing was right for
column4: even in the North
column5: a narrative that suggested the cause may have been just
column6: but even [northerners] can admit or believe that Sherman was perhaps a little bit too much?

column1: ASR: I think that's interesting. I haven't really thought about that but you're exactly right. You know it comes out
column2: the movie
column3: right around the 75th anniversary of the march. There's a huge fanfare about it. They do this three day premiere with people dressed up in costumes and hoop skirts. In one of these crazy you-can't-make-it-up historical coincidences
column4: Martin Luther King as a child actually sings in a choir that performs at the Gone with the Wind premiere. What are the chances? So anyway I do think there is a lot of that
column5: that there's not ever a good kind of northern counter-narrative of Sherman’s march. Even the northern novels don't really--Yeah that's right there's not really a northern defense of the march in that period. Veterans themselves in the 1870's
column7: and 90's they talk about the march in very heroic terms that they see it as winning the war and they minimize the degree of destruction
column8: but you don't really see that coming out afterwards. The condemnations of Gone with the Wind are not about the way it portrays Sherman it's about the way it portrays African Americans and the way it portrays Reconstruction
column9: as the carnival of corruption. So you're right that's a great insight. I should have put that in the book.

column1: CWBR: Going off of your point there about Reconstruction it does seem that this march is really heavily mythologized very quickly and even though it has a tidy narrative as you say you also write that it sort of is missing the central cast of characters and missing the epic battles that the other mythologized events in the Civil War like Pickett's Charge
column2: and there are a number of reasons why it occupies such a huge space. I was hoping you could expand on that a little bit.

column1: ASR: There's very few actual battles along Sherman's march and from the Union side in particular they take very few casualties over the course of the march. Very few people died. That's one of the reasons that Union soldiers remember the march fondly. It doesn't have the kind of heroic grandeur such as Pickett's Charge or Cold Harbor or anything like that. It is the military movement that is about civilians
column2: I think in a way that fewer or any other campaigns are described that way. Historians know about all of these campaigns against civilians and places on the border or as I mention the Shenandoah Valley
column3: but the general public doesn't. So what happens is that Sherman's march becomes the scapegoat for all the ills visited on civilians
column4: and all the devastation wrought on the South. Then I think there's a little bit of conflation too of any destruction and devastation is going be blamed on Sherman. These legends
column5: Oh Sherman burned my family’s house in Alabama
column6: well no
column7: because he wasn't there. I've had people come up to me giving talks and someone how came up to me recently saying ""Oh we have a chair with scorch marks on the back and the scorch marks are from Sherman
column8: and it could be from the march because this person mentioned where the chair had been and that in fact was in South Carolina on the route of the march so that could be true. But I think there's a lot of that kind of legend that grows up around it.

column1: CWBR: Well even in just the way the march is described I thought it was interesting when it comes down to the tactics. In the [popular] narrative
column2: it always comes down in a swath
column3: but it wasn’t actually in a swath right?

column1: ASR: The phrase that I always use is
column2: we think of it as this 50-mile wide lawn mower stripe but it's not. It's more like a 50-mile row of stitches in that there are a lot of places that aren't touched on Sherman's march. One of the things I explore in the book are that there are all these different stories and legends that grow up
column3: about the reasons why this house was spared or that house was spared. It occurred to that the reason there are so many stories about homes being spared for different reasons was in fact so many homes were spared. You can't make this argument that Sherman's march cut this 50-mile wide swath and at the same time have tourism brochures and what-not praising all the antebellum homes that are still standing. It becomes this interesting way for stories about the march to come up that [people say] “this house was spared because we put up Masonic apron on the door or that house was spared because there were pretty girls there
column4: or we saved the family silver by hiding it somewhere clever
column5: or the jewelry got stuck in the baby’s diaper and that's why we still have the jewelry.” These ways of outwitting the Yankees become really prevalent
column6: common stories.

column1: CWBR: It seems that compares to a lot of other Civil War memory--of course women have played a huge role in shaping a lot of those memories with the Daughters of the Confederacy and what-not--but it seems women play an even more essential role when it comes to Sherman's march because they're actually the actors
column2: right?

column1: ASR: In most cases women were the ones that confronted the Sherman soldiers when they came onto their farms or plantations. Partly this was because most able-bodied men were away
column2: and those able-bodied men who weren't away often hid when they knew Sherman was coming. They figured the women would be largely protected by their gender. One of the big misconceptions we have today about Sherman's march is that we talk about it in the context of “total war
column3: ” whatever “total war” means
column4: and to us it means a war on civilians that involves the death of civilians. It's total war in the WWII or the Vietnam or Gulf War sense where there's actual killing of civilians
column5: and that just doesn't happen along Sherman's march. They're not hauling civilians out and shooting them. They're not using sexual violence as a weapon the way that we've seen in ethnic cleansing and things like that. I don't want to minimize the impact the march had on civilians and it was terrifying for them
column6: but it was a war against civilian property not against civilian persons.

column1: CWBR: Then why do you think that narrative seems to be so entrenched? It seems pretty evident that even if one could broadly define Sherman's war against property as still some kind of form of terror tactics
column2: he's not the first even in the Civil War to do that.

column1: ASR: I think it's the triumph actually of a lot of the Lost Cause in ascribing this Sherman and it's the triumph of something like Gone With the Wind where that's the narrative that's put forward. Sherman I think
column2: people always ask if Sherman was a war criminal and the answer to that I would say is no. I think Sherman is someone who knew very well the laws of war and I would say that he knew where the line was and he pushed right up against that line
column3: but didn’t step over the line of what was permissible under the laws of war at the time. The only cases were where I think he might have are where in retaliation for Confederate actions he
column4: in one case a Union soldier steps on a minefield in Georgia and has his legs blown off and Sherman calls up a bunch of prisoners of war and has them walk across the minefield. They actually survived all that. Then there are some cases in South Carolina and North Carolina where some groups of Union foragers were killed and in retaliation Sherman ordered some Confederate prisoners killed. That I think is more morally problematic than the kind of destruction and destroying of supplies that the march engaged in.

column1: CWBR: It’s sort of ironic that one of the most morally problematic events of the whole march is actually afflicted on freed slaves when that is sort of Sherman's other legacy is that he visited great destruction on white southerners but also an agent of emancipation.

column2: I think that's one of the great contradictions of Sherman in Sherman's march. That's the other thing
column3: when people talk about the destruction and devastation of Sherman's march they're really talking about how it affected southern whites when in fact it's African Americans who in many ways bear sort of the equal brunt of the destruction. If all of the food in an area is taken or ruined that's starving African Americans as well as whites. Sherman was no friend to African Americans really he did not believe
column4: for example
column5: in African American troops. He did not have African Americans units marching with him and one of his subordinate commanders
column6: in this event that you allude to at Ebenezer Creek in Georgia
column7: where it's a big cypress swamp and the Union soldiers are crossing over pontoon bridges and they're being followed by hundreds if not thousands African Americans
column8: the subordinate commander actually named Jefferson Davis--no relation to the Confederate president--orders the pontoon bridges pulled up and leaves these African Americans with Confederate cavalry closing in on them. Their choice is try to swim across
column9: which many try and many drown
column10: or to be captured and sent back into slavery
column11: which is what happens to them. Sherman is ok with what happens he doesn't condemn Davis for this
column12: but when the news reaches Washington the Secretary of War Stanton comes down and is chastising Sherman for this and saying you [Sherman] go to do something for African Americans. So they meet first with about twenty African American ministers in Savannah and say
column13: ""Well what do you want
column14: what do you want to come out of the war?""  And they say
column15: ""We want land.""  Sherman offers a suggestion so outlandish that [Stanton] will back off--this is Special Order 15—that they take all of this land that has been abandoned by whites who fled all along the coast of Georgia and South Carolina
column16: altogether about 400
column17: 000 acres
column18: and divide it up into plots for African American families to settle on.  From Sherman's perspective
column19: that solves two problems.  It gets Stanton off his back
column20: and it means that these thousands of African American who've been following him will be resettled on this land and not continue to follow.  And it happens that this plan is briefly put into effect
column21: but I think the true test of it is that when Andrew Johnson
column22: after the war
column23: essentially voids it by returning all of this land to its original owners
column24: Sherman doesn't say a word.  He's moved on
column25: he doesn’t care.  He is simultaneously this great liberator
column26: and his army is a great army of liberation
column27: but they're not willing motivators. They're not ideologically motivated.

column1: CWBR: Sherman has quite a long career in fiction after the war and after he died
column2: but it seems like that is kind of a theme--whether in emancipation
column3: or in fiction
column4: or in Lost Cause histories--of Sherman being this agent that causes things to happen
column5: but he's not actually there.  He's always sort of there
column6: but off-frame.  I thought that was sort of an interesting contrast
column7: in your section on depictions in art and fiction
column8: with somebody like Lee
column9: who is like a King Arthur figure in a lot of depictions
column10: always on his horse leading and a presence.  I wonder if that is indicative of how people imagine Sherman as an early practitioner of total war--do people more naturally imagine Sherman as hunched over a table of maps and troops strength readouts
column11: sort of callously directing the logistics rather than galloping across a battlefield?

column1: ASR: I don't know if I ever thought of that--I think your portrayal of him hunched over a map is more generous than what I think are stereotypical portrayals
column2: which is sort of Sherman
column3: wild-eyed
column4: holding a torch
column5: where Sherman is personally burning things everywhere he goes.  Portrayals of Sherman are interesting.  There are not a lot of portrayals of Sherman's march
column6: certainly--The Mort Künstler
column7: Don Troiani
column8: those paintings that people love--are definitely more of a glorification of the war in Virginia.  Sherman
column9: though
column10: does have such a long postwar career too.  He's General-in-Chief of the Army for about another 15-20 years.  One thing I was struck by was that when he died in 1891
column11: there was this great outpouring of grief
column12: a national outpouring of grief
column13: with the black-bordered newspaper columns and the big funeral and all of that.  So he was a big national figure
column14: and doesn't have nearly the number of statues that Lee has
column15: but he does have a few big statues.  Specifically
column16: the one in New York City at 59th Street
column17: at the entrance to Central Park
column18: there's also a large one in Washington D.C. So I don't know that he's that slighted. Although I will say that I grew up seeing that statue all the time and had no idea that it was Sherman until I started working on this book.

column1: CWBR: Of course that could just be a function of being around a landmark
column2: monuments all the time
column3: you may not think to really look at it until you move away from it.  But to backtrack a bit
column4: I wanted to hear about the ""bummers.""  You were sort of surprised by their postwar sentiments
column5: right?

column2: because again
column3: when you come of age in the post-Vietnam world
column4: where so much of the writing about soldiers is in the vein of memoirs talking about post-traumatic stress
column5: and soldiers who were asked to do terrible things
column6: asked to make war on civilians
column7: and they feel guilty about that and they feel traumatized by all that.  You just don't find that with Sherman's ""bummers
column8: with the marchers.  The big caveat to that
column9: of course
column10: is that I can only know what they wrote down.  So certainly
column11: the veterans who are gung-ho veterans
column12: who belong to these veterans organizations and who go around and make speeches and all of that
column13: are only one subset.  They don't speak for all veterans
column14: but the dominant story that they tell is one of tremendous pride in their service
column15: tremendous pride in the march. They believed that they ended the war. I think they're not wrong about that. The analogy that I draw is that they're sort of like the airmen on the Enola Gay
column16: who believed that what they did was necessary
column17: was right
column18: and brought the war to a close.  So they're not troubled by it
column19: they're remarkably untroubled by it
column20: I found.  To them this was the great moment of their lives
column21: the great experience of many of their lives.

column1: CWBR: This march just keeps inspiring other people to try to experience it for themselves too. This experience thing [of Sherman's march]
column2: I don't know that it's stronger than with other events
column3: because certainly people visit battlefields all the time
column4: but retracing this entire march is a larger undertaking than visiting a battlefield park for a day.  It inspires this peculiar form of travel writing from just after the war through present day
column5: people travelling through the South
column6: coming to wildly different conclusions over time by visiting the same locales
column7: and you end up deciding to follow in their footsteps
column8: so what was that like?

column1: ASR: I felt like I couldn't really write about Sherman's march
column2: because so much of what I write has to do with these specific places
column3: that I didn't feel like I could do it without visiting them myself.  I didn't retrace the entire march but I did about two-thirds to three-quarters of it.  I did all of Georgia in 2008
column4: then I did the North Carolina from the Bennett place—from the surrender--to Columbia and then further south of Columbia.  I actually did that in reverse
column5: because I was driving down from Maryland.  I found it really interesting.  I thought that I would see a lot more memorialization.  And I just didn't find as much as I thought I would.  Even the roadside markers seemed more about troop movements
column6: and not really the impact of the march.  I found that surprising.  There was also such a contrast in the way that Atlanta sort takes their Sherman experience of being burned right before Sherman leaves on the march
column7: and they kind of run with it.  Atlanta put the Phoenix on their city seal
column8: and in a lot of way the march is kind of the best thing that ever happened to Atlanta
column9: whereas I was really struck in Columbia by how much angrier Columbia seemed.  Columbia seemed to still retain this sense of grievance from Sherman.  I’m actually looking forward to a big symposium there on the anniversary of Sherman’s burning the city.  I was glad I got to go
column10: and it will be interesting to go back. One of the fun side-effects of this book coming out is that I got to back to a few places. Even just seeing the names on the road signs again.

column1: CWBR: Given how much more room you saw in the memorializations you mentioned
column2: for added complexity that you show in the book here
column3: moving the memory beyond just troop movements
column4: do think that the memory of the march is as fluid as it was in the past? Do you think we'll start to see a little of this complexity and contradiction work its way into the popular memory?

column2: I'd like to think that complexity and fluidity moves in.  Certainly the Civil War Sesquicentennial in general has been a much more rich and diverse and complicated view of the war and what happened during the war
column3: compared to the centennial.  I'm by nature an optimist
column4: so I'll say yes
column5: I think our understating will become more complicated and more subtle
column6: rather than fixed. So we’ll close on an up note.

column2: I appreciate taking the time to sit and discuss with us your latest work
column3: Through the Heart of Dixie: Sherman's March and American Memory.

column2:
it was a pleasure.
