column2: Brian Craig			"<h3>Interview with Brian Craig Miller
column3: Associate Professor of History at Emporia State University

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is happy to speak with Brian Craig Miller
column2: Associate Professor of History at Emporia State University. Professor Miller previously authored John Bell Hood and the Fight for Civil War Memory
column3: and is Editor of the journal Civil War History. Today we get to discuss his most recent book
column4: Empty Sleeves: Amputation in the Civil War South. Professor Miller
column5: thank you for joining us today.

column1: Brian Craig Miller (BCM) : Thank you very much for having me.
CWBR: Ok so I always ask to start about what drew you to this project
column2: but I think in this case it’s a particularly important question
column3: given how potentially relevant these veterans’ challenges
column4: and their society’s reactions were
column5: as you mentioned toward the end of your book.

column2: it sort of came by accident in some ways.  In graduate school we were discussing new ways of thinking about Reconstruction
column3: and at that time I was starting to think about John Bell Hood as a potential thesis and dissertation topic
column4: and since he was a double amputee
column5: I thought wouldn’t that be a really interesting way at getting at his particular life?  In the midst of writing about Hood and his amputation and what that meant
column6: ultimately
column7: to his manhood and how it affected him in the postwar period
column8: I started getting these letters in the mail that I mention in the epilogue
column9: from these various veterans organizations
column10: that showed amputees from Iraq and Afghanistan who had acquired prosthetic limbs and were looking for a financial donation to help them buy some sort of craft kit.  It was usually around the holidays so they could assemble a model kit and then paint it to give them something to do with their functioning limb
column11: which I thought was really fascinating
column12: in terms of the way that these photographs were taken
column13: of these particular veterans
column14: that were sent with the mailing to acquire funds.  To me
column15: it became one of those things were the past of the Civil War and the present day crisis
column16: that I think a lot of men and women who are returning from war are facing now
column17: particularly with some issues with gaining the health care that they need quickly
column18: and just simply being recognized.  That they have extensive challenges both with issues of mobility as well as chronic pain they may be facing
column19: as well as just simple recognition for their military service.  So I think in many ways
column20: the present day conflict
column21: and the reverberations and aftermath of that conflict
column22: bled into this particular project to think about
column23: what does it actually mean in the Civil War era
column24: to return home missing an arm or a leg
column25: and how does Southern society
column26: that has just been defeated in war
column27: incorporate the damaged individual into the fold of society?  I think that sort of matches where the Civil War historiography is going right now.  I think the current trends of the issues veterans are facing in Iraq and Afghanistan are starting to appear in the Civil War era
column28: with the work done recently by Brian Matthew Jordan
column29: or James Martin
column30: or I think you will see work here shortly from Diane Miller Sommerville
column32: who are all talking about the challenges that veterans are facing
column33: and I think that will continue on in the near future.

column1: CWBR: A very interesting thing about this project is how it’s challenging in two different directions
column2: because there is
column3: as you mentioned
column4: there’s real parallels with the challenges veterans face today and certainly
column5: challenges that veterans from both sides of the Civil War faced
column6: but then there are a lot of particularities to what Southern veterans experienced.  I was wondering if you could explain why
column7: specifically
column8: you choose to look at Southern veterans?

column1: BCM: The reason for the Southern veteran
column2: if you will
column3: being the center of this project is because in some ways I thought it would be more challenging to do the Southern side of the story
column4: which certainly is not something that we traditionally see in Civil War scholarship.  A lot of times when volumes are produced on veterans
column5: in particular
column6: I would say that a vast majority of the source material and the stories within those books are mostly focused on Northern veterans
column7: and for good reason.  The paper trail is much greater
column8: the United States medical records are more extensive and easily accessible
column9: so I wanted to focus on the South and especially in its connection to manhood.  We think of how Southerners defined their manhood before the American Civil War
column10: with honor
column11: or this internalization that men actually had to go through to realize they were a man
column12: and how they outwardly showed that through how they physically appeared
column13: how they interacted with the public
column14: how they controlled their drinking or their horses and so forth.  And also their ability to master or control their wives
column15: their slaves
column16: their children
column17: and their own personal behaviors.  The Civil War in many ways alters a lot of those particular facets of defining manhood.  For example
column18: honor is shattered in many ways because Southern men are going off to war to fight to prove their manhood and they’re returning as military failures.  Their concept of mastery has been completely overturned because of emancipation and women taking a much more prominent role in literally running many Southern households while their men were away fighting the war itself.  So it seems that in some ways when men are returning home
column19: and society was once again looking to them as men
column20: it seems that the male physique
column21: which had been so important in the prewar era
column22: would in some ways naturally rise back to the top again.  However
column23: because now the male physique has been battered in many ways
column24: not just through amputation but because of physical scarring or emotional scarring that has made these men more dependent on their wives
column25: on their children
column26: on their society in general to care for them
column27: which certainly would have been a mark of feminization in the prewar period.  What I was struck with
column28: was I found some isolated cases of amputees in the South before the American Civil War
column29: in the 1840s and ‘50s
column30: many of them amputees from the Mexican-American War or from the Texas independence conflict
column31: and what I found is that Southern society didn’t necessarily embrace them.  Even though they would be considered military heroes
column32: they were still viewed in a negative light because their physical being
column33: if you will—their body—had been battered
column34: broken or damaged in some way
column35: which was seen as a marker of feminization
column36: or certainly not pristine manhood.  That sense seems to carry its way through the Civil War and into the postwar period
column37: creating what historian LeaAnn Whites calls
column39: a “crisis in manhood.”  I think it’s a crisis that was deeper and more profound than historians have been willing to acknowledge
column40: particularly because of this newfound dependent place in which Southern men find themselves
column43: coming back to a society that isn’t necessarily thrilled that their military prospects turned out so poorly.

column1: CWBR: It’s that return of damaged physiques that seems to offer the starkest contrast between Southern and Northern veterans. The Union guys can expect limb replacement programs from the government
column2: they have Federal pensions
column3: and of course they won
column4: so there’s this outpouring of public gratitude for having won.  For Confederate veterans there are already steeper obstacles because of the shattered economy in the South
column5: but then there are all these notions of Southern male honor
column6: the pall of defeat
column7: and these hinder the support that these guys can expect.  Since we’re already on that topic
column8: could you talk about the ways in which those notions of honor hindered the support that they could expect?

column2: it seems in particular that because these men would not get any Federal benefits at all
column3: that they would have to be reliant on benevolent societies
column4: local communities
column5: or state governments to step up and take action.  The benevolent societies were completely overwhelmed.  I think they had great intentions early on
column6: particularly the local groups that were gathering supplies or raising funds to buy prosthetic limbs
column7: but they simply could not handle hundreds of men who needed their assistance
column8: particularly when they were working based on donations.  The eye then focused on state governments
column9: where you only see seven Southern states start prosthetic limb programs—North Carolina
column10: Mississippi
column11: etc.
column12: some of these deeper South states—start a limb program
column13: starting with legs
column14: then eventually arms.  But the programs are mixed.  They take some time
column15: and require that the amputee themselves travel to usually the state capital or another other major city in that state to acquire the limb.  It would require some measurements and you’d have to wait for the limb to be constructed and then fitted.  Some men found them very useful
column16: others did not
column17: they found them painful.  States started to revise some of those programs by offering men a choice between a limb or a cash payment.  I discovered that as those programs advanced a few years
column18: that men wanted the cash payment. It was more important for them to have seventy-five or one hundred dollars up front rather than a prosthetic limb that may increase mobility or may hide the fact that they received a catastrophic injury during the war
column19: but it seems that their dire straits of poverty required them to take the cash payment.

column1: Those programs fizzled out and you started to see other programs like land grant programs. Louisiana and Texas particularly gave large tracts of land to amputees. In west Texas and more rural areas of Louisiana
column2: but those programs weren’t as successful as the state governments hoped them to be
column3: because many of these amputated men didn’t know what to do with such large parcels of land unless they had family members who could help them farm these plots of land.  So ultimately it comes down to the pension programs.  Because of Unionist governments
column4: because of Constitutional questions within state governments themselves
column5: you have legislators
column6: particularly in Texas
column7: wondering if they should actually
column8: if Confederate veterans should be seen as wards of the state
column9: if this dependency that they’re going to have on a government handout payment in the form of four times a year—is that appropriate
column10: is that an honorable endeavor to take place?  The governor of Florida actually questioned if this is a manly enterprise.  If Southern veterans were true men [the governor reasoned]
column11: then they shouldn’t have to rely on state governments in order to survive.  So the pension programs are very slow coming.  By the 1880s
column12: some of the states started to buy into these programs
column13: and they started to pop up from time to time all the way through Kentucky
column14: which was one of the last to start its program
column15: in the nineteen-teens
column16: which was almost fifty years after the conflict itself.  Many of these veterans have started fade away
column17: and haven’t even survived to the point where they could actually collect a pension.  That I think was most striking to me.  The Lost Cause
column18: in many ways
column19: has allowed us to think that these veterans returned home
column20: were completely embraced by Southern communities
column21: the women took care of them
column22: they lifted them up
column23: they constructed monuments in their honor
column24: they praised them
column25: and cared for them.  But the reality is that these men came home
column26: they had no financial prospects
column27: they ended up begging on the streets in some cases
column28: or trying to find odd work here and there
column29: but the doors were closed to them.  In fact
column30: one veteran famously noted the sign that appears when he looks for work everywhere
column31: “no maimed veteran need apply.” These men were not being recognized by society as men
column32: let alone men who could be productive in a postwar Southern economy.

column1: CWBR: Talking about how overwhelmed these benevolent societies were
column2: about how this question eventually had to go to the states and to politicians because there’s just no other institution that’s capable of supporting them.  In a general sense
column3: I’m curious about numbers
column4: and if there are numbers available
column5: for Southern veterans.  Looking at some of the tables in the book
column6: the number of amputees seems a little lower than one might expect
column7: especially once you divide them up among the states.  But at the same time
column8: this controversial subset of veterans becomes a symbol for veterans
column9: especially aged veterans
column10: writ large.  So I was wondering first about the numbers
column11: and second how they became such a powerful symbol.

column1: BCM: The numbers are a tricky prospect for anyone working on Southern medical history. A lot of the records for medical hospitals and medical care were not standardized until several months into the war itself
column2: so you didn’t have appropriate record keeping.  A lot of it was just doctors writing things down in ledger books
column3: which of course were scattered all over the South.  Then as the Confederate government starts to centralize these medical records
column4: and a lot of them were destroyed when the Confederate capital of Richmond was evacuated in 1865.  So we don’t have an exact count of how many Confederate amputees there were.  I think most medical historians have estimated it’s probably close to the Union figure
column5: which was around 29
column7: but it’s really difficult to pinpoint that exact number.  The pension files themselves may be useful in counting that number
column8: but in some states they’re still medically sealed
column9: because they contain medical information so historians are not actually able to go and look at that information.  This is actually applicable in the state of Texas
column10: for instance.  The medical portion of pension files in Texas is not available for historians because it contains sensitive medical details
column11: so again
column12: so that would maybe be one way of counting these amputees
column13: but we’re certainly not able to do so in a physical sense.  I can tell you that what medical there is does show that the number of amputees did decline during the course of the Civil War
column14: which I think may surprise many readers with general Civil War knowledge
column15: which sees this as a continued medical crisis throughout the war
column16: but it seems that by 1864
column17: Southern surgeons and hospitals have become very regulated
column18: with very strict cleanliness policies
column19: and doctors themselves had access by that time not just to practice but to medical journals and surgical manuals which had been updated.  These went step-by-step on when and when not you should amputate
column20: and it became so standardized in practice that surgeons
column21: particularly by the last year of the war
column22: were able to treat thousands of gunshot wounds
column23: but weren’t necessarily amputating at the same rate that they had done at Manassas or Shiloh
column24: in the early part of the war
column25: where you saw surgeons completely overwhelmed
column26: without extensive experience
column27: and they were cutting off limbs left and right.

column1: I think in some ways we can see the amputee
column2: particularly because he became such a prominent physical being in many Southern communities
column3: to be elevated to a different stature amongst other Southern veterans.  But it struck me again
column4: particularly with these benevolent groups
column5: that the amputees themselves aren’t always easily recognized in Southern society. You could have instances in some Southern communities where veterans and amputees begging on the streets were told that they were no longer allowed to do this.  They would be rounded up—particularly in the city New Orleans—and they would be rounded up and dumped into the Shakespeare Alms House.  So the city actually went back and revised that statute to say that actual Confederate veterans could remain begging on the streets
column6: but what happens is some men are able to acquire Confederate uniforms by buying them or stealing them
column7: and get through that loophole and beg for money as an amputee that would not have been caused by a war-related injury.

column1: I thought that the United Confederate Veterans

column4: but what I found was that not a lot of amputated men were joining this organization
column5: let alone being recognized by the organization.  The UCV does have in their mantra that benevolence is part of who they are
column6: and they want donations to be solicited so they can help take care of aging veterans and infirm veterans
column7: particularly in veterans’ homes across the South
column8: but once state governments started to get involved and take over those veterans’ homes
column9: it seems a lot of the financial resources the UCV would have put into taking care of veterans now goes to other endeavors
column10: particularly textbook writing.  The UCV becomes very
column11: very concentrated on making sure that the narrative of the war is written from a Southern point of view
column12: and that Southern point-of-view textbooks are being used in classrooms across the South
column13: rather than in lifting up and caring for these amputated men.  Maybe it’s because amputated veterans aren’t interested in joining a veterans’ organization

They certainly had not experienced any sort of major medical surgery in their life or been into a location where that had taken place

The Rebel Yell: A Cultural History Warren
column2: Craig A.			"<h3>Interview with Craig A. Warren
column3: Associate Professor of English and Prodessional Writing at Penn State Erie
column4: The Behrend College

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is happy to speak with Craig A. Warren
column2: Associate Professor of English and Professional Writing at Penn State Erie
column3: the Behrend College. Professor Warren previously authored Scars to Prove It: The Civil War Soldier and American Fiction
column4: and today we get to discuss his most recent book
column5: The Rebel Yell: A Cultural History. Professor Warren
column6: thank you for joining us today.

column1: Craig A. Warren: Thanks for having me
column2: I appreciate it.

column1: CWBR: We always start out by asking because it's always an interesting question
column2: especially in this case with this subject that hasn't been in historiography for quite some time
column3: what was it that drew you to this project?

column1: Warren: I became really interested in the rebel yell in the summer of 2008. At that time my first book had just gone to press. To a large extent that book is about the memoirs of Civil War veterans and southern women on the home front. I came away from that project tremendously impressed by the ability of everyday Americans to put on the page some of the abstractions of war. Things such as freedom
column2: democracy
column3: and human dignity. I also became aware of where these writers struggled to represent certain phenomena in print and to communicate it to the reader. One of those areas
column4: interestingly enough
column5: was the legendary battle cry of Confederate soldiers
column6: the rebel yell
column7: and I saw writers struggling to represent it on the page. Some were trying to spell it out with vowels
column8: consonants
column9: and exclamation marks etc. That didn't satisfactorily convey this ferocious battle cry to the reader. Others adopted different strategies by using metaphor
column10: saying the rebel yell sounded like the squealing brakes of a runaway train
column11: or it sounded like the howling of wolves
column12: and even a hurricane. This was not satisfying either since these three things don't necessarily sound alike. Also a frame of reference we are familiar with doesn't seem to connect with a Civil War battlefield. Then some just gave up altogether
column13: which my favorite was the Union veteran and writer Ambrose Bierce who simply said the rebel yell was
column14: “the ugliest sound that any mortal have ever heard.” I saw these different attempts to describe the rebel yell
column15: all of which failed to a large extent. As a literary critic I was interested in the limitations of language to describe a sonic phenomenon
column16: but as a cultural historian I quickly became interested in the rebel yell for other reasons as well. The more I looked into it the more I realized it had this really rich and vibrant career after the Civil War
column17: all through Reconstruction and the Gilded Age and the early twentieth century. I think that's a history that most people still today are completely unaware of. That really got me interested to dig and understand the yell better
column18: and to understand its evolving meaning and purposes for subsequent generations of Americans.

column1: CWBR: I do want to come back to the sonic aspect and the limitations of the language
column2: but before we get into all the details maybe it would be helpful to have a quick overview of the career the yell had that you mentioned. You found that it started from unclear but probably varied origins
column3: to become what we are familiar with historically as a particular battle cry
column4: but it changes a lot even after that.

column1: Warren: That's right. As with any human language or expression the rebel has
column2: as you say
column3: murky origins. Everything evolves from a complicated matrix and linguists do their best to patch together where human languages come from and how they evolve and change. It seems that the Antebellum South was absolutely awash with different kinds of high pitched yelling. Some was related to animal husbandry calling to animals
column4: shepherding animals. Some had to do with rural life
column5: communicating with neighbors and family members over long distances. There were also hunting cries used by every class strata in the Antebellum South. Then there were Native American war cries which could be heard through the 1830's and in some frontier communities in the south. Over a period of time it seems that all these different sounds and styles of noisemaking change how southern communities
column6: in a broad sense
column7: approached standard cheering. Unlike in northern populations and communities where cheering typically took the form of noisemaking in unison in a standard way like 'Hoorah
column8: hoorah
column9: ' it seemed that in the South
column10: both in town and in rural communities
column11: cheering took the sound of free-form screeching
column12: overlapping noises usually at a high pitch
column13: lacking words or word sounds. When the Civil War began
column14: it seems to me that this style of cheering just came naturally to most folks in the South
column15: and was translated from a civilian life to the battlefield
column16: the camp
column17: and the march. It's sort of a mistake to think the rebel yell was exclusively a phenomenon to the battlefield. Southern troops used it in lots of different ways and in different contexts. In any case it became a battle cry and as you were saying after the war
column18: it did change. For a long time was seen as a
column19: I would say
column20: kind of defiant statement of white southerners that they were still here and living through Federal occupation
column21: but they were not foregoing their traditions. It was used in some cases of racial violence against freedmen. It was used in scenes of insurrection. The Crescent City White League
column22: a white paramilitary organization was using the rebel yell while battling troops in blue in New Orleans. It was used in political contexts whenever different political parties would get their candidates together. The rebel yell was often sounded by old Confederate veterans now in support of new political measures. This goes on through the Spanish American War
column23: and I don't know how much you want me to get into its career as a battle cry in 1898
column24: but it's a major sociopolitical barometer of intersectional hostility in some cases
column25: but also reconciliation as well. It's not until the twentieth century that we see the rebel yell eclipsed by the Confederate battle flag as a major symbol of white southern identity.

column2: going back to the origins of the yell
column3: was this odd obsession
column4: given how familiar most southerners would have been with all the different possibilities for its origins—whether it be Indian battle cries or hunting calls
column5: anything like that—with figuring out a single source
column6: and I was curious about that.

column2: I think its human nature. We like to be detectives to try and find out the one single place where a particular expression began or where particular human behavior started. Really I think that's fool’s gold
column3: there’s not going to be
column4: when it comes to human language
column5: one single beginning for virtually anything. I think that what happened with that obsession during the decades following the Civil War
column6: with the origin of rebel yell
column7: was that a lot of people began to understand the rebel yell existed somehow as the voice of the South.  That's how it was often characterized. That being the case
column8: anyone who had a particular political or cultural agenda and wanted to represent true southern identity as belonging to a particular region
column9: people
column10: class
column11: or political party would adopt the rebel yell as their own and try to make the case for its origins falling in line with their personal interests. For instance
column12: if you wanted represent the South as this romantic
column13: agrarian
column14: cavalier society then you make the argument that
column15: “oh the rebel yell derived from the fox-hunting cries of plantation owners.” If you instead want to make the case of true southern identity is in that blue collar work ethic of yeoman farmers then you say
column16: “well the rebel yell derives from rabbit hunting calls that these farmers would voice after tending their fields during the daytime.” If you want to represent the South as a multi-racial society then you say
column17: “oh it derives from Native American battle cries” or you suggest even that the rebel yell—ironically enough—began with slave songs and celebrations and those were passed on to their white masters. I guess what I'm getting at is the rebel yell becomes a political or cultural chess piece. People interested in trying to define the South in a particular way are going to interoperate its origins accordingly.

column1: CWBR: In defining its origins it also
column2: it was interesting to me
column3: generates quite a bit more commentary than I had read anywhere else on how it was that northern soldiers supposedly cheered as well.

column1: Warren: That became something that for us today is kind of amusing
column2: to see northern and southern veterans crossing pens after the war describing the difference between northern battle cries and southern. Northern troops seem to yell in a European and British style which is a low register
column3: in unison
column4: give a 'hoorah
column5: hoorah.' They said this is the manly
column6: deep-breasted cheer of the northern soldier. They all did it in unison and that sits very well with the concept of Union and togetherness. The southern veterans though
column7: thought that was all clockwork and mechanical. They thought that kind of cheering was appropriate for northern factory workers who never saw sunlight and never got outside or had any individualism at all. They prized the rebel yell and said
column8: here’s a battle cry which each individual contributed his own preferred pitch and sequence of sounds to the collective whole
column9: and it's not a kind of cheering by rows
column10: but instead free-form screeching
column11: and all that overlapping sound creates a unified cacophony. The different sides found ways to talk about their style and mood of cheering as a way to describe their political approach to conflict and democracy. Are we representing a united front or are we each doing our own thing together? I think that's really interesting symbolically. There’s a lot to be said about how the rebel yell was different from the style of cheering in other sections of the U.S. and in Europe at the time. I think it does speak to the fact that the American South
column12: although it had lots of shared characteristics and origins with the North
column13: did have different cultural attitudes and origins owing to its region and to its people
column14: which white southerners were encountering in the generation leading up to this whole war.

column1: CWBR: It is interesting to me that these northern veterans and southern veterans
column2: as they’re sort of sparring in various written pieces
column3: are more or less in agreement on what makes a northern yell different from a southern yell
column4: it's just they disagree on whether this is a good or bad thing
column5: in their characteristics. Yet both interpretations lend themselves pretty readily to the growing Lost Cause ideology of the South being overcome by this tremendously more numerous
column6: more industrial force
column7: and really the ideology goes out of the equation.

column2: I think that what happens over time is that as the two sections move towards reconciliation there becomes this need for mutual respect. Northern veterans instead of saying
column3: “oh this high pitched rebel yell was effeminate
column4: or it was wild and incoherent
column5: and it represents everything that was wrong with secession
column6: ” began instead to praise the rebel yell as a unique American voice
column7: voiced by a worthy opponent who
column8: “though defeated in battle
column9: nonetheless had lots of virtues in term of honor and dedication and commitment to cause.” If it does get discussion
column10: the rebel yell gets incorporated into this drive towards reconciliation
column11: which was not shared by everyone by any means
column12: but in large contours there’s this movement towards reconciliation. It gets to the point where after a while
column13: you begin to see the rebel yell embraced by people in the north and northern readers and newspapers are writing to southerners asking if they can describe the rebel yell in print or help them to better understand it. It becomes almost a kind of shared American achievement and I noted earlier that it took part in the Spanish-American War. By 1898
column14: I would suggest the rebel yell became the de facto battle cry of the U.S. military. It was used on San Juan Hill and then the Philippines and elsewhere
column15: taught to Northern troops and even African American troops by Southerners. After the war former Northern officers coming back to Washington D.C. in 1898 were serenaded by the rebel yell at the nation’s capital
column16: which must have been really disorienting for them considering their previous experience with it
column17: but it had become a national battle cry. I think you are right to say that it is an evolving experience and its meaning for the nation
column18: and not just for the South
column19: changes over time.

column1: CWBR: That Spanish-American war moment was particularly striking
column2: because it really does look for a moment that the rebel yell is going to become a newly fully incorporated American military tradition and it's going to be that shared American achievement you mentioned. All signs point to increased popularity
column3: then what? Two or three years later it retreats
column4: what happened?

column1: Warren: I think there was no longer the urgency on the part of white Southerners to prove their loyalty to the larger United States. That is what a lot of rhetoric was about during the Spanish-American War. People are saying
column2: “oh look how the South is now sending its officers and men to support the United States and now they're wearing the blue uniforms as well and so forth.” After the Spanish-American War I think that Southern loyalty has been proven
column3: so there's not this urgency in the part of the South to share the rebel yell with the North
column4: so I think that's one of the reasons why there’s this retreat of its use. I also think that by the turn of the century
column5: and I say this in the book
column6: the rebel yell is no longer a military phenomenon. By then it’s been used and practiced by subsequent generations of civilians
column7: people whose fathers and grandfathers had been Civil War soldiers and had taught that to them. We start seeing it also used in political spheres
column8: the term rebel yell becomes an expression that's used to denote certain political perspectives. It's just not strictly a military phenomenon anymore and I talk about its growing demilitarization after 1898. So for me the Spanish-American War represents its zenith as a shared national battle cry and after the rebel yell
column9: both screeching and name brand of the rebel yell
column10: moves increasingly to the civilian sector.

column1: CWBR: Was it the civilian sector then that was most responsible for the fact that
column2: as we get past the Spanish-American War
column3: you start to describe these multiple personalities for the rebel yell
column4: so that there's still a Southern defiant yell that especially comes out in as a result of the Civil Rights movement
column5: but then there’s also what you called a “cartoon yell?”

column2: you know it's true. Once it's no longer seen as this terrifying ferocious battle cry
column3: as it was described immediately after the war (veterans were writing about it in those terms)
column4: people begin to see it as an expression of life and vitality. People talk about the rebel yell as what Walt Whitman would call a “barbaric yawp
column5: ” declaring oneself’s place in the universe. It becomes something that screamed out at sporting events and race tracks. It becomes a fun-loving expression. Certainly during the Civil Rights movement the mid-twentieth century
column6: segregationists started using the rebel yell in a throwback way as during the Civil War itself
column7: but at the same time there's what I call the cartoon rebel yell was firmly placed as the sort of teenage hijinks yell
column8: screeching out while driving 90 miles per hour down a country lane. It has multiple personas all at once
column9: which is one of the reasons why I thought it was such an interesting phenomenon.

column1: CWBR: We also cannot talk about its change without discussing the context of what might be replacing it. So especially when we are getting into the Civil Rights era
column2: and the visual aspect is so important there
column3: you write that that’s true as well for how the yell is regarded
column4: right?

column2: we have to remember
column3: emerged from the nineteenth century. It's invisible
column4: intangible
column5: just really much more at home in a culture that was oriented toward sound. There are critics that have done a great job about talking about how sound was so important to nineteenth century America. That's one reason why today we have a hard time understanding why people would go and listen to three-hour-long oratory
column6: but that was something that was part of their culture
column7: perhaps especially in the South. As we get in the twentieth century
column8: especially after World War II
column9: we are now in a culture of images
column10: with the advent of televisions and motion pictures. Increasingly people are looking for visual symbols culturally and politically. What happens
column11: to my mind
column12: is that the rebel yell is no longer as much at home in that kind of society. So the use of the yell as the dominant symbol of white southern identity is eclipsed by that Confederate battle flag
column13: which had largely gone dormant from about 1865 to 1948 or so
column14: when the Dixiecrats adopted it and it started beginning to be used for other purposes. John Coski's excellent book The Confederate Battle Flag charts this evolution about how the battle flag was largely used just in ceremonial ways through Reconstruction in the Gilded Age
column15: but really came into its own as a controversial and important symbol around 1950. That was helpful for me because I began to see how in his description of the career of the battle flag
column16: how it was following many of the same contours we had seen the career of the rebel yell established. I began to ask what the difference here is. Well one major difference is that the flag is visible and it’s more dignified to be suited for a governor's office or for a state capital than the rebel yell
column17: which is more of a ragged
column18: raw expression of self. The rebel yell is better suited for a street fight than for a governor's office. I think that's one reason why we see the battle flag eclipsing the yell as a major symbol right around 1948-50.

column1: CWBR: It's not too long after that
column2: that it seems to me like the yell experiences an effort to re-imbue it with a bit of the original ferocity and gravitas that it originally had. You mentioned there’s another personality
column3: the “lost yell.”

column2: it wasn't that there was a clear passing from the yell towards the flag. There was an overlap for a while
column3: the same places the segregationists are waving the Confederate battle flag such as from University of Mississippi in 1962 when James Meredith was enrolling. At the same time that those flags are being waved
column4: protestors were also shouting the rebel yell. There is this throwback
column5: but at the same time there is this new movement to which I refer to as the concept of the “myth of the lost yell
column6: ” which suggests that the rebel yell has been lost to history. That began with a handful of Confederate veterans at the end of the nineteenth century who didn't like how the rebel yell was being used by civilians. They thought it was being treated irreverently
column7: and used as a party trick.   They wanted it to be treated as a dignified anthem for a particular time and place
column8: the Confederacy of 1861-65. They wanted to cordon it off from its irreverent use and said
column9: “Oh it's been lost forever and you can never hear it after Appomattox.” Lots of other veterans
column10: though
column11: were demonstrating the rebel yell quite willingly at banquets. The argument about the lost yell never got a lot of traction until most veterans passed away. Then people like Shelby Foote
column12: who had a particular cultural agenda
column13: began pushing again the concept of the lost yell. Over time people began to embrace the idea that “we may have a facsimile of the rebel yell today but we really don’t know exactly how it sounded but the true rebel yell has been lost
column14: ” so you see this movement as well. I think what Shelby Foote and others were trying to do was to distance the rebel yell from what they would see as its abuses in the mid-twentieth century. They didn't like the KKK using the Confederate battle flag during the Civil Rights Movement
column15: or the segregations using the rebel yell
column16: which made them think that it was spoiling what these nineteenth century artifacts had been used for initially
column17: and they should not dishonor them in that way. They suggested that these things are actually dead and gone forever. They said that the rebel yell
column18: like Southern oratory had been lost. I suggest in my book that it’s a myth and that there's never been a time since 1865 when we haven't had Confederate veterans willingly give up the rebel yell
column19: or that we haven't had any recordings
column20: audio and visual
column21: of Confederate veterans giving the rebel yell. The idea that it was lost to history is really part of a particular agenda
column22: but it's not a reality.

column1: CWBR: Well the recordings that you mention became this really fascinating part of the book where you did quite a bit of sleuthing to dig a little bit into various efforts that have now been made with the miracle of digital technology and what not
column2: to have now a “found yell.”
I think when Shelby Foote went on Dick Cavett in the 1970's and talked with Ken Burns in that famous PBS documentary The Civil War in 1990
column3: we didn't have the World Wide Web yet
column4: on which we could share recordings with the entire world
column5: so it was easier than to make the case that the rebel yell has been lost and we don’t have any recordings of it. Now that kind of thing can be shared. There was an effort on the part of the Museum of the Confederacy a few years back to try and uncover what they were putting forward as the true yell. They were following the tradition that there had only been one way to give a rebel yell
column6: that everyone who gave the yell did it in the exact same way. There's no historical record to back that up
column7: but they latched on to that idea. They found a recording the United Daughters of the Confederacy had and then another one across the country thinking they were two separate recordings that lined up and uncovered the true yell. What I do is go through a lot of UDC catalogs and find different radio stations who played recordings of the yell over the last several decades and try to show that actually the Museum of Confederacy found the same recording twice. It wasn't a one true yell that was offered by different guys and units
column8: but actually the same recording. I hope that what I have done in looking at that and trying to figure out exactly what's been recorded and when or who by
column9: is that there was no true way of giving the rebel yell. Every soldier has his own preferred way of doing it
column10: and I would suggest every soldier gave a slightly different rebel yell from one occasion to the next. So the found yell was really that realization
column11: that there was no one way to do it and the fact that we now have the World Wide Web and technology is better to share those kinds of things. We can look at what the Library of Congress has
column12: to look at their audio and visual recordings of Confederate veterans giving an individual yell or collective yells. This is available now at the Smithsonian website actually. I like to think now we can get past a lot of the myths that have grown around the rebel yell and better understand its real evolution for what it means for our country.

column1: CWBR: So what do you see as the importance of the historical debate over the yell as its going on into the twenty-first century
column2: trading its particular historical meaning in our culture for symbolizing a more general rebelliousness?

column1: Warren: One think I learned from this process is that often times passes for history is really an attempt by various commentators to shape the thinking of generations of Americans about American history or Southern history in this case. Really the job of the scholar is to look at different interpretations of the past or cultural artifacts and try to approach it in that sort of neutral objective way
column2: and see how these markers have been used to front a particular agenda
column3: and to understand how American culture develops overtime in accordance with these perspectives that are maybe politically motivated or culturally or socially motivated. In terms of what I've learned about the yell’s shift from one particular use on a battlefield for instance for being used for commercial purposes and everything else
column4: it's that a cultural icon really cannot be contained. Shelby Foote and others might want us to say that this artifact is lost forever and lost to history
column5: but cultural artifacts are not lost. They evolve over time
column6: they change over time. You see this when Billy Idol can use the rebel yell—this British rocker having it on a song or an album—or whenever the rebel yell is used now as a name for a clothing line or bourbon. You see how these things can be commercialized
column7: how symbols can change and be adopted for new purposes and new agendas. I think that's the truth in how we approach symbols as people
column8: and to understand that about our images and symbols is important
column9: because it makes us more aware of who we are and how we choose to represent ourselves to the world.

column2: I won't ask you to offer your own rendition of the yell
column3: but I thank you for taking a moment to sit down with us today and discuss your new book The Rebel Yell: A Cultural History.

column1: Warren: Thank you very much for having me
column2:
it was a pleasure.

" Isenhower
column3: Zach Spring 2015 2015-05-01 Interview University of Alabama Press ""

column1:
4970 978-0-393-06618-0 $29.95 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
The Fiery Trial: Abraham Lincoln and American Slavery Foner
column2: Eric			"<h3>Interview with Dr. Eric Foner
column3: Dewitt Clinton Processor of History at Columbia University

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview

column2: I’m joined by Eric Foner who is DeWitt Clinton Professor of History at Columbia University to discuss his Pulitzer Prize-winning The Fiery Trial: Abraham Lincoln and American Slavery. Professor Foner
column3: congratulations on your award and thank you for joining me.

column1: Eric Foner (EF): Thank you very much; I'm happy to talk to you
CWBR: What inspired you to take this approach to looking at Abraham Lincoln?

column2: as you know
column3: there are enumerable books about Lincoln out there already
column4: many of them are
column5: of course excellent books.  I feel that in recent years
column6: with some important exceptions
column7: there's been a tendency in some of the literature to sort of focus so specifically on Lincoln that the wider world slips from view sometimes
column8: that
column9: in a sense
column10: my feeling is Lincoln needed to be put back in political context
column11: particularly in this one area: that my book is about Lincoln and slavery; it's not a total biography.  It's about Lincoln and the evolution of his ideas about slavery
column12: policies about slavery
column13: and I did feel that there was still something to be said tracing out how Lincoln’s attitudes and views changed over the course of his life: how he related to other people in the whole broad anti-slavery firmament.  So
column14: I guess
column15: I felt there was room even though there is such a large body of literature already about slavery
column16: about Lincoln

column1: CWBR: You mention placing him in that overall world and I wonder: is seems like you suggest that we can often see certain aspects of Lincoln in ourselves. Does examining the personal growth during his life
column2: in terms of how he looked at government
column3: slavery
column4: and society
column5: make him more approachable?  Does it remove some of the mystique
column6: making him more human?

column2: I hope so.  I mean Lincoln was a man of greatness; he grew into greatness.  I don't think he was a great figure for all of his life and I think we can learn something from how Lincoln related to broad social movements of his time: abolitionism
column3: other forms of critique of slavery
column4: which he was not really part of
column5: but he was willing to learn from them
column6: and I think just the notion of a statesman who is open to new ideas
column7: who is intellectually curious
column8: who is willing to change-of course
column9: in the greatest crisis in our nation’s history- is something we can learn from: that people should not be totally set in their ways
column10: totally inflexible.  Today
column11: if a politician changes his view about something he is immediately denounced as a flip-flopper
column12: right?  Lincoln was a flip-flopper; he changed enormously
column13: in some regards: in terms of policy about slavery
column14: attitudes about race.  Another way of putting it is he learned
column15: he grew
column16: he understood that new ideas were valuable.  So the notion today seems to be that anyone who learns anything
column17: that's to be criticized and condemned because they're not holding exactly the same positions throughout their whole life.

column1: CWBR: How important was an ideological base in Revolutionary politics and the ideology of the Founding Fathers to Lincoln’s political foundation?

column2: of course
column3: greatly admired the founding fathers as most people of his generation did.  In that famous Lyceum speech when he was still a young man in the late 1830s
column4: he sort of said
column5: well what have the Founding Fathers left for us to do
column6: so to speak?  They created this
column7: what he considered the last
column8: best hope of man
column9: this democratic system of government
column10: and
column11: in a sense
column12: they had usurped what subsequent generations might do to achieve notoriety and greatness.  But
column13: of course
column14: Lincoln felt that-he believed-(this is open to some criticism) but he believed that the founders had set the country on a course toward the eventual abolition of slavery and he felt that their policies were being overturned particularly in the 1850s by Stephen A. Douglas and those pressing for the expansion of slavery.  And so
column15: on the one hand
column16: Lincoln claims to be
column17: in a sense
column18: a conservative; he's going back to the original purposes of the revolution.  But
column19: in doing so
column20: you're radically altering the system that has existed since that time.  He said that the nation cannot exist forever half slave and half free.  Well
column21: it had existed half slave and half free for well over 50 years. So on the one hand he says he's going back to the views of the founders; on the other hand he's really trying to change the fundamental nature of American society because of his anti-slavery commitments.

column2: then
column3: in the overall society
column4: did Lincoln’s unique upbringing in Kentucky and Illinois
column5: on the edge of slaveholding society
column6: give him a distinctive perspective into intersectional politics and dealing with the South during secession and war?

column2: of course
column3: Lincoln
column4: as you well know
column5: was born in Kentucky
column6: a slave state.  He grew up in southern Indiana and then southern and central Illinois
column7: areas settled mostly
column8: at that time
column9: by people from the South.  He married into a Kentucky family
column10: so he obviously had very close personal connections with the South and
column11: in some ways
column12: with slave society.  And I think that that gave him a sense of…he didn't denounce southerners.  He didn't denounce slave owners the way some abolitionists did; he never said that they are sinners
column13: that kind of thing.  In fact
column14: he said in one of his speeches that if we were in their position we would be pretty much doing the same things they are.  But I think that during the war one of his problems may have been
column15: at least in the secession crisis
column16: that he overestimated the degree of support for the Union in the South.  He sort of felt that secessionism was a minority movement
column17: was almost like a conspiracy of a small group.  And he believed that there was this strong latent Unionism in the South that would eventually rear its head and end secession.  That
column18: of course
column19: did not turn out to be the case so maybe
column20: in that sense
column21: on the one hand
column22: his personal connections with southerners made him less likely to engage in a kind of vitriolic denunciation; on the other hand it may have led him to overestimate the degree of Unionism.  After all Kentucky was not your typical slave state: Kentucky remained in the Union
column23: it was divided his wife's family
column24: his father-in-law
column25: who died in 1849 I think
column26: was strongly pro-Union.  Henry Clay
column27: the great Kentucky statesman who Lincoln admired so much
column28: was pro-Union and Lincoln may have somewhat extended those views to the rest of the South in a way that didn't turn out to be totally accurate.

column2: was there an honest opportunity for compromise in your opinion?
it's interesting
column3: Lincoln admired Cay enormously but Clay made his reputation
column4: of course
column5: as the Great Compromiser.  Lincoln
column6: in the secession crisis
column7: refused to compromise.  He said he is perfectly willing to compromise on peripheral issues
column8: but not on the core question which was the westward expansion of slavery.  On that
column9: he said I am not compromising so Lincoln was willing to risk war even in the face in the secession crisis.  So I think Lincoln was able (and this is another lesson for statesmen) to clearly differentiate
column10: in his own mind
column11: between core principles
column12: which he wouldn't compromise
column13: and other issues which he was willing to compromise.  So
column14: if Lincoln’s only aim
column15: as some people seem to think was to preserve the Union
column16: he could have easily preserved the Union by just giving in to the South
column17: no problem.  Give the South what they want
column18: let them expand slavery
column19: and then the Union is saved.  What's the problem here?  But Lincoln said no; it must be a Union worth saving
column20: a Union in which slavery is confined and put in
column21: what he calls
column22: the course toward ultimate extinction. And that's your fundamental problem there; if you don't compromise on that you're not going to settle the secession crisis.

column1: CWBR: How does one reconcile the fact that many white southerners mark Lincoln’s election as a blow to slavery with the fact that many abolitionists like Garrison worry that Lincoln is not radical enough? What does that tell us about the complicated task that Lincoln faced?
EF: Lincoln was not an abolitionist; he didn't claim to be an abolitionist. Abolitionists were often very critical of Lincoln. On the other hand
column2: people like Garrison
column3: Wendell Phillips
column4: and Frederick Douglas hailed Lincoln’s election as a step in the right direction.  They said no
column5: this is not going to end slavery just like that
column6: but it's definitely a step in the right direction.  Simon P. Chase
column7: who was an abolitionist although a republican politician
column8: says this is the culmination of my life’s work-Lincoln’s election-the slave power
column9: southern slave owners
column10: have been expelled from control of the federal government.  So
column11: even though abolitionist felt Lincoln was not nearly as radical as they wanted
column12: southerners (white southerners
column13: secessionists) feared that Lincoln’s election marked a fundamental shift in power in the country.  They didn't think that Lincoln was going to sign an emancipation proclamation as soon as he came to office; he had no legal grounds for doing that
column14: and he made it clear he wasn't going to do it.  But
column15: in the longer run
column16: this seemed to be to them a sign of the northern states now acquiring control of the national government and they felt slavery would not be safe ultimately under the rule of people who were hostile to slavery.  So that's why they seceded.  Read the South Carolina Declaration of the Causes of Secession
column17: they don't beat around the bush; that's what they say: slavery is no longer safe with the election of Lincoln.

column1: CWBR: What role did the Union military play in forcing Lincoln to define or clarify his policy on slavery and what role did the slaves themselves play in that?
EF: At the outset of the war
column2: of course
column3: Lincoln says that this is not a war about slavery; it's a war about preserving the Union.  Four slave states
column4: the Border States
column5: remain in the Union; Lincoln was very concerned about maintaining their loyalty.  But very quickly the government has to take cognizance of slavery.  The first thing is slaves run away.  Wherever the Union Army goes
column6: slaves start running toward Union lines and the army has got a dilemma.  At the beginning they start returning these slaves but many soldiers don't want to do that.  They're not in the army to be fugitive slave hunters and
column7: moreover
column8: many of those slaves have been used as laborers for the Confederate Army and why send them back to build fortifications against your own forces?  So this forces the Lincoln administration to start making policy about slavery and in 1861 they do it in a modest sort of way.  By 1862
column9: in the spring when they capture the southern part of Louisiana
column10: they're in control of an area with many
column11: many thousands of slaves and so the slaves put the issue on the agenda so to speak by their own actions.  And then the army has to deal with it.  The army says: well what are we supposed to do?  We can't just start capturing slaves and sending them back; it is distasteful
column12: it's counterproductive.  Sometimes slaves have very valuable information about the disposition of Confederate forces or the local terrain or things like that which they bring to Union commanders and they say: well we just can't send this guy back into slavery now that he's been helpful to us.  So that's a couple of
column13: among many
column14: of pressures that are pushing Lincoln toward a new policy on slavery.

column1: CWBR: How did the Emancipation Proclamation alter the course of the war and might the Proclamation be indicative of a general shift toward total war?
EF: Well I think the Proclamation does fundamentally change the nature of the war because it makes slavery officially a target of the Union war effort. Henceforth
column2: after January 1
column4: wherever the Union Army goes
column5: one of its responsibilities
column6: as Lincoln says in that document
column7: is to protect and maintain the freedom of about 3.2 million (more or less) slaves who were declared free under the terms of the Emancipation Proclamation.  So it guarantees that
column8: if the Union wins the war (which
column9: of course
column10: is an “if;” it's not guaranteed) then slavery will end
column11: no question about it.  Even though it doesn't apply to Kentucky
column12: it doesn't apply to Maryland
column13: if slavery dies in South Carolina
column14: Mississippi
column15: and Alabama
column16: it's not going to be able to survive all that long in Missouri and Delaware.  So it really does change the nature of the war and
column17: indeed
column18: of American society.  It means that now the issue on the agenda is going to be: what is going to be the status of these millions of slaves who are now being declared free people?  What's going to happen to them in American society?  Are they going to enjoy the same rights as white people?  Are they going to be in the same labor system?  So it opens up a lot of important questions
column19: even though it sort of points toward solving the question of slavery
column20: per se and so I think it does very much change the nature of the war.  And also of course the Proclamation
column21: for the first time
column22: officially announces that black soldiers (black men) will be allowed to enlist in the Union Army and I think the service of the 200
column23: 000 black soldiers and sailors by the end of the war does have a very big effect on racial attitudes.  Even Lincoln
column24: himself
column25: comes to feel that these people who fought for the Union have stake to claim for citizenship in the post-war world.

column1: CWBR: What effect did Lincoln’s increasing use of emancipation as a war aim
column2: as the war progressed
column3: have on public support leading up to the 1864 election?  Without Sherman’s victory at Atlanta
column4: was a loss to McClellan possible?

column1: EF: Well certainly in August of 1864 Lincoln believed he was going to lose; many Republicans thought Lincoln was going to lose the election. There was a great deal of war weariness in the North; casualties in 1864 were enormous compared to the rest of the war. Even though there had been Union victories
column2: important ones previously
column3: (Gettysburg and Vicksburg) still it seemed to be a sort of stalemate in the East and there was a lot of fear that war weariness would lead to the election of General McClellan
column4: the Democrat.  In August 1864 Henry Raymond
column5: the editor of the New York Times
column6: and some other Republicans came to Lincoln and said: people think the Emancipation Proclamation is prolonging the war because they'll never come back unless they can keep their slaves.  Why don't you say that we'll accept the South back with their slaves if they just give up the war?  Rescind the Emancipation Proclamation
column7: basically
column8: that will
column9: at least boost
column10: your chances of re-election because
column11: if they say no
column12: it will prove that the Proclamation is not the reason the war is continuing.  And Lincoln seems to have thought about it a bit over night but then he said: I can't really do that.  First of all
column13: it would just be wrong to promise people freedom and then rescind the promise.  Second of all
column14: we need those black soldiers; if we do this the black soldiers will lay down their arms and without them we can't win the war.  So he was wedded to emancipation by then
column15: even at the possible price of losing the election.  Then
column16: as you said
column17: Sherman’s capture of Atlanta seems to have turned the tide in terms of public sentiment and he is elected eventually by a very large margin.  But basically once the Proclamation is issued
column18: Lincoln is not going to go back on it and
column19: even though some radicals thought he was too slow in issuing it
column20: once it's issued
column21: this is it. This is now the policy of the Union and he is not going to change.

column1: CWBR: What was Lincoln’s vision for American society in the post-war period and how did his vision evolve or change from his antebellum ideas of an American society with or without slavery?

EF: We know very little about what was Lincoln thinking about the post-war world; obviously he was assassinated April 1865 when Reconstruction is really just beginning. There were various plans of Reconstruction put forward during the Civil War but these were plans for winning the war
column2: not a blueprint for the post-war South.  And certainly
column3: in his final speech
column4: just before his death he talked about maybe limited black suffrage in the South
column5: which is something he had never publicly spoken of before so I think his ideas were changing and evolving.   I don't think Lincoln had a blueprint at all.  I think he wanted a relatively quick reunion of the country; he was not vindictive toward white southerners.  On the other hand
column6: I think he recognized
column7: by this point
column8: that the former slaves had a claim on the conscience of the nation and you couldn't just abandon them and let them be put back into some kind of system akin to slavery again.  How to work that out
column9: how to bring the white South in and yet protect the rights of the black South was a gigantic dilemma which Congress will be wrestling with for several years after this.  Of course
column10: the problem was that
column11: once Lincoln is assassinated
column12: you get probably the worst president in American history
column13: Andrew Johnson
column14: replacing him who is totally incapable of confronting this question at all in any serious way and that complicates the situation very dramatically.

column2: I would like to thank you
column3: once again
column4: for taking the time today to discuss with us The Fiery Trial: Abraham Lincoln and American Slavery.

column1: EF: Well I'm very happy to talk to you
column2:
absolutely.

" Buman
column3: Nathan Fall 2011 2011-11-01 Interview W. W. Norton & Company ""

column1:
4900 978-0-674-04562-0 $27.95 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
The Union War Gallagher
column2: Gary			"<h3>Interview with Dr. Gary Gallagher
column3: John L. Nau III Professor of History at the University of Virginia

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview

column2: I’m delighted to be joined by Gary Gallagher who is John L. Nau III Professor of History at the University of Virginia to discuss his most recent book The Union War. Professor Gallagher
column3: thank you for talking with us today.

column1: CWBR: You mention in the acknowledgements that you came up with the idea for this book ten years ago; how did you decide to approach this question and look at a study of the Civil War through the concept of Union?
GG: I began talking about the book ten years ago with Joyce Seltzer
column2: who is the editor I worked with at Harvard on an earlier book
column3: The Confederate War. But I’ve really been thinking about this for much longer than that. I’ve been thinking about it because I’ve found over the years perhaps the most difficult thing to explain to students
column4: or groups of adults to whom I speak about the war
column5: is why the loyal citizenry thought Union was worth fighting for.  It’s a very hard concept for many modern Americans to come to terms with: why would someone from Vermont who is under no direct threat
column6: either their property or their system of local government
column7: from the Confederates
column8: why would they think it was worthwhile to put on a uniform and risk their lives to save the Union?  Union just doesn’t mean anything to us now
column9: and it’s very hard to explain that to modern audiences.

column1: CWBR: I was especially intrigued by your discussion of language and vocabulary
column2: particularly when you discuss how the word “Union” has essentially dropped from our current vocabulary but that it dominated the Civil War and antebellum period. Why do you suppose that is the case? What did Union truly mean to the wartime generation of soldiers and civilians?

column1: GG: I do think Union has gone out of our vocabulary
column2: literally gone out of our vocabulary in terms of its mid-nineteenth-century meaning.  Union has a labor connation now; it has no tie to the way that it was used in the mid-nineteenth century.  In the mid-nineteenth century
column3: Union and nation and country and United States were deployed as synonyms frequently; they’re interchangeable in a lot of the writings that you see in the mid-nineteenth century.  I think that part of the problem now is that Union
column4: among that cluster of words
column5: simply has dropped out. Now we think of nation
column6: or we think of country.  And we take the nation for granted; we take all of the things for granted that were much more fraught in the mid-nineteenth century. We can’t imagine an internal threat to the United States of the sort that galvanized the loyal citizenry between 1861 and 1865.  Union is just a word that no longer has any meaning in that regard
column7: and if we don’t have a sense of what that word means . . . I think Elizabeth Varon’s book from a couple of years ago
column8: Disunion
column9: helps get at the meaning of the word.  She talks about how important the word “disunion” was and
column10: of course
column11: disunion can only be an important word if Union is an even more important one.  Why was the idea of disunion so troubling to so many people?  Well
column12: it’s because Union meant so much
column13: and I think it meant a cluster of things.  It meant the legacy of the founding generation
column14: the handiwork of the Philadelphia Convention
column15: the small “R” republican form of government
column16: the small “D” form of democracy; it meant a nation where common people had a voice in their own government--of course
column17: we’re talking in a mid-nineteenth-century context
column18: so that is to say white men had a voice in their government--and also had the ability to rise economically.  Lincoln spoke to this beautifully
column19: in many ways during the war
column20: but the really interesting and important thing to me is Lincoln is simply saying the same kinds of things--he says them better--but he is saying the same kinds of things that untold people are saying.  This place is unique in the Western World
column21: the rest of the Western World is going in the wrong direction
column22: advocates of Union believe.  They believe the failed revolutions of the 1840s show that the European nations were falling even more into the embrace of oligarchy and aristocracy and monarchy. In an American context
column23: the slaveholding southerners represented oligarchs and aristocrats; unionists in the free states deploy those words constantly in referring to those who led the secession movement.  Everything they stood for
column24: slaveholding oligarchs
column25: was inimical to the work and promise of what the Founding Fathers had done from the perspective of those who really took Union seriously.  They also believed that Union had meaning beyond the United States.  It’s important for all of those reasons within the United States but beyond that
column26: it’s important because
column27: they would argue
column28: that democracy had not at all been established in the Western World and if it fails here
column29: it might be snuffed out entirely.  When Lincoln talks about the last
column31: that’s what he is talking about
column32: but lots of other people used language very similar to that. So it has a Trans-Atlantic meaning
column33: and it also has a meaning for those who lived in the United States: a profound meaning
column34: something that would cause people to risk their lives.

column2: up front
column3: the challenges that any scholar must overcome when looking at the motivations of the common soldier and/or the common population during wartime
column4: especially given the tremendous amount of letters written during the American Civil War.  What sorts of obstacles did you face in trying to provide a broad enough scope to achieve a representation of the ways in which soldiers and civilians
column5: alike looked at Union and the Civil War?

column2: there’s so much evidence from the Civil War that you can argue anything.  You can take almost any position and argue it
column3: and you can find evidence that supports what you want to argue.  I don’t just look at soldiers in this book
column4: but common soldier testimony is so voluminous that I think the only way to come at it is to read as much as you can with the understanding that no scholar can read anything but the tiniest percentage. We’re talking about millions and millions of letters that the soldiers wrote
column5: any scholar who reads 20 or 25
column6: 000 of them has done heroic labor in research.  But those 25
column7: 000 letters are statistically insignificant
column8: and they cannot
column9: in any way
column10: be considered a real representative sample of soldiers’ sentiments.  So I think it’s important to place different kinds of evidence in conversation with one another.  Read as much as you can
column11: pick out the themes in the letters that you’ve read
column12: and then compare those to what you find elsewhere. There are other types of evidence you can use. In The Union War
column13: I used patriotic covers
column14: newspapers
column15: song lyrics
column16: and other things. I believe historians should use as many different kinds of evidence as possible--and when you have the array of different kinds of evidence
column17: see if themes cross over from one kind to another.  That’s the way I think we have to come at this. Everything we do is imperfect; there’s just no way to get a perfect reading of what was going on.  But when I think that you look at an array of evidence
column18: Union stands out. This includes the writings of Abraham Lincoln
column19: who had as good a sense of what motivated the loyal population as anyone. He was an incredibly perceptive politician
column20: and his public statements and statements designed to be leaked to the public
column21: so to speak
column22: first and last
column23: spoke of a war for Union.  He says it in the beginning; he says it in his message to Congress after the 1864 Presidential Election. In the latter
column24: he says
column25: in every great war--I’m paraphrasing him--a people have to have one overriding goal and in this great war of ours
column26: its Union.  Much of what he is talking about in that statement is a plea to pass the Thirteenth Amendment.  But in calling for that
column27: he specifically says the Thirteenth Amendment—emancipation
column28: killing slavery--will be one of the tools to help achieve the overriding goal of Union.  Even at that late stage of the war
column29: he understood that
column30: for most of the loyal citizenry
column31: it’s still about Union.    Most of them had embraced emancipation by that time
column32: not for the reasons we would want them to
column33: not as a great moral crusade
column34: but because they knew that emancipation would help to beat the Rebels
column35: would punish the slaveholding oligarchs who caused all of the problems in the first place
column36: and would create a better Union
column38: a Union that didn’t have the poisonous issue of slavery sort of lurking in the national political scene to rise up and cause a problem such as that in the Secession Winter of 1860-61.

column1: CWBR: If northerners were fighting for Union
column2: does that mean southerners were fighting primarily for disunion and not states’ rights or slavery?

column1: GG: I think it’s very important to separate the issues that brought secession and what motivated people in the Confederacy during the war. Those are two related issues
column2: but they’re not the same thing.  Secession came because the cotton South believed that Abraham Lincoln’s election
column3: the election of a Republican
column4: posed a sufficient threat to the long-term stability of slavery to make secession a smart choice.  It’s all about slavery (secession is)
column5: absolutely
column6: it’s all about slavery.  You take slavery out of the picture in 1860
column7: and you don’t get secession. I see no way for secession without slavery.  I don’t think there can be any question about that
column8: and I don’t think that any serious scholar does question that.  The fact that the Republicans had a plank in their platform that said they would leave slavery alone wherever it existed struck slaveholders as dishonest.  They knew that both Lincoln and Seward
column9: the two most famous Republicans at that stage
column10: had said
column11: in very well-known speeches from 1858
column12: that the nation couldn’t exist half-slave and half-free.  Slaveholders knew that both Lincoln and Seward wanted the nation to be all-free
column13: and therefore they just didn’t trust this idea that Republicans wouldn’t strike at slavery wherever it was
column14: never mind that they were going to block it in the territories.  So secession is all about slavery.  Once you get secession
column15: once you get the cascading crises in the wake of that first round of seceding states
column16: then other factors do come into play.  And I think motivations for actually supporting the Confederacy and going into the Confederate army were various
column17: just as they were with the United States soldiers.  But I think protecting home ground
column18: not being dictated to by the United States
column19: those are very important. But Confederates talked
column20: all the time
column21: about preserving their way of life
column22: preserving their country
column23: preserving their homes
column24: and all of those things are tied
column25: inextricably
column26: to the fact that they lived in a slaveholding society
column27: in a society that gave them racial control over 3.5 million black people.  Slavery is important any way you look at this
column28: but I think different kinds of motivations come into play in terms of what why soldiers went into the army for the Confederacy
column29: for example.  But we have to take as a base line that the vast majority--you can’t say everybody because with millions of people there are always outliers--the vast majority of the white south
column30: whether or not they owned slaves
column31: had a profound interest in slavery as a means of race control
column32: in addition to slavery as a means of economic control in some ways.

column2: how did many northerners justify going through the trial of so many casualties? It seems almost as if Grant gets a pass for the tremendous casualties. Was it the promise of a stronger Union?

column1: GG: He didn’t get a pass from all citizens in the North. A lot of the Democratic newspapers
column2: especially the Copperhead kind of newspapers such as The Old Guard
column3: were very hard on Grant. Some of them began to call him a butcher; that’s mainly an epithet that was leveled against him by Confederate newspapers but some of the newspapers in the United States did so as well. I think it was a measure of the devotion to Union that the citizenry was willing to put up with that level of loss in the spring and summer of 1864
column4: although it was a close thing in the summer.  We always need to remind ourselves that United States victory was not pre-ordained.  The United States could have lost the war.  I think that more than once the Confederacy came close to meeting the test it needed to meet for success. The Confederacy had an easier test than the United States did.  All the Confederacy had to do—and Lee understood this very well--was persuade the civilian population of the United States that it wasn’t worth the cost. I think Overland Campaign pushed a significant part of the civilian population close to that point in the summer of 1864
column5: from late June and through July and into August.  I think it was--of course this isn’t new with me--Sherman in Atlanta and Sheridan in the Shenandoah Valley that turned things around and re-elected Lincoln and the Republicans who
column6: of course
