column7: had not run as Republicans in 1864.  They ran as the Union Party
column8: which is another very clear indication of how important that concept was.  Let’s don’t even call ourselves Republicans
column9: they said
column10: we’ll bring in the greatest possible support if we call ourselves the Union Party.  It was close in the summer of 1864.  Grant did get some criticism; the person who was largely immune from criticism and a person who was a much bloodier general than Grant
column11: first to last
column12: was Lee.  That’s one of the interesting topics of the war.  We’re off-subject a bit
column13: but Lee essentially was given a pass by the people of the Confederacy. That’s always fascinated me.

column1: CWBR: You seem to be arguing for a middle ground when you discuss the role that the Union Army played in emancipation
column2: a coming together of opposing traditions (military and social). How important is an understanding of both perspectives in the process of emancipation and the execution of the war?

column1: GG: There are several factors that have to be in any consideration of the process of emancipation
column2: and it was a process.  Lincoln has to be in it; Lincoln’s absolutely one of the crucial factors.  Congress is very important
column3: beginning with the first Confiscation Act in the summer of 1861 and moving through all of that legislation in the spring and summer of 1862.  And
column4: of course
column5: the actions of hundreds of thousands of enslaved people in the Confederacy are very important
column6: the notion of self-emancipation that W.E.B. Dubois advanced in the mid-1930s and which has been picked up by any number of historians beginning in the late 1960s and coming down
column7: most recently
column8: through Steven Hahn and others now.  All of those are very important elements of the process
column9: but my argument is the one that gets left out is the role of the United States Army.  If you take the United States Army out of the equation
column10: you don’t get emancipation no matter what any of those other people want; it doesn’t matter.  If the United States Army doesn’t go somewhere
column11: emancipation doesn’t go there either. It’s fascinating to look at the geography of emancipation in the Confederacy during the war.  Where are the roughly half-million enslaved people who actually achieved freedom during the war?  And I take this number from Ira Berlin’s project at Maryland
column12: which I think is the gold standard in that regard; it’s about a half a million
column13: about one in seven.  One in seven
column14: where are they?  They’re where the United States Army went and stayed for a significant period of time: up and down the Mississippi River
column15: the Lower Peninsula in Virginia
column16: in significant parts of Tennessee
column17: that’s where emancipation comes.  It comes where the army goes.  What is the degree of emancipation in Texas?  Virtually zero; the United States Army doesn’t get there
column18: so it doesn’t matter how much an enslaved person wants to be free.  In Texas
column19: there’s no chance because the army doesn’t come.  So I just think it’s very important to put the army
column20: not only in the picture
column21: but put the army very prominently in the picture.  And also
column22: to make the point that it doesn’t even matter whether the soldiers in the army want emancipation to come or not.  A lot of them do; by the end of the war
column23: I think most of them did
column24: though again
column25: not for the reasons we would want but they still did.  But even somebody who isn’t really for emancipation
column26: an army commander who’s not really for emancipation--Sherman would be a good example of that--still acts as a destructive agent regarding slavery as he moves his army through central Georgia or wherever he’s going. The army is absolutely critical to the process of emancipation.

column1: CWBR: Stephanie McCurry’s most recent book suggests taking the slaves seriously in the ways in which they negotiated freedom
column2: that they had to navigate a difficult environment when the Union army came marching through the Confederate countryside. How might your findings complement or contradict the concept of the slave as an active player in emancipation?

column1: GG: I don’t contradict it at all. I think that enslaved people did play an active role when they were in a situation where they could. I’ll just come back to my earlier point; the situation has to be one where there is the possibility of freedom
column2: and that possibility of freedom lies in the presence of a United States military force near enough at hand to make the decision for freedom one that was attainable.  It might still be very difficult to get to Union lines
column3: it often was
column4: but they had to be close enough to get there.  So I see no inherent contradiction at all between the idea of an enslaved people working hard to achieve their own emancipation and the fact that the United States Army was crucial in allowing them to do so.  I see no contradiction there; it’s just that I would argue that it doesn’t matter how much an enslaved person wants to be free
column5: they cannot be free within the context of the Civil War unless the conditions are appropriate and the crucial factor is: has the United States Army come close enough to make it possible?

column1: CWBR: David Blight has become the staple for looking at postbellum reconciliation. Does recognition of slavery and its abolition as major war motivations or war goals hold northern and southern whites accountable for rebuilding their postbellum society?

column2: I think reconciliation has been exaggerated; I don’t think most people were reconciled after the Civil War.  I think there’s a difference between reconciliation and reunion
column3: and there’s an interesting study that will be coming out soon by Caroline Janney. She’s writing a book on the memory of the war that is going to deal with these themes
column4: and distinguishing between reunion and reconciliation is one of her points.  I think she’s exactly right. Of course reunion began at Appomattox; the two sections are put back together into the nation. But true reconciliation--the kind of reconciliation where the opposing parties would say it doesn’t really matter who was right or wrong
column5: let’s just talk about how brave we all were together
column6: and let’s airbrush black people out of the picture
column7: and just have a white drama of triumph--I don’t think that ever really happened.  I think it happened in key places
column8: sort of showcase places
column9: but reconciliation for Union veterans was--and Grant is a perfect example of this--their version of reconciliation was: we were right
column10: you were wrong
column11: and now we welcome you back on those terms.  That’s not really reconciliation of the sort that’s often put forward.  I think the animosities were profound
column12: and I don’t think they ever went away for the wartime generation.  And the mass of white veterans did not airbrush emancipation out of the picture. That doesn’t mean they held the kind of racial views we would want them to hold
column13: but they didn’t airbrush emancipation out.  There’s a wealth of evidence that supports this point.  In the speeches at Union monument dedications--the ones at Gettysburg are the easiest ones to get to—the speakers talk about Union the most but also talk a lot about emancipation.  Emancipation was a good thing; emancipation hurt the slaveholding class
column14: it removed this future threat to the republic
column15: it made a better republic possible.  I don’t subscribe to the idea that there’s this great collective amnesia that swept over white people North and South in terms of which side was right and which side was wrong.  I don’t think most Confederates would have ever said that they were wrong; they weren’t happy that they lost and they weren’t happy that slavery was gone but they accepted reality.  And the United States veterans who won the war would never have said that it didn’t matter whether you fought for Union or fought for the Confederacy.  For Union veterans
column16: they had been right and they were willing to reconcile on those terms: “You ex-Rebels were wrong and we defeated you
column17: now you can now come back into the Union.

column1: CWBR: During an 1889 battlefield dedication at Gettysburg
column2: Joshua Chamberlain says “our thoughts were not then of States as States
column3: but of the States united
column4: ---of that union and oneness in which the People of the United States lived and moved and had their being…[T]he cause for which we fought was higher; our thought was wider…What is lost is slavery of men and supremacy of States.” Was the Union the ultimate contribution of the wartime generation to the future of the United States?

column1: GG: I think the wartime generation would have absolutely said yes
column2: and they would have said that it was an improved Union because it no longer had slavery in it and therefore did not have a powerful oligarchic class of slaveholders.  I absolutely think they would have said that the primary outcome of this war was Union.  Emancipation is also extremely important
column3: they would have said
column4: for those reasons
column5: because it helps the Union.  It makes the Union stronger; it protects the Union going forward. I think that Chamberlain gets at that.  Chamberlain certainly mentions emancipation
column6: and he would have been much closer than most Union soldiers to the position that we
column7: in the twenty first century
column8: would want the Union soldiers to have regarding emancipation.  But it is about the Union; you have to save the Union first. To repeat myself
column9: they would have also said it’s a better Union.  War made a better Union.  It’s a better Union because that ticking time bomb of slavery has been excised.  So
column10: for most of the loyal citizenry
column11: they had taken care of all of the business at the end of the war.  They had saved the Union
column12: and with the Thirteenth Amendment they had gotten rid of slavery.  The only reason they went beyond those things was because in the war’s immediate aftermath former Confederates did not seem to understand they had been defeated. I don’t think there’s any great lost moment in Reconstruction
column13: I absolutely do not.  The Fourteenth Amendment was
column14: in the mid-nineteenth-century perspective
column15: mainly designed to punish slaveholders again; that’s what loyal citizens would have said.  Even the Fifteenth Amendment represented a way to punish the former slaveholding oligarchs.  The only reason we got to those two amendments was because the white South behaved so badly
column16: with a big assist from Andrew Johnson
column17: in the wake of Appomattox.  I think that many of the loyal citizens said: wait a minute; they’re not acting like they lost the war.  They’re acting like they didn’t lose the war!  They were offended by that
column18: and so they went beyond the Thirteenth Amendment.

column2: thank you for taking the time to discuss The Union War with us.

column1:
GG: You’re certainly welcome.

" Summer 2011 2011-08-01 Interview Harvard University Press ""

5512 978-1-59420-342-8 $36.00 CWBR Author Interview:
More than Freedom: Fighting for Black Citizenship in a White Republic 1829-1889 Kantrowitz
column2: Stephen			"<h3>Interview with Stephen Kantrowitz
column3: Professor of History and Director of Graduate Studies at the University of Wisconsin
column4: and recently named a finalist for the Gilder Lehrman Douglass Prize

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Stephen Kantrowitz
column2: Professor of History and Director of Graduate Studies at the University of Wisconsin. We will be discussing his recent book More than Freedom: Fighting for Black Citizenship in a White Republic 1829-1889. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: Stephen Kantrowitz (SK): I am really happy to be with you.
CWBR: Based off the title of your book
column2: could you explain why you chose the dates that you did since most people see your subject as something intimately connected with the war years?
the reason behind the wider parameters there is that the black freedom struggle in the nineteenth century is closely
column3: intimately related to the Civil War era. Its normal dates and topics and events
column4: but it isn't totally identical to it. The black freedom struggle that I'm charting begins with the publication of David Walker's Appeal to the Colored Citizen's in 1829-1830. Which from my perspective establishes the idea that African-Americans are going to forcefully claim a place in the American nation. But not only that
column5: it is possible for them to do so by making an alliance with whites and being their friends. I don't say that in a casual way
column6: Walker truly believes that it is possible for whites and blacks to share a country. That will mean changing the hearts of white people. It is that project
column7: as much as the project as ending slavery
column8: as much as the project of transforming the legal
column9: or constitutional status of African-Americans that he and his comrades are after during that entire period.  To 1889
column10: is a little less clear as a date. The reason I chose that date has a lot to do with the life of a person who is central to the arch of the book
column11: which is Lewis Hayden
column12: who was a fugitive slave who becomes one of the key activists in the black Boston community of the nineteenth century.   He dies in 1889.  That is the year before the lodge elections bill fails
column13: that is the year before the Mississippi disenfranchising constitution passes
column14: it really is the end of an era that something like David Walker and his friends would have imagined as possible earlier in the century.

column1: CWBR: You chose Boston as the focus of your work. Why did you choose this city over others with large free African American populations like New York or Philadelphia?

column2: first it is personal. I am from suburban Boston
column3: I am from Brookline
column4: and in the course of exploring the history of the free black communities in the North
column5: I realized that I felt a very powerful personal connection to the place
column6: and found the strangeness and difference of the history that I was exploring relative to my own experience of the place
column7: really a powerful motivator that kept me going and connected to the project in many ways over the course of a decade. I think there is a much more important intellectual reason for doing this project and that is free black people are the freest and most equal in Massachusetts. There freer and more equal in Massachusetts than any other polity or context in North America
column8: or at least in the United States. Black men have the right to vote
column9: and have few formal restrictions on their lives. Therefore we get to see the limits of the possible. We also get to see a place where slavery has been extinguished since the 1780s
column10: and so there is a long
column11: long history of freedom. We also have a white climate that is more open to anti-slavery abolitionist ideas comparatively early. So
column12: Boston is a great place to test the limits of the possible. It is a great place to see how far things could go
column13: and it is wonderful for that reason too because it is in Boston that the first important interracial coalitions devoted to anti-slavery and equality emerge in the form of New England anti-slavery society and the Liberator and that world. This makes Boston a wonderful place to see how far it was possible to imagine how things would go.

column1: CWBR: African Americans in Boston identified themselves as ""colored citizens
column2: how important was this term to the fight for citizenship?

column1: SK: It is a surprisingly important term
column2: and one that kept coming up over the course of the research. Not because I think everybody in that world had read David Walker
column3: it is not clear to me that they had. The term itself survives and establishes a foothold in people's imaginations and it does so
column4: as something to aspire to. That is people say
column5: we the ""colored citizen's"" assemble to do this or that
column6: and you will find that language throughout the anti-slavery press
column7: you'll find it in petitions
column8: you'll find it throughout the Civil War and beyond. People use it to express their hope that they can be both ""colored"" and citizens. African Americans also use this term ironically
column9: they use it to suggest that many people think this term is an oxymoron in fact
column10: and that we are incapable of being citizens because we are ""colored."" African Americans understand that use a lot of other terms that signal the same things. Like
column11: ""Aliened-Americans
column12: or the term ""2/3 free
column13: that is one of David Walker's phrases
column14: or the ""nominally free."" There are a lot of other phrases like these that play upon this idea of skepticism. ""Colored Citizens"" is really critical
column15: and at one point
column16: was actually the title of the book.

column1: CWBR: Was the rhetoric and legacy of the American Revolution important to helping African Americans see a path to citizenship? Is following this ""American"" pattern helping African Americans to gain citizenship?
SK:Well to some degree. But I would phrase it a little differently. I would say African Americans are they themselves aware that they had participated in the Revolution. So say
column2: George Middleton
column3: a Revolutionary War veteran
column4: is one of the stalwarts of the community in the early nineteenth century on Beacon Hill. There are a large number of memories of the so called ""bucks"" of America
column5: a black unit that was presented a flag by John Hancock. So
column6: what I am suggesting is that the relationship to the Revolution is not one of the Revolution happened
column7: we can use this event and therefore analogize our freedom struggle to the American Revolution's freedom struggle. Instead
column8: we are going to seize that freedom struggle as though it were our own which it only was in part of course. The best example of this is the way that slavery comes to an end in Massachusetts. Which is
column9: well there are many slaves in Massachusetts in the 1780s. However
column10: in the middle of the decade
column11: a series of court cases brought by Massachusetts slaves in which they sue for their freedom based upon the first line of the Massachusetts constitution. Which is ""All men are born free and equal."" On the basis of that simple utterance
column12: they say how can slavery exist when all men are born free? The courts agree
column13: and the Supreme Court agrees that slavery is unenforceable. Slavery collapses. So
column14: the Revolution offers some of the tool kit for establishing freedom
column15: but it is black people seizing that opportunity and leveraging those universal principles into something that will work for them in their own lives. That is the importance of the American Revolution for them. You can see this in the way that William Cooper Nell approaches the Revolution when he writes Colored Patriots of the American Revolution in 1855. He is very carefully deploying a partial record of black military service and other achievements
column16: to make a case that African Americans had always been integral to the American national project. Now
column17: he leaves out the fact that many African Americans took up the British offer to serve with them in exchange for freedom. This had been the case in every war where they had been an opportunity to serve one side or another for freedom. So
column18: he writes a very selective account in order to make the case
column19: because
column20: well
column21: he is a propagandist as well as a historian. So
column22: it is a complex relationship
column23: but the Revolution is absolutely useful too and important too to the black freedom struggle in the nineteenth century.

column1: CWBR: How important was the relationship between black activists and white supporters
column2: why was this relationship needed in order to move citizenship forward?
we think about the United States in 1850 or 1860
column3: there are about 250
column4: 000 free black Northerners
column5: there are somewhere around 20 million white Northerners.  There is no way that 250
column6: 000 people even if they were all enfranchised
column7: even if they were all activists
column8: which of course they are not. There is no way that this tiny group of people can assert itself politically and transform a white republic
column9: into a non-racial republic. What they can do is recruit white allies. That is the reason that 1829 is such an important date.  It is the first time we hear free blacks appeal to whites In David Walker's appeal when he says
column10: ""What a happy country this will be if the whites will listen."" William Lloyd Garrison and a handful of others do appear to listen to that
column11: and their willingness to extend themselves over the color line at great social cost
column12: and enormous lifetime that many of these individuals make to that struggle. That ability to do that and show that this is a cause worth doing is the turning point for African American participation and belonging in the American body politic
column13: and American social life
column14: and American cultural and political life. So
column15: I think it is absolutely critical and tough
column16: it is not easy
column17: and as with any struggles white people at any moment can decide to go home
column18: and retreat to a world of comfort. That doesn't involve constant struggle
column19: and their black counterparts do not have this option
column20: and so there is an inequality built into the struggle itself. On the other hand
column21: some of the white people last in the struggle for decades
column22: and some last for their entire lives. The book charts some of the ways in which some of the white allies disappoint and desert and betray their black coalition partners. On the other hand
column23: it shows people who had been bitter enemies like Benjamin Butler
column24: turn out to be for critical moments really important allies. So
column25: it's a mixed bag
column26: but it is a really important story because it is what makes that change possible for a specific group of people.

column1: CWBR: Why was the formation of organizations
column2: public and private
column3: from Masons to militias
column4: so central to your book?

column1: SK: There are central to the story of this because
column2: for the most part
column3: I said that black men were enfranchised in Massachusetts
column4: but they are excluded from virtually every white dominated institution
column5: organization
column6: political party
column7: and political club. So
column8: in order to learn the function as political beings
column9: to learn how institutions work
column10: to learn how constitutions are written
column11: to learn how meetings are run
column12: to learn all the basic elements of political life African Americans have to turn to one another to do it. And it is through these organizations that they do these things
column13: in much the same way that Europeans had turned to one another in the eighteenth century in the middle of the ""Enlightenment"" and begun to constitute themselves as independent societies
column14: which were not under the control of the state or the church. It is a much the same story as that
column15: except in the American context it is not threatening to a king or church and thus they can do. If they try to do it in Richmond or Charleston
column16: or in New Orleans
column17: it would have been construed as a precursor to a slave revolt. In this context they can do it and they learn to do. The second reason is less practical and more transcendent
column18: that is they are mostly poor people. These are mostly people who experience a lot of hostility and neglect in their daily lives
column19: as members of a very small stigmatized minority. So
column20: to have a place to go where they constitute themselves as whole
column21: special
column22: important that is really important to them and their understanding of themselves and one another
column23: and their ability to turn to the wider world with a sense of they are worthy of the things they imagine. This takes place in churches
column24: it takes place in schools
column25: it takes place in masonic and other kinds of fraternal organizations. Wherever it takes place I think it is part of a dialectic
column26: a necessary back and forth between the retreat to a place of security and comfort and the knowledge that one needs to move out from that world into the world where you might make some transformative change.

column1: CWBR: How does the 1850 Fugitive Slave Act change how African Americans work to preserve their freedom?
SK: Well the Fugitive Slave Law of 1850 upends their politics. There had been efforts to capture fugitives
column2: and rescue fugitives prior to that; examples include the Lattimore war in the 1840s. But at the same time they had not had the concerted weight of the federal government pursuing a pro-slavery political project in this way. The Fugitive Slave Law of 1850 signals to African Americans that the Federal Government has abandoned whatever ambivalence had characterized it at some point. And instead has decided to become active agents for slaveholders
column3: and that is really threatening. It warns a fair number of far-sighted African American intellectuals that the Dred Scott decision is coming. Martin Delany as early as 1854
column4: remarks
column5: ""forget these personal liberty laws
column6: our fate is in the hands of the federal government
column7: that is where the fate of our liberties will be decided."" That turns out to be true. So
column8: it is hard to overstate the importance of the Fugitive Slave law
column9: it causes some people to flee
column10: it forces others to become more militant. It ignites the political crisis of the 1850s
column11: and it accelerates the spiral from Kansas/Nebraska
column12: to Bleeding Kansas
column13: to John Brown
column14: to the beginning of the war itself.

column2: when the war finally does come we have this popular picture of free African Americans pushing to join the army
column3: and help fight for freedom. However
column4: is that the case 100%
column5: in at least the North or in Boston. What issues did the free African American community of Boston have with joining the army
column6: based on what their idea of citizenship was?

column2: when recruitment begins for the 54th and later the 55th and the 5th cavalry
column3: black Bostonians bring to that effort their own history with military recruitment. For them
column4: the last ten years have been crucial because for ten years black Bostonians have been trying to establish a black unit of the state militia
column5: with black officers accredited and admitted and enrolled in the militia in the same way as any other unit. That is
column6: enrolled on the terms of perfect equality with other units. That fits with their whole idea that engagement as citizens of the American nation requires a transformation of the American nation so that it abandons its commitment to whiteness. For example
column7: they are not only asking to be chartered as a unit of the state militia they want the want the state to remove the word white from its state militia law. That is a key feature here
column8: which the state won't do
column9: because that is part of federal law.  So
column10: they run up against this over and over again
column11: and in frustration their militia movement collapses and they never march and it is a kind of a fiasco. It is not a fiasco though at the end of the day
column12: because what it does is it sets the table for the conversation at the end of the day that happens in 1863
column13: and that conversation says: it is great that the Union has decided to honor our desire to serve against the slaveholders
column14: but it has to be on terms of equality. Initially they think they are going to be offered the same pay as white soldiers
column15: they are promised that in the recruiting for the 54th. People like Robert Morrison and John DeGrasse go to the governor and say: we need to have black officers appointed. Governor Andrew approaches the War Department
column16: and is told in no uncertain terms this will not happen. Faced with a situation where they are not going to treated as equals
column17: where they can't have black officers
column18: black units will be led by white officers
column19: Morrison and his friends say nope we are not going. The proof is in the pudding here
column20: the commitment of black Bostonians is not universal but it is strong enough when the 54th marches through Boston on its way to South Carolina in the spring of 1863
column21: there is nearly 1000 men marching through the streets but only about 40 of them declare Boston as their hometown. Compare that to the initial movement to form a home guard to defend Massachusetts at the moment of secession in 1861.  In one night they get 125 men to sign up
column22: here they had weeks
column23: and weeks to recruit and they only had about 40. That tells the story
column24: as for equality a lot of people simply aren't willing to serve
column25: and when it turns out they are going to be paid as military laborers
column26: and not private soldiers
column27: many of them think twice about what they have done. Some of them have to be sent home
column28: they strike for pay. When the state of Massachusetts offers to make up the difference in pay they say that won't do. The Federal Government has to recognize our equal service with equal pay
column29: if we take extra pay from Massachusetts it makes it look like the money is the point
column30: of course the money is not the point
column31: the principle is the point. By 1864
column32: Congress ends up passing the Equalization Act
column33: ultimately pay is pretty much equalized for everybody. They do win that fight
column34: but it really is a painful struggle though.

column1: CWBR: When the war ends slavery ends
column2: now the struggle for citizenship though has really just begun. What did the activists in Boston hope to accomplish in a world without slavery
column3: and how well were they able to reach out to their newly free southern brethren and help and tie together with them this push for Citizenship?

column1: SK: This is where the great disappointment of their story begins. Neither the effort to build on their wartime victory
column2: and on the early constitutional amendments
column3: or the outreach to the newly free people bears the kind of fruit that they thought it would. The 13th
column4: 14th
column5: and 15th Amendments are transcendentally important.  They understand how important these things are to ending slavery
column6: and national path to citizenship
column7: and there cannot be racial discrimination in obtaining the franchise. Few things can be as important as these
column8: they also see the limits of them.  Some of the people in this world oppose the ratification of the 14th Amendment because it doesn't go far enough. It does allow southern states to continue discrimination against the right to vote
column9: if they are willing to pay the penalty of a proportional reduction of representation in Congress. That seems like a total betrayal to people like Edwin Garrison Walker. The 15th Amendment likewise
column10: a lot of these folks believed that should have included women too. Many black activists in the Boston community
column11: men and women
column12: are some of the best women's rights advocates in the United States. They are very disappointed to see the 15th Amendment go forward
column13: for not speaking about sex as well as race. They are also disappointed that the right to vote might not be limited on the basis of race
column14: as opposed to an affirmative right to vote. What happens quickly thereafter
column15: black Northerners find themselves marginalized and treated as second class citizens
column16: in much the same way as black Southerners are experiencing. They are described as mob like and incapable
column17: as really not quite ready for the full exercises and privileges of citizenship. When it comes to the freed people
column18: I think black Northerners because of the power of their vision and the power of their literacy
column19: because of their institutions initially feel as though they are going to shape freedom. They are going to teach the free people how to live as citizens rather than slaves. But the free people have ideas of their own. They have not grown up in an institutional framework
column20: have not grown up under constitutions
column21: they live in a different cultural and political world. So
column22: it is very difficult for
column23: say
column24: ministers who have been trained in the North
column25: or for that matter Masonic organizers
column26: to use the same tools that they used in the North to build political or cultural institutions in the South. Although they often rise to prominence in southern Reconstruction politics
column27: they don't build the same world that they had lived in in the North. It is just not possible
column28: in terms of life
column29: in terms of labor. The violence of the labor struggle in the South are just too different from what they know. It is a story of surprises and disappointments.

column2: I appreciate you taking the time to discuss your most recent work
column3: <i>More than Freedom: Fighting for Black Citizenship in a White Republic
column4: 1829-1889. Thank you for joining us today.

column1:
SK: It has been a great pleasure.

" Frawley

column1:
6306 9780307592644 $30.00 CWBR Author Interview:
Custer's Trials: A Life on the Frontier of a New America Stiles
column2: T.J.			"<h3>Interview with T.J. Stiles
column3: author of Custer’s Trials: A Life on the Frontier of a New America

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): The Civil War Book Review is pleased to speak with T.J. Stiles
column2: winner of multiple awards for biography and author of Jesse James: Last Rebel of the Civil War and The First Tycoon: The Epic Life of Cornelius Vanderbilt. Today we get to discuss his most recent work Custer's Trials: A Life on the Frontier of a New America. Mr. Stiles
column3: thank you for joining us today.

column1: T.J. Stiles: Thanks very much for interviewing me.
CWBR: You've worked on subjects from varied backgrounds and who played remarkably different roles in American history. What drew you to George Armstrong Custer
column2: who dies in a remote area at a young age
column3: and is today remembered mostly for how he died?

column2: I approach my subjects from the perspective of a historian. I'm interested in the period and the questions and then that leads me to an interesting individual who I can really explore as a writer as well. And so
column3: Custer is someone who's ubiquitous in any exploration of the Civil War Era. He just keeps showing up everywhere. And so I was very aware of his life. And as I began to think how to explore this revolutionary period of the Civil War and Reconstruction
column4: and all of the attendant issues that come up with that period in a new way
column5: I wanted to think ""What have I not done? What are stories and aspects of this history that are interesting to me?"" And I thought about the western experience and I thought about the conventional Civil War in the East and I thought about the other aspects--literary
column6: cultural--of this period that I have not touched on in my first two books. Custer first drew because of the travelogue of his life. His travels across that astonishing nineteenth-century landscape. Traveling from New York to the Great Plains
column7: to dealing with pre-industrial nomadic peoples
column8: to visiting Wall Street and having business there. It is just an amazing journey across that panorama. And then
column9: as I began to look into what he was doing
column10: then it really came together for me as a book and what my particular take would be.

column1: CWBR: Custer's Trials is ostensibly about the life and times of Custer
column2: but as you have alluded to here
column3: the book works equally well as a story about the birth of a modern United States. When did you realize that Custer's life embodied this change and how did that realization shape your approach to writing about Custer and his contemporaries?

column1: Stiles: Well there are several things that began to put together a picture of Custer as a figure on a frontier in time
column2: as I put it in the book. We think of him as a figure on the geographical frontier
column3: which part of his life definitely embodied that. But also
column4: I eventually came to the conclusion that he was--what really defined his life
column5: more than a geographical frontier--was this chronological frontier. And one little nugget of that came from his serialized memoir
column6: which he wrote for a major magazine and which was published as a book
column7: about his first years in the West after the Civil War. And he described his march to the Battle of the Washita
column8: through a howling blizzard
column9: how he was leading the column through the snow with only a compass to guide. And he wrote that
column10: he could see the width of Broadway. He meant Broadway in New York. He didn't bother to identify it as the great street of New York. He assumed his audience would know. And that identification with the cosmopolitan center
column11: that allusion to an urban metropolitan landmark
column12: in a story about the wilderness of the Great Plains--about the Indian Wars--that was fascinating to me. That was something that just stuck in my mind from years ago when I first read that. And then as I began to look into his life
column13: and I began to look into the way he had a very diverse range of actives outside of service in the Army
column14: and even his service within the Army
column15: showed him struggling with excited by
column16: and sometimes rejecting all the many changes taking place in America at the time.

column1: CWBR: Even before the Civil War ended
column2: while praise for Custer was growing there was a growing contrast between him and Grant. Does this contrast reflect the thesis of your book
column3: which places Custer on this frontier in time?

column1: Stiles: I think the relationship between Custer and Grant is absolutely central to the book. One of the interesting things about Custer is that he had this very large and flamboyant
column2: colorful
column3: public life and yet because of the volume of material that has been preserved--the number of letters he wrote
column4: the way in which his wife wrote about their intimate life together---we have a very interior portrait of Custer and this is actually the most interior biography I've been able to write so far. In his relationship with Grant
column5: you see both the external and the interior aspects of Custer
column6: highlighted by the contrast with Grant. And the growing tension between Custer and the times is reflected in and exacerbated by his growing tension with Grant. Grant was equally American with Custer in many ways. They were both from Ohio
column7: they both were from struggling families
column8: they had very obscure backgrounds
column9: and yet
column10: Grant was understated. He was someone who despised flamboyance and the big show. He was extremely practical--someone who was very modest and direct in his methods and his manner. Custer
column11: of course
column12: was the flamboyant figure
column13: very consciously adopting an almost southern air of the cavalier. And that was significant. That isn't just something he should be scorned for. And yet
column14: it is something that is a little bit out of step with an America that was more organizational
column15: industrial
column16: and corporate
column17: and one that that was more technical as opposed to heroic and individualist in the way that Jacksonian America had been. And this then throughout the course of his relationship with Grant
column18: this difference in style
column19: in leadership
column20: difference in style in their public image
column21: the difference in their interest to having a public image
column22: which did not appeal to Grant as much as it did to Custer obviously. That becomes caught up with the way they address the times. Grant is somebody who came to embrace not only emancipation
column23: but civil rights. Whereas Custer increasingly made himself into a public figure opposing civil rights
column24: opposing black suffrage
column25: opposing the fourteenth amendment. There is a rise and fall in their how much they confronted each other personally
column26: but it really came to a head right before the 1876 Little Bighorn Campaign.

column1: CWBR: Grant is an interesting figure because he is our segue into other figures in Custer's life that you dwell on in the book. Custer is obviously influenced tremendously by the people closest to him or the people above him in terms of the military institution. So can you describe the dynamic between Custer
column2: his wife Libbie
column3: and Eliza Brown
column4: the African American teenager he hired during the Civil War?

column2: this is something that is both fascinating in terms of simply the human narrative but also the way in which Custer came to confront
column3: in a very personal way
column4: the larger issues of the Civil War. Custer was someone who had a professional military education
column5: even though he famously graduated last in his class at West Point in 1861
column6: though first in demerits. He graduated--and many cadets did not make it all the way through. He had a professional military education
column7: probably the best in the world at that point. And yet he rose in the Civil War through personal connections
column8: through patronage
column9: the traditional method of advancing in the world
column10: and he combined ability and real merit with this working the chains of patronage. So 1863
column11: on the eve of the battle of Gettysburg
column12: his personal connections with General Alfred Pleasonton lifted him to the rank of Brigadier General
column13: gave him command of the Michigan Brigade of Cavalry
column14: he demonstrate his ability at the Battle of Gettysburg
column15: particularly the third day
column16: when he not only famously led charges
column17: but he also deployed his men well and making use of their Spencer rifles and the new technology that the Union is bringing to the War. Now this great moment
column18: this transformation in Custer's life
column19: when he became a Brigadier General of the US volunteers
column20: this led him to want to adopt the lifestyle of a general and the lifestyle he'd seen Pleasonton lead. So he went to a contraband camp in Virginia at the close of the Gettysburg campaign and he—a contraband camp of course as I know your listeners know was a camp for escaped slaves--and he found this young teenage from the piedmont region of Virginia
column21: who was really extraordinary. She obviously had a real presence
column22: as we know not only from Custer's response to her
column23: but from what his wife Libbie later wrote. And she went to work for him as his cook
column24: she took advantage of that position to really build authority and security for herself
column25: such as she had never known. She took all of the skills of dealing with white people from a position of total powerlessness and she applied those in the role of the general's cook
column26: and she really became his domestic manager. She traded information with visitors
column27: couriers and messengers from other commands. She served as the banker
column28: an interceder for Custer's men
column29: she began to build her own patronage network by distributing food out of the general's mess. So she is someone who really took advantage of that position
column30: built up the security for herself and then had a very interesting change in her life when February 1864 Custer then married Elizabeth Bacon
column31: or Libbie as she was known. A very well education
column34: who came to the front and found that another woman was running the household
column35: a young black woman. Now this was long before the Great Migration
column36: there are very few black people in the North
column37: and Libbie doesn't know how to navigate that relationship. She expects to have the domestic authority as the wife
column38: and especially as the wife of a general. And yet she finds herself consistently outmaneuvered by this young black woman. So there is a personal tension as well as mutual admiration and respect between the two women
column41: find the issues of race and slavery personified in this extremely intelligent and capable and resourceful black woman
column42: and she actually tries to educate the Custers in slavery. She brings them
column44: they go to Louisiana and to Texas. She brings them into slave quarters
column45: she introduces them to people who have been whipped
column46: and shows the scars on their backs and really helps to change Custer's views because he had quite frankly accepted slavery and opposed Lincoln's election in 1860. And yet this personal relationship
column48: bring him around on the issues of emancipation
column49: and that relationship between the three of them went on for six years until 1869.

column2: as a researcher
column3: how difficult was it and what sort of methods did you use to reconstruct her life
column4: to put it back together because it seems that a lot of the material you were able to draw on had to come from Custer or his wife
column5: so how did get to an authentic version of Eliza Brown?

column1: Stiles: This is a very interesting question. This is something I dealt with
column2: for example in my first book Jesse James
column3: for whom but not only for Jesse James but the lives of the slaves in his family and his family members was not well documented in letters and diaries and traditional sources. So it is a matter of correlation and interpretation and putting together small bits of information until it builds a convincing picture. In the case of Eliza Brown
column4: we also have the benefit of the many amateur researchers who looked into Custer's life. He's one of those figures who has attracted a great deal non-scholarly research and as my late mentor Richard Maxwell Brown said: ""These are grassroots historians.” They should not be scorned. They don't operate within the academic structure
column5: they are not interested in issues of historiography
column6: they can get very focused on the trees rather than the forest and yet a lot of them do great work. And so
column7: there has been research on Eliza Brown--the farm she came from
column8: who her slaveholders were
column9: where she ended up after she left the Custers. I was able to draw on those bits of information. Put together with what historians have written
column10: I think Brenda Stevenson is the author of Life in Black and White: A Look at Slave Life in Northern Virginia (Life in Black and White: Family and Community in the Slave South) and tries to understand what daily life was life
column11: what the relationships were like
column12: what the struggles were like for the enslaved
column13: in exactly the part of the country where Eliza Brown came from. So it's drawing on the historiography
column14: putting it together with bits of data
column15: and then getting into the more qualitative look at her life
column16: much of which comes through not only mentions in Custer's accounts
column17: in his letters
column18: and letters from Libbie Custer
column19: but also Libbie's memoirs is a very important source. Memoirs need to be treated with a grain of salt of course
column20: more than a grain of salt. What's fascinating about Libbie Custer's memoirs is that if you read it carefully with an attention to who Eliza Brown and her position in the world
column21: you can read it very differently than has been read in the past. Libbie Custer reflected in her memoirs this tension
column22: as well as the mutual respect and support
column23: that the two of them had. There's many moments throughout their memoirs which she highlights moments where she embarrassed Eliza Brown
column24: when she sort of showed her up
column25: her racism is quite frank. We understand the tension between the two women because Libbie Custer wrote about it. It's there in her own account and so that is convincing to me because I don't think it is particularly flattering to Libbie Custer. Sometimes you take the same bit of information and if you think about that information from the perspective of the person who is has traditionally not been in power to tell the story it looks very different.

column2: when Custer was deployed to Louisiana immediately after the Grand Review of the armies and he took Eliza Brown
column3: took Libbie
column4: they stopped briefly in Michigan
column5: and Libbie's hometown Monroe
column6: then they traveled through Ohio to their way to New Orleans
column7: they stopped at a restaurant that had no separate facilities for black customers. And so
column8: the owner refused to serve Eliza Brown at all and Custer insisted that she be fed. And so he insisted
column9: in a great confrontation with the owner
column10: that she be seated with Custer and his staff. And Libbie
column11: and it was a very tense moment
column12: as we know from Libbie’s memoir
column13: and this has been traditionally has been seen as a great thing. Custer was insisting that his servant should be showed respect and served also. But for one thing it is the lack of segregated facilities that upset Custer. The fact that there were no facilities where her to be fed. He wasn't trying to desegregate the dining halls of Ohio; he was asserting his position in the world as a major general at that point of the US Volunteers. And he wasn't going to let some civilian say that his servant couldn't eat. And for Eliza Brown
column14: that moment is fraught with tension; she did not ask for that confrontation. She is aware of the dangers of confrontations over race; and she knows that if anyone is going to suffer from that confrontation
column15: it will be her. This is my interpretation brought in by imaginatively understanding--based on our knowledge of race relations of the Civil War and its immediate aftermath--what life was like for a black person who is powerless in that situation. Libbie wrote that she was embarrassed
column16: and I write about that in the page
column17: but I say from Eliza Brown's perspective it’s not embarrassment-- its fear
column18: its danger
column19: and a sense of powerlessness that's going to be in play. Now that's interpretation
column20: that's not fact. And yet
column21: highlighting this moment
column22: drawing it out
column23: putting my interpretations on the page
column24: draws attention to it and I hope gets the reader to think about these moments from the perspective from somebody whose normally been left in the margins
column25: or left out of the picture entirely.

column1: CWBR: What was it about the West as a context--because you talk a lot about context and how much it matters for these historical actors--what was so different about the American West versus Custer's lived experiences before the war and during the war?
Stiles: That's an interesting question because it brings out Custer's personal flaws and conundrums as well as the
column2: as you put it
column3: the contextual differences. Custer was someone who I think was driven by a great ambition; he desired greatness and he desired to be seen as great; and
column4: coming from a very obscure background
column5: he had an underside
column6: I detect
column7: an underside of insecurity
column8: which gave him great volatility. He rose to high rank in the U.S. Volunteers at a very age without much of an apprenticeship in lower levels of command; he was from a staff position to a command position very early in his life; and
column9: so he didn't have the seasoning
column10: the experience and the slow process of maturation within an organization
column11: within in a command. The Civil War though was a great crisis and we see in the Civil War that--and actually in later moments in the West also--that in combat is the one moment when we don't see signs of insecurity
column12: we don't see the volatility that marked other areas of his personal life. He was at ease; he was himself; and
column13: so combat despite the impression left by how he died
column14: combat was his great forte. He wasn't simply lucky
column15: even though he was; he wasn't simply heroic in leading charges
column16: though he was; he really knew how to husband his resources
column17: how to make use of the latest technology. He more often deployed his men in dismounted skirmish lines in the Civil War then he had them lead in mounted charges. He made great use of his rifled artillery and other resources available to him. And so
column18: we see Custer as a true professional in the Civil War and in moments that come afterward. The problem is
column19: the moment that combat stops
column20: Custer now has to play a different role; he has to play a different role within the Army itself
column21: in which his role goes from combat leadership to what can only be called management. He has learn how to deal with troops who are no longer driven by the great mission of the Civil War who are now going to be dealing quotidian complaints about food and discipline
column22: and other issues that come up in any command. He has to develop tact; he as to develop a way of keeping his troops contented to a certain degree without simply relying his heroic image
column23: and that's an area where he really flounders. And what happens is this is where we see the insecurity in Custer. Again and again he lashes out
column24: very different from the way that Grant as a commander operated. Grant really knew how to win his troops loyalty without relying on harsh discipline
column25: not that he didn't use it
column26: but that wasn't his primary hallmark as a commander.

column1: Custer on the other hand engaged in whippings
column2: head shavings--other humiliations--to try and force his men to knuckle under
column3: and it only built up more resentment. Now in the different phases in the West the first came actually in this period of 1865 into very early 1866 when he was deployed into Louisiana and then Texas. At that point he was commanding U.S. volunteers who had not been mustered out; and
column4: these are troops that wanted to go home. He was dealing with Texas which is an area that had never been significantly invaded by Union forces
column5: it had not been conquered; slavery had gotten stronger there
column6: and there we begin to see another aspect of Custer's post war difficulties
column7: which is a return to his conservative viewpoint
column8: and also his desire to be accepted by
column9: what we can only call
column10: his social superiors. So the planters of Texas who had done quite well during the war
column11: they cultivate Custer and he very readily accepts their invitations and their offers to socialize with them. And we see his Jacksonian Democratic
column12: conservative views on race and society really coming back to the fore after all of this lobbying by Eliza Brown about slavery. That's the political of this story and how it put him in conflict with the country becomes very important with his next deployment in the West in 1866 and 1867.

column1: CWBR: Could we also describe the difference between east and west at this time as one of---in the American West--especially in the 1870s--as a place that is simply less managed
column2: it's one that seems in your book
column3: at least
column4: seems to be a place that is racially ambiguous at times
column5: where people who are in the margins of society in the east are in power in the west
column6: does that play into the West's ability to confound not only Custer but his contemporaries too?

column1: Stiles: Well I think that's a major issue in general in the West. We have to remember of course there are many wests. The southwest in Texas you have the slave economy of the South
column2: which not only in Texas
column3: but also in the so-called Five Civilized tribes of the nations that had been ejected from the southeast on the Trail of Tears
column4: they have slavery
column5: they sided with the Confederacy. You have that southern slaveholding culture is very strong on the southern Great Plains
column6: and then you have other layers of the West
column7: which are brining into a mix and conflict and alliance
column8: a very complex mix of very different peoples in a vast landscape. So of course you have Latino-Americans--I wouldn't call them Mexican-Americans because the border crossed them--who have strongly influenced a lot of the culture in the West and especially in the southwest. You have many different Native Americans who are in conflict with each other. You have different economies that are taking place; you have of course the Sodbusters in Kansas and Nebraska
column9: but you also have the mining economy of the mountain states
column10: and you have the great transit that's taking place across the Great Plains
column11: which is a major issue
column12: and something the Army doesn’t really quite come to grips with because its driving the conflict of the High Plains nations. And then you have this hybrid hunting and trading economy that the Great Plains peoples have to varying degrees and the conflicts between the High Plains who are fully nomadic and the nations of the lower Great Plains
column13: lower in altitude to the east
column14: who combine horticulture with seasonal hunting
column15: and who are in a great conflict with the High Plains nations.

column1: It's a multilayered set of conflicts. You have a changing economy as the cattle drives start and you have the great cow-towns grow-up in Kansas
column2: and you have different sources of conflict. It's not simply whites come in and try to grab the land
column3: it's migration through the West is creating economic degradation which is making the bison based economy of the High Plains untenable
column4: so the Army keeps trying to assert the right of passage and the Great Plains people are stating quite frankly that's making their lives untenable and the Army doesn't really quite accept it--or to the degree that they understand it--they say you just have to live with it. So there are all of these different tensions that are taking place and Custer steps into this very complex landscape at a moment of personal crisis. I mean 1866 and 1867
column5: when Custer is deployed to Ft. Riley
column6: now his regular Army rank is that of Lieutenant Colonel
column7: he is effectively the field commander of the new 7th cavalry
column8: and yet he was in personal crisis because he had thrown him into Andrew Johnson's campaign again the Republicans and the 14th amendment. He went alongside Grant on the Swing Around the Circle
column9: but where Grant was disgusted by Johnson's politics
column10: and actually left the campaign early
column11: Custer spoke to the crowds alongside Johnson on the stump and helped organize a soldier's convention to support Andrew Johnson
column12: to oppose the 14th amendment
column13: the Republicans; he very much himself a conservative national political figure. And as a result
column14: he was scorned by a majority of--at least politically speaking--by a majority of people in the North. And he went from being a great hero to being a---someone who was intensely controversial.

column1: This is before he starts confronting the Indian Wars and so that important; he's under pressure
column2: he's under crisis. And his constant neediness
column3: this personal neediness of his
column4: for attention and approval and for sex
column5: quite frankly
column6: put him in crisis in his marriage. He had spent time in New York in 1866
column7: away from his wife
column8: he was flirting
column9: he was pursuing other women. And I believe
column10: from reading the bits of evidence that we have
column11: that he had as a result created a crisis in his marriage. So Custer confronts this very complex picture of the conflict  with the High Plains nations at a moment when he is personally preoccupied
column12: and it's a very different kind of warfare
column13: and of course that's something historians have stressed
column14: that the warfare on the Great Plains
column15: it’s not properly guerilla warfare--it’s a raiding warfare
column16: something that Alexander the Great had to deal with in Afghanistan
column17: something that settled populations have dealt with on their borders
column18: on their frontiers of nomadic people from time immemorial. And it's a very difficult kind of warfare for a conventional force to manage
column19: and Custer is trying to carry out orders that are not necessarily well thought out
column20: he's put in an impossible position at a time when he is least able to grapple with it personally. As a result
column21: he completely falls apart—in 1867 he was court marshalled
column22: quite rightly
column23: and convicted quite rightly
column24: and again it reflects this amazing confluence of personal disaster
column25: of political crisis in the nation
column26: and of these great crises that are taking place on the Great Plains as a result of the U.S.'s expansion into this space that has been dominated by other peoples for so long.

column1: CWBR: What were the expectations of plains Indians? Well the high plains Indians especially
column2: who were used to military conquest--their expectation was to win militarily and not necessarily acquiesce to the United States offers of land and settlement?

column1: Stiles: This is something we have to remember is that the United States had been a presence in the West
column2: the trans-Mississippi West since the time of Lewis and Clark
column3: and the U.S. had a sort of contractual relationship
column4: a relationship of alliance and partnership
column5: rather than domination. So
column6: for example
column7: the Lakotas in the northern plains they had actually
column8: at various points
column9: been allies with the United States as the U.S. dealt with other nations. They had been enemies and allies
column10: they had confronted I don't deal with much in the book
column11: but extremely important
column12: is the war on the northern plains that resulted from the so called Sioux uprising in Minnesota during the Civil War. General Alfred Sully led a column
column13: including a number confederate prisoners of war who were given the option of serving in the U.S. Amy in the West--What's the term? galvanized Confederates who'd been converted into Union soldier--and led this destructive column through the West; and
column14: yet what happened after that campaign is that it was followed by Red Cloud's War where there were some fights including the famous the so-called Fetterman Massacre
column15: and there were some Army victories
column16: some Indian victories
column17: and the U.S. government decided to ratify this Sioux on the northern plains. So rather than a story of constant displacement and constant defeat--you know we tend think of the U.S. of advancing west and defeating and displacing various Indian nations--a kind of march of defeat for the Indian nations--the Sioux had seen ups and downs
column18: they'd seen victories and defeats followed by the Fort Laramie Treaty
column19: which basically ratified their power on the northern plains. It granted them this huge reservation and then a larger area that was called ""unseated Sioux territory
column20: which included a big disputed zone in their wars with Crows and others to the West. And then they accepted these treaty goods and treaty rations that were given to them
column21: that the U.S. saw as a show of the U.S.'s superior position
column22: that they were ceding to U.S. authority and they have these agency posts in their territory and they come in and accept these rations. Whereas I think the Sioux were seeing this as a part of their ongoing contractual relationship with the U.S. If anything it was more resembling the tribute that they forced some of their militarily weaker neighbors over time. They certainly didn't see themselves as a defeated and subordinate people. And so this is very different from the High Plains people
column23: of the central plains
column24: who were confronting US power and suffering defeats much more directly.

column1: What leads to the great Sioux War of 1876 and '77
column2: is not necessarily a sense of grievance by the Sioux they were upset by many things
column3: particularly the invasion of miners into the Black Hills
column4: but the fact that they had a sense of power--1873
column5: for example
column6: was climax of their generations long war with the Pawnees. They wiped out the last major Pawnee buffalo hunting party on the Great Plains. So they are embroiled in a series of wars
column7: which they are winning at the time when they face the great confrontation with the U.S.; and that's very important to remember
column8: that they were not feeling weak
column9: they were feeling strong when Custer advanced to his death.

column2: I appreciate you taking the time to chat with us about your most recent work: Custer's Trials: A Life on the Frontier of the New America.
Tom Summer 2016 2016-08-01 Interview Knopf ""

column1:
5284 978-1-4000-4200-5 $30.00 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
We Have the War Upon Us: The Onset of the Civil War
column2: December 1860-April 1861		Cooper
column3: William J.			"<h3>Interview with William J. Cooper
column4: Boyd Professor of History at Louisiana State University

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview

column2: I’m discussing with Professor William J. Cooper
column3: Jr.
column4: his newly-published <i>We Have the War Upon Us: The Onset of the Civil War
column5: December 1860-April 1861. Professor Cooper
column6: thank you for joining us today.

column1: CWBR: You examine the failure of the Democratic National Convention when it met in Charleston as a signal of the splintering of the Democratic Party. Surely the Democrats understood what their failure meant nationally; why couldn’t northern and southern Democrats compromise to oppose the Republicans who faced a much easier task in an election against a broken Democratic Party?

column2: Jr. (WJC): Well the Democratic Party had two problems. The first problem was Stephen A. Douglas who was an anathema to the southerners
column3: and the southerners were determined to stop him.  They thought they had a good chance to do so because of the two-thirds rule requiring two-thirds of the delegates to nominate a candidate.  Moreover
column4: the more moderate southern leaders like Jefferson Davis
column5: for example
column6: wanted the convention to move toward nominations before a platform. They wanted to get a candidate in place and then get a platform
column7: but the more radical southerners wanted a platform first because they wanted to force Douglas to come towards them or to beat Douglas at his own game.  And those people led by William Lowndes Yancey of Alabama forced through a platform regarding slavery in the territories that the Douglas people could not and would not accept.  Though the platform committee voted for that platform
column8: or that plank
column9: because the vote was by states.  Once the radical southerners pressed the others on the platform committee went along with them.  But when it went before the full convention it was voted down
column10: and at that point Yancey lead a walk-out.  Now most scholars don’t think Yancey wanted to break up the Democratic Party
column11: that he wanted to come back as a kind of hero
column12: a king maker.  Well he didn’t come back
column13: and other southern states that walked out with him didn’t come back because they weren’t asked to do so.  The Douglas people in Charleston thought that they could get him nominated but the ruling was made by the convention chair that it took two-thirds of all the delegates
column14: not just those remaining; thus they didn’t get what they wanted and the convention adjourned
column15: agreeing to meet again in Baltimore. It met and it was the same difficulty even compounded because some of the southern states sent old delegations and some sent new delegations. The party came apart. It came apart both on the southern antipathy to Douglas and on radical southern demands that northerners wouldn’t accept.

column2: but you state that “Fire-eaters considered [at one point] the Palmetto State their citadel
column3: the stronghold where they exercised enormous influence.” How and why did South Carolina ascend to this status instead of any of the other Deep South states?

column1: (WJC): I’ll do the best I can with that. That’s a vexing question that numerous historians have addressed
column2: and none have come to a conclusion that satisfies more than a handful of individuals.  Why South Carolina became so radical and stayed so radical so long is very hard to understand.  The political organization of the state which gave great power to the legislature and still required property qualifications to sit in it
column3: the absence of a two-party system which was chiefly due to John C. Calhoun’s dominance of the state during the formative period of the Democratic and Whig Parties
column4: the overwhelming domination of the state by large planters
column5: the fact that the state had been majority black for so long
column6: all of these come together.  And of course South Carolina was a nullifying state in the 1830s and wanted to secede in 1850
column7: but even the radicals of the state decided that someone needed to go first because they had been alone once before yet they could not get anybody else to go out so secession in South Carolina came apart.  In 1860 they still wanted someone to go out first-most of them-but they couldn’t get anybody to take that step.  But when they thought they got promises that some would follow especially Georgia
column8: the radicals in the legislature in the state succeeded in getting the state to go out.  It’s very difficult to understand because amongst the chief radicals were some of the richest people in America: the rice and Sea Island cotton planters on both sides of Charleston on the sea coast
column9: people who were absolutely vulnerable if any military conflict should occur.  And when that did occur one of the first places that fell to Union forces was around Beaufort
column10: South Carolina
column11: a radical bastion and a center of very wealthy planters. My answer is not very satisfactory because I don’t think a satisfactory answer exists at this point.

column1: CWBR: It seems that the Radicals-we mentioned those fire-eaters in the South
column2: but also those hard-liner Republicans in the North- that they are the ones that scooped up any potential undecided support during the secession crisis.  Why couldn’t the Border Conservatives
column3: as you call them
column4: garner more support for compromise and patience during the secession crisis?

column1: (WJC): The Border Conservatives failed because they failed to move the leadership of the Republican Party. And I spend a lot of time in this book talking about the struggle of Border Conservatives. They had an ally in the Republican Party
column2: William Henry Seward.  I’m persuaded that Seward wanted to make a deal
column3: that he would have made a deal had it been within his power
column4: but Lincoln said no and Seward pushed Lincoln as far as he thought he could.  He did urge Lincoln to adopt a more conservative
column5: more conciliatory course
column6: even down to Fort Sumter when he wanted Lincoln to remove the federal garrison.  But he never got too far in front of Lincoln
column7: he never wanted to alienate Lincoln.  The failure of the Border Conservatives to convince Lincoln that he needed to move toward their position guaranteed that the Republican Party would not move.  Nothing would have moved the Republican hard-liners but
column8: if Lincoln had moved
column9: the great center of the party would have followed him. I am persuaded of that.

column2: at times like politics got away from the political giants of the day
column3: specifically William Seward and Jefferson Davis
column4: who preached caution and union.  How did the people on the ground
column5: the hard-liner Republicans and the Fire-eaters successfully achieve the plunge into secession and war?

column1: (WJC): Well let’s go to the South first. Secession followed the election of Lincoln. Fire-eaters had been preaching secession to break up the Union
column2: for so long
column3: but they advocated a doctrine that asked southerners to step into the unknown
column4: to take a giant step away from something they knew into something that they didn’t know.  Now the fire-eaters proclaimed that this was going to be the political Garden of Eden
column5: the land of milk and honey.  But southerners weren’t sure and southerners were loyal Americans; they embraced the United States.  They looked to the great American heroes as their own heroes.  Leaving the country
column6: leaving the United States was not a step they would take easily but with Republicans in charge
column7: now the fire-eaters ask: what’s going to happen with the Republican administration?  So now you’ve got the unknown of secession matched with the unknown of what a Republican would do.  What men like Jefferson Davis wanted was some signal from the Republicans that they were going to respect what a person like him thought of as southern rights.  And that meant to say that the southerners had a constitutional right
column8: not only to own slaves in Mississippi
column9: but a constitutional right to share in the national territory
column10: in the national property .  Davis didn’t demand a slave code for the territories but he did demand a constitutional right.  He was quite willing-and men like him were quite willing-to make compromises on territorial alignments
column11: but on the fundamental right he wanted Republican acquiescence or recognition.  He thought that if he had that he could go back to Mississippi and to the rest of the South and say: look
column12: they recognize our rights.  When he couldn’t get that
column13: the fire- eaters had him in a box; if he wanted to retain
column14: if men like him wanted to retain
column15: any power and prestige in their states they were forced to go in that direction.  Likewise
column16: in the North
column17: the hardline Republicans said: we will never make any deals
column18: we will never make any compromise.  While their number was a minority within their party
column19: the president- elect
column20: the man who was to be the leader of their party
column21: stood with them on that particular issue.  We must remember that
column22: despite the fire-eaters in the South and the hard-liners in the North
column23: a large pro-compromise element did exist and that group included northerners and southerners
column24: anti-slave and pro-slave alike who sought to maintain the Union despite sectional differences. In my judgment Lincoln’s failure in this crisis was that he never said anything publicly about what he would and wouldn’t do.  He never stood up and told southerners that he would be president of all Americans
column25: that he and they were different but also alike. Lincoln had an enormous gift for fitting political language and one can imagine the kind of statement he would have made. It might very well have quieted some of the southern concern but he didn’t’ do it.

column2: you discuss a shift in Lincoln’s approach to compromise
column3: noting that he supported the Compromise of 1850 publicly but within a decade of that support
column4: “Lincoln unequivocally opposed compromise even as the Union came apart.” What accounts for this adjustment in his viewpoint?

column1: (WJC): Well I think that there are two things. This is a general position on Lincoln and compromise
column2: but I think you have to be a little more specific and look at Lincoln at this particular instance between his election and his taking office
column3: why he was so adamantly opposed then.  And I think that there are three reasons
column4: and I talk about them in my book at some length.  First
column5: he was ignorant of the South; he had no southern political friends
column6: really no southern friends of any kind except a few in Kentucky.  He didn’t know anything about the Deep South politics; also he didn’t understand the society of the Deep South.  I don’t think he had any recognition of how deeply slavery had become embedded
column7: how white southerners
column8: no matter whether they thought slavery was good or bad
column9: were committed to it.  Committed to their slave society
column10: they wanted no interference with it.  They feared that he was going to interfere with them.  I don’t believe he stopped to think
column11: when he said this country can’t continue half-slave and half-free
column12: how southerners might react when he says something like that.   Second
column13: Lincoln approached this whole problem as a Republican partisan
column14: I think he had just become party leader.  He knew Seward
column15: for example
column16: had more national stature than he did even after his election
column17: and he knew that many Republicans still looked to Seward.  He wanted to establish himself as the party leader.  He was very concerned about what he saw as the fragility of the Republican coalition
column18: that he was the first elected Republican president and he feared that if he moved toward conciliation
column19: toward any serious compromise
column20: that he would alienate the hard-liners
column21: the left wing of his party
column22: who might bolt.  In contrast
column23: Seward who had been a spokesman for antislavery politics for a decade
column24: first as a Whig
column25: then as a Republican
column26: had a standing to face those people head-on if they came after him
column27: and he suspected that they would. But where would they go if the most radical bolted?  He thought that the Republican Party needed to expand
column28: and he was looking to those conservatives in the border states to build a national Republican Party based on Union.  Now
column29: Lincoln eventually came to the Union party idea during the war
column30: but before war he never saw the Republican Party expanding beyond its initial boundaries.  He did not come to this crisis as the president-elect of a country but as the leader of a party and a party that had always been in opposition.  But there was even a third factor.  Lincoln
column32: was more viscerally anti-slave than Seward.  Yet
