column33: he was no abolitionist; he even supported the original Thirteenth Amendment which would have made it practically impossible to touch slavery in the states.  As a constitutionalist
column34: he couldn’t do otherwise because he believed the constitution sanctioned slavery in the states
column35: but by emphasizing the territories and by saying never again in any territory he could get around that constitutional barricade and still hold to his constitutional scruples.  He saw the future in territories.  In his view stopping slavery in the territories stopped slavery in the future.  He also claimed that he was simply carrying out the legacy of the founding fathers.  In his famous Cooper Union address back in February 1860
column36: he focused on the signers of the Constitution and he said that these men really intended for an antislavery America and somehow that legacy had been turned in the wrong direction.   But although Lincoln in the speech talked about what he called the facts
column37: the founding fathers bequeathed a much more complicated legacy. With every president from Washington to Monroe new territories permitting slavery were added to the Union or organized

column1: CWBR: You mentioned Seward’s national recognition and leadership in the formation of the Republican Party
column2: being one of the premier Whigs before that.  In those weeks after the election
column3: did Seward want to appear as the savior of the Union for his own self-fulfilling purposes or did he simply not trust Lincoln to serve the country adequately?

column1: (WJC): I don’t think he knew enough about Lincoln to know what to think about Lincoln. I think most Republicans were in that position except those who were very close to Lincoln in Illinois. Lincoln had a fairly small circle
column2: his circle of intimates was almost closed.  And Seward wasn’t the only Republican concerned about what Lincoln would do.  I think he did have concerns about Lincoln but I think Seward also
column3: early on
column4: decided that the Union was in great danger and something had to be done to pacify the South in terms of convincing southerners that the Republicans weren’t out to get them.  And that’s what he wanted to do
column5: but as I said a few minutes back
column6: he was never willing to cross Lincoln.  Lincoln had bested Seward for the nomination and had been elected.  You can understand Lincoln’s thinking: if I go along with Seward
column7: it’s going to look like I’m Seward’s man
column8: and it’s going to be Seward’s presidency rather than mine.  I’ve got to establish myself and put myself in the front.  And he did that; he certainly did that in December of 1860 when after Thurlow Weed
column9: Seward’s political ally
column10: went to Illinois hoping to get Lincoln’s agreement on things he and Seward wanted. Weed failed.

column1: CWBR: James Buchanan has time and again faced severe criticism for his failure to prevent secession and his seemingly passive stance in the face of southern attacks on federal property. But
column2: I wonder
column3: how tough was the task that he faced and might historians have judged too harshly what he did not do (hold the Deep South in the Union) while failing to commend him for halting the spread of secession and preventing open conflict?

column1: (WJC): Well I don’t think Buchanan could have done much to halt the spread of secession. Yet
column2: he did have a great deal to do with keeping the flag flying at Fort Sumter and Fort Pickens that gave Lincoln levers that Lincoln wouldn’t have had otherwise.  Tthere was enormous pressure on Buchanan to give up both of them
column3: and he held his ground in both.  I think he deserves a good deal of credit in terms of maintaining a position that his successor could use if his successor chose to.  What Buchanan would have done if he had ever faced what Lincoln faced at Fort Sumter: Anderson’s saying he needed to come out
column4: that he was running out of supplies.  I think he would have withdrawn Anderson under those circumstances because his agreement with Anderson was if Anderson asked for help he would send help
column5: Anderson didn’t ask for help in early March of 1861.  He said he couldn’t be successfully reinforced.  In terms of stopping secession there was very little Buchanan could do.  You may say
column6: well he should have done what Andrew Jackson did.  Well remember Andrew Jackson did two things.  One
column7: he did raise the threat of the sword but he also worked with Congress to get a compromise to diffuse the situation.  Buchanan had no chance with Congress
column8: the Republicans wouldn’t pay him any mind whatever.  He had even lost his influence with the southern Democrats over Fort Sumter.  So by January the first he was in Congress a dead letter practically speaking
column9: with both Republicans and southern Democrats.  Then
column10: he faced a much more difficult situation than Jackson did.  Jackson had one state where Buchanan had one state going out and several other states
column11: all the way west to Texas saying we’re all going out if you do anything. So he calculated that if he took any overt act that would encourage secession more than if he didn’t take any overt act. Now perhaps taking an overt act would have slowed it down; we can’t know that but that was the calculation he made and in my mind to compare him and Jackson is really like comparing apples and oranges.

column2: Williamson Cobb
column3: left his post in Washington to return home
column4: he writes the Republican Party: “you can still this storm before the sun shall set to-day.”  Is that correct
column5: and how?

column1: (WJC): Well he said that in a speech in the House of Representatives. If the Republicans would have agreed to a serious compromise
column2: that would have killed secession.  I mean Cobb believed that; I certainly believe that; Jefferson Davis believed that
column3: Robert Toombs (who didn’t want any compromise) believed that.  It’s hard to see
column4: in a state like Georgia where the vote was so close anyway
column5: that if serious compromise had been reached that Georgia would have gone out.  Even though South Carolina had gone out
column6: Georgia was the bridge to the rest of the Deep South.  However
column7: the same deal that started secession in Georgia would have done likewise farther west.  In sum
column8: I think Cobb was right.

column2: just as you begin it
column3: with a look at John J. Crittenden
column4: the political heir-apparent to Henry Clay.  While Clay became known as the Great Compromiser or Great Pacificator
column5: Crittenden failed to hold the nation together. Does this signal failure on Crittenden’s part or is he symbolic of the inability to compromise after Lincoln’s election?

column1: (WJC): I think that Crittenden did all that Crittenden could do. He could not move Lincoln; he could not move the Republicans. The Republican Party was not going to break with Lincoln. He was the first elected Republican. The Republicans had never had the White House before and they were going to stand united behind that man if they could. And even Seward
column2: who wanted to go toward Crittenden wasn’t going to break with Lincoln. They were going to keep a united party. It was not Crittenden’s fault as one hard-liner Republican said and I quote him: “we couldn’t stand firm until people like Clay and Webster were gone.” Crittenden just couldn’t move the people he had to move.
I appreciate you taking the time to sit and discuss your most recent work
column3: <i>We have the War Upon Us: The Onset of the Civil War
column4:
December 1860-April 1861.

" Buman
column5: Nathan Fall 2012 2012-11-01 Interview Knopf ""

column1:
4053 9780807133712 $24.95 hardcover CWBR Author Interview:
Jefferson Davis and the Civil War Era Cooper
column2: William J.
column3: Jr.			"<h3>Interview with William J. Cooper
column4: Jr.

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): You begin your latest book with the phrase ""Jefferson Davis by William Cooper
column2: once again
column3: of course referring to your 2000 biography ""Jefferson Davis
column4: American.""  But why Jefferson Davis in the first place
column5: what lead you to study this man?

column2: Jr. (WJC): I've been interested in Davis for a long time. When I was a senior in college
column3: I wrote my senior thesis on the Confederate strategy at the end of the war in the West from Atlanta to Bentonville
column4: and of course Davis was a major character
column5: and that and I went to graduate school and I thought about Jefferson Davis and my advisor told me that Davis was too complicated for a graduate student to write a biography about
column6: but I could pick a portion of his life like ""Jefferson Davis
column7: Secretary of War.""  This seemed to me to be about as dull as you could get.  So I went in a totally different direction
column8: and I ended up writing about antebellum politics.  But Davis was interesting to me and always in my mind.  Nobody ever wrote the biography of Davis that everyone turned to.  I became a dean in the 1980s and when I finished that I was looking around and I said to myself
column9: ""This is the time.  If you are ever going to give it a shot
column10: give it a shot."" And so I decided to try it. At that time the Jefferson Davis Papers project at Rice University was made open to me-- earlier in my career they had a less than open door policy to let people come in. And so I decided to take a shot at it.

column1: CWBR: This collection of essays focuses sharply on Davis the politician and Davis as the commander-in-chief of the Confederate States of America. And you characterize Davis as the ""consummate antebellum politician
column2: a man who intimately understood politics as ""a means to an end
column3: and he worked to achieve his goals through deliberation and compromise. Was Davis representative of the ordinary southern politician? How did he differ from his colleagues?

column1: WJC: I don't think he did differ from his successful colleagues. I could rattle you off a half dozen more names
column2: but Davis has generally been depicted as a person who was not a politician; a man who was the antithesis of the politician
column3: and this depiction did not simply deal with the Confederate States of America
column4: though it centered on his role as president.  But before that he was most often characterized in the historiography as a person who was stiff-necked
column5: who was unbending
column6: who as his wife said
column7: ""didn't know the arts of a politician and wouldn't practice them if he knew them.""  And my research indicated to me that he was a very different kind of person.   I don't think he was that kind of stiff-necked
column8: unbending man; I think he was a professional politician and he was really good at what he did.

column1: CWBR: Keeping in the vein of politics here
column2: you say in this book
column3: definitely
column4: Davis played a critical role in the opposition of the Compromise of 1850
column5: yet as you also note
column6: this didn't mean that Davis opposed compromise
column7: per se. Why did he oppose the plan from 1850? And what would he have preferred?

column1: WJC: Well he opposed the plan for 1850 chiefly because of California. Bringing in California as a free state would end the balance in the Senate. There would be 16 free states rather than 15
column2: and the slave states would remain at 15.  He saw southern power in the Senate as absolutely critical in maintaining southern power in the nation.  And he followed Calhoun.  Calhoun believed that you had to have political power to maintain your position in the United States even if your position was based on views of the constitution.  So Davis believed that California coming in would disrupt the balance and would weaken southern power.  He also objected because California was being handled a way differently from any preceding territory becoming a state.  It was done so quickly with no territorial phase
column3: which would eliminate any possibility for Southerners to participate in its settlement. That’s why he opposed the Compromise of 1850 so desperately.

column1: What he preferred and what he had supported and voted for in 1848 was to extend the Missouri Compromise line.  He also voted in 1848 for the proposal that would turn the question of slavery and the territories of to the federal judiciary—the so-called Clayton proposal
column2: which like the Missouri Compromise extension
column3: passed the Senate
column4: but failed in the House.  He supported both of those
column5: because he thought those were dividing the question
column6: giving the South a fair chance;  whereas he thought the Compromise of 1850
column7: with California as the headlight
column8: didn't give the South a chance and broke equality.

column1: CWBR: Davis urged caution during the secession crisis and he didn't support immediate secession. Did southerners ever question Davis's suitability for the Confederate presidency based on his support—albeit qualified—of the Union?

column2: not really I don't think.  There may have been a few radicals who thought Davis had been too conservative
column3: but not for most Southerners.  He was not like Alexander Stephens
column4: who had actually opposed secession at the Georgia secession convention.  Once it became clear that Mississippi was down the road to secession
column5: Davis said fine.  When he was in Jackson
column6: in November 1860 at the meeting of the congressional delegation for the governor to make his decision on how to approach the legislature and the crisis
column7: Davis opposed immediate action and he told the governor this.  But when Davis left that meeting to go to Washington
column8: he made it very clear that what Mississippi decided was where he would go.  When he first got to Washington in December
column9: he was very dismayed and very depressed and didn't think there was any chance that any kind of compromise
column10: and then his spirits lifted a bit at mid-month. As he said
column11: he didn't really give up on the Union
column12: until the failure of the Committee of Thirteen in the Senate.  But he was not looked upon as somebody who had really opposed secession
column13: like Alexander Stephens.  He was looked upon as a moderate
column14: and that was terrifically important
column15: especially to people in the Upper South states. People in states like Virginia had informed some of those who were going out that they needed to put in a moderate man like Davis.

column1: CWBR: Now you certainly make clear too that Davis has held firm loyalties to the Union. Yet you also note that early on in the war Davis wanted to make
column2: ""the enemy know firsthand that the sting of war.""  How would you describe Davis's feelings toward northerners
column3: and toward bringing the war to them?  And then
column4: how did Davis's outlook harden over the course of the war years?

column2: what Davis wanted was for the Confederacy to be left alone
column3: but he didn't really think that was going to happen.  He didn't believe the North would let the South go without a struggle
column4: and he foresaw a very long and difficult struggle.  At the same time
column5: I don't think Davis had any enmity toward Northerners
column6: per se. He began to have a real antipathy toward the Lincoln administration because of what he saw as a harsh war policy. Confederate territory came into Union hands in 1861 and from then on every month
column7: every week almost
column8: more and more fell.  What he saw was not only Union armies pushing Confederate armies back or overrunning Confederate forces
column9: but he saw buildings burned
column10: he saw people put on the road as refugees
column11: he saw a war against civilians.  And then
column12: of course
column13: when the Union army began to employ blacks that
column14: in the South
column15: that raised a specter that haunted Southerners for generations—the idea of race war. He saw the Emancipation Proclamation as an utterly brutal act that endangered southern civilians
column16: particularly women and children.  By 1862
column17: when the South had been invaded
column18: and he saw what he called this brutality
column19: and what modern historians call the hard War
column20: he wanted the North defeated.  He wanted northern civilians to know what they were perpetrating on the South
column21: and the only reason northern civilians didn't feel it was because he didn't have the wherewithal to make them feel it.

column1: You argue in this book that Davis saw the fight for the Confederacy as a ""holy mission."" The Union had failed and so the principles of 1776 had to be secured through a “revolution against politics"" as George Rable has put it. Did Jefferson Davis foresee an eventual return to a more traditional form of politics or would fealty to the Confederacy always amount to a ""holy mission"" even after independence had been gained?
WJC: I can't answer that. His great goal was to have an independent Confederacy. If the Confederacy had in fact won its independence
column2: none of us knows what would have happened.  I simply can't answer that question
column3: but he certainly believed that as long as the Confederacy was in balance that the old politics had to disappear.

column1: CWBR: You argue that as the conflict progressed
column2: political concerns dominated Davis's strategic thinking
column3: again linking the idea of politics and war aims. To what extent did these concerns about politics hamper the Confederate war effort?

column1: WJC: I don't think that he got more concerned about the political aspects of the war as the war progressed. I think that was in the forefront from the very beginning. I argue that Fort Sumter was his first great political strategic act
column2: because Fort Sumter was a political act more than a military act in my judgment.  I think if Davis never had to concern himself with politics he might have done things differently.  But in some ways I think that’s a false question
column3: because he himself said there was no way to separate the two.  He existed in a world in which politics had to play a part.  Probably if politics wasn't involved at all
column4: you could say well he may have jettisoned the Trans-Mississippi early on.  He did say that it was a tough job to have politics and war at the same time.  Maybe he would have concentrated more on other issues as some of his critics said he should have done
column5: but I'm not sure. That’s a hard question to answer.

column2: too
column3: though that one of the problems that Davis faced was that he felt he had to keep troops throughout the Confederacy.

column2: he did.

column1: CWBR: And he had to do that
column2: in your opinion
column3: to maintain the political balance?

column1: WJC: He had to do that to maintain loyalty. Davis knew there was no Confederate nationalism in 1861. He said on one occasion that Confederate nationalism was being created in the cauldron of war. He looked to the Revolution. He saw American nationalism being created in the American Revolution. So he thought it could be done—that Confederate nationalism could be created. But it didn't exist when the war began in his own mind
column2: nor in mine.  He looked at portions of his country and he was told by politicians and by soldiers that in places like Arkansas
column3: for example
column4: that if he didn't defend Arkansas that it would probably leave the Confederacy.  And if Arkansas left who might be next?  As he explained to one of his generals
column5: he said
column6: ""When we give up on a place we not only lose territory
column7: we tend to lose men as well
column8: because their loyalty had not yet been secured by the Confederate government in his own eyes. And I think he was right.

column1: CWBR: You also discuss in here that Davis tended to be a micromanager.

WJC: Only in one sense. He was a micromanager in Richmond in directing the war. He had several Secretaries of War and all but one was quite able. But in dealing with his generals he was not a micromanager. I argue emphatically that he was not
column2: that in fact
column3: he should have managed them more carefully and more closely.  When he appointed a senior general to a major post he basically left that general alone.  He might make suggestions and he did make suggestions
column4: but he was not a micromanager of his generals in the field—not at all.  I would argue that Lincoln was much more of a micromanager over his generals in the field than Davis.  But in running the general war
column5: letters left the War Department with the Secretary of War’s signature and with the adjutant general's signature
column6: but all the decisions were Davis's decisions. You can look at the materials he looked at
column7: and as president the stuff that came across his desk you can see his endorsements.  Does a piece of artillery go here or there?  He liked to talk to his Secretaries of War and would have long conversations with them.  He wanted them to talk and he wanted their opinions
column8: but he made the final decision on almost everything. But once appointed somebody as a general—even people he didn't really like very much—he left them out there to do what they would do.

column1: CWBR: In Davis's estimation the Confederacy faced ""victory and liberty
column2: or defeat and enslavement.""  Did he ever talk of defeat and enslavement
column3: in particular
column4: in the postbellum years?

column1: WJC: No. During the war he did say we that if we lose
column2: we will become slaves of a horrible North.  After the war he kept very quiet about public questions
column3: particularly because he had been imprisoned and he had never become reconciled to the new order of things in terms
column4: for example
column5: trying to get his citizenship back.  He refused to do that.  He realized that if he made any comments about public matters
column6: it would only serve to hurt those he cared most about
column7: that is
column8: the South and the southern states.  So he didn't comment publicly on public matters.  In terms in what was happening inside the South
column9: privately he did feel that during the Reconstruction years that the South was basically in servitude.  He applauded the end of Reconstruction; he applauded the restoration of white supremacy.  And if you look at his public speeches in the 1880s
column10: he is not a fellow who is standing up bemoaning and lamenting.  He is looking at the future; he is talking about the future.  He says he is proud of his country.  I think that's because by 1880
column11: he saw that the South was back in the hands of those people that he thought should have control of it.  But during Reconstruction
column12: he never made a public comment about Reconstruction that I know of.

column1: CWBR: Now in sort of the same vein
column2: you state that Davis believed that Northerners
column3: especially the Republicans
column4: challenged the Americanness of the South.  Did Jefferson Davis see his ""holy crusade"" as a way to prove that Southerners were true Americans
column5: and in Davis’s mind was the true America lost with the death of the Confederacy?

column1: WJC: Davis saw the Confederacy as the true America without any question. He believed that. When the Confederacy failed
column2: as Davis said toward the end of his life
column3: many of his hopes and aspirations fell with it and his conviction about the future fell.  But then I think
column4: as I try to argue
column5: that by 1880 his view had changed; that he is much more optimistic
column6: that he applauds his country.  He says that all Southerners should be proud Americans. I think he thought by the end of Reconstruction that the America he had cherished was in fact gone
column7: but there was an America there that deserved southern loyalty and southern allegiance. And it had his loyal allegiance
column8: though he refused to do those things that would have given him his citizenship back
column9: because in his own mind he said
column10: ""those people didn't have the right to take it
column11: so I don't have the right to hold it; I'm not going to give them the opportunity to give it back to me or reject me."" You can say that was pretty stiff-necked
column12: but that was holding to a dogma he had about the legitimacy of what he had done in 1861
column13: its constitutionality
column14: and the correctness of it.  But if you look at the last public address he gave to a group of young men near his home on the Mississippi coast in the last years of his life
column15: he tells those young people that they need to look forward
column16: that they can't be trapped by the past and they should be proud of being Americans.

column1: CWBR: Now in your last essay you raise a really fascinating point about the creation of the Lost Cause ideology
column2: and you mention in there that the Lost Cause ideology was based in some part on omitting slavery from the history of the Civil War. What role did Davis play in creating that Lost Cause ideology and in trying to create it in part by omitting the idea of slavery from the causes of the Civil War?
I argue that Davis had a very important role to play.  He was not young enough
column3: as some of the men who historians normally point to as the real founders of the Lost Cause ideology
column4: but was an older man and older generation.  If you look at his memoir
column5: The Rise and Fall of the Confederate Government
column6: which was published in 1881
column7: he specifically says in it that slavery was not the cause of war.  If you look at the remarks he made in Montgomery in 1886
column8: which was the focus of that essay
column9: again there is nothing said about slavery. But if you contrast those remarks with the remarks he made in Montgomery in 1861
column10: when he was the provisional president
column11: in both his actual inaugural address and the remarks he made in public before that in Montgomery he put slavery at the very forefront of what was going on.  So I think he was absolutely in sync
column12: if you will
column13: with the general thrust of southern opinion at that time that was putting slavery and race out of it. The unity of North and South was coming
column14: was taking place and nobody wanted to talk about slavery
column15: and Southerners certainly didn't.

column2: Christopher Fall 2008 2008-11-01 Interview Louisiana State University Press ""

column1:
5864 9781594161919 $35.00 CWBR Author Interview:
To Raise Up a Nation: John Brown
column2: Frederick Douglass
column3: and the Making of a Free Country		King
column4: William S.			"<h3>Interview with William S. King
column5: independent scholar

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with William S. King
column2: an independent scholar making his debut in the Civil War Era
column3: and discuss his book
column4: <i>To Raise Up A Nation: John Brown
column5: Fredrick Douglass
column6: and The Making of A Free Country. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: William S. King (King): Well I'm glad to be here.
CWBR: So just to get us started
column2: describe to me what brought you to this subject
column3: not only recovering John Brown as a key player
column4: but then linking him to Fredrick Douglass and using these two lives to sort of tell this very large story of the era?

column2: well my links with John Brown go back to my earliest childhood.  I lived in that area of Kansas in the early 1950's with my parents and have active memories through the years
column3: of the battlefields there
column4: of John Brown's presence. More than that I would say in the development toward my journey to writing something like this was the impact of the Civil Rights Movement in the United States. In all of its phases
column5: and I feel that I have been very shaped and profoundly affected by it in all of its phases. I think to really to really put a point on it one of the impetuses of me developing toward was the killings that developed
column6: of course Medgar Evers
column7: Martin Luther King himself and Malcom X
column8: and many others that sacrificed their lives in a very American way in the sense that they were targeted individuals
column9: because they became outspoken and became effective. In this struggle that we've had in America we've had with race relations
column10: but my initial contact which moved me into this book was reading Du Bois’ John Brown and there one has a point meeting in the stone quarry outside Chambersburg between Fredrick Douglass and John Brown. Essentially all we know about it come from Douglass's narration of it in his Life and Times
column11: and of course he talked about it in a few other venues as well. At the end of his account Brown puts his arm around Douglass after two days of discussion
column12: and it was a comprehensive discussion
column13: when he says
column14: ""Come with me Douglass I will defend you with my life. When I strike the bees will begin to swarm and I shall want you to help me hive them."" But Douglass as we know refused to go and broke off with John Brown at that point
column15: and the rest transpired. I wanted to write that story and that led me to the other biographies of John Brown and Fredrick Douglass
column16: and his own writings (Life and Times)
column17: the works of Benjamin Quarrels
column18: and Phil Foner. That story gets repeated but is never elaborated on
column19: causing my reading to keep branching out. I was living in New York City at the time and I had the great fortune of getting laid off—this was back in the 1970s—and took myself to the New York library picking books I had noticed in my reading
column20: which were interesting and out of print coming from the nineteenth century volumes. I began reading in
column21: crucially
column22: in some people that had known Brown and had written biographies of him notably Richard Hinton
column23: Franklin Sanborn
column24: and James Redpath. I began
column25: not having been able to write anything yet
column26: but just gathering notes and experience
column27: which grew out. I had been familiar with the story the Civil War
column28: several years prior to this I had read the entire series by Bruce Catton on the Civil War.  That's basically what it was and I struggled with this writing for a number of years and kept reading. That is where it began its development
column29: from that specific incident in the stone quarry outside Chambersburg.

column1: CWBR: It sounds like part of what drew you to the story of Brown was this (and the link that would obviously connect him to much later figures you mentioned Dr. King and Medgar Evers)
column2: is this notion of sacrifice and then is that sort of the link that then led you to branch out and explore the myriad instances of sacrifice--many of them nameless—by these people that are soldiers and commanders?

column1: King: I think that’s really the crux of it
column2: although I don’t overtly state that
column3: but I think that's what moved me through this.  And it's a process of revelation too
column4: because there is so much that's obscure about this aspect of antebellum period because there's such contradictory views on John Brown and the understanding of what he did is very ill thought-out in most
column5: if not all regards. The relationship of Douglass and Brown
column6: which is crucial to understand this whole era
column7: has not been a source to study for everybody.  They leave it at the brief statements that Douglass makes
column8: and Brown didn't make any
column9: then leave it at that. But there's a whole area that can be open up to this portal
column10: as it were.

column1: CWBR: Do you think that part of how Brown has been misunderstood is basically then what sort of prevents people from exploring the relationship between Brown and Douglass? You mention early in the book that Brown has sort of become this caricature; he's sort of eternally the depiction in the Tragic Prelude that hangs in the Kansas state house
column2: of this larger than life kind of crazy man. How does that prevent us from exploring his relationship with Douglass?

column1: King: Well in the matters that pertain to the Civil War his story by in large has not really had a comprehensive grasp of the nature in the meaning of American slavery. The fact that it is often a peripheral discussion in the matters of the civil war
column2: even a great work like Bruce Catton's volumes. I recall him saying in his book The Coming Fury
column3: which was on the precursor to the Civil War
column4: the 1850's
column5: he really devotes one line to state of the slaves and their stake in the issue saying
column6: ""the mute and luckless negro."" That's his phrase and he really doesn't develop a view of slavery or of the agencies blacks really had
column7: both enslaved and free
column8: in bringing on that war and in its resolution. I find that many historians
column9: and my latest experience was with David Blight
column10: a professor at Yale University who is a magnificent scholar on the Civil War as you know
column11: I just happened to take myself to the internet and watched his twenty-two part lecture series of an hour each on the Civil War. He devotes a whole chapter to John Brown
column12: but is appallingly miserable in his discussion of Brown as a historical figure. Partly that is because they haven't felt that they really had to think through what he did and they’re deriving all their information from sources that really had a negative view about him and haven't penetrated for several reasons the meaning of Harpers Ferry. In one of them they sort of cap the whole thing on this notion that he was trying to raise a slave insurrection there of significant proportions
column13: which I show in the book was not the case at all
column14: and certainly it would have defeated all efforts he was trying to accomplish there if he had been able to do that
column15: which is just fantastical. I just find that they haven't thought it through
column16: which is a great failing of scholarship because there is plenty of material available. Notably
column17: in Brown's on words
column18: if you really study them if you get away from this notions of him being a mono-maniac who was mad and was a bloodthirsty
column19: cold blooded killer
column20: which he wasn't. You have to see what he was grappling with and the difficulties presented. One of the things I was able to bring out was that he was definitely trying to foreshorten what he saw to be the terrible war that did come. He saw that
column21: and it wasn’t a fantastical
column22: God-driven apparition
column23: he really understood his time
column24: and the potentials that war would unleash. Although there is magnificent work done
column25: I don’t think scholars have really gotten to the root of that war.

column2: you have
column3: as I understand as your saying
column4: when you're trying to decide how to evaluate Brown
column5: and of course evaluating Brown sort of a matter of deciding which of his words to weigh his actions against. It seems that a lot of historians have weighed his state of mind against his words where he says
column6: oh I would like to seize the armory and start and insurrection. So they have decided that weighed against those goals
column7: Brown must have been a failure and basically
column8: as I understand
column9: what you're saying is historians should take more seriously when he writes about the moral impetus slavery and how very seriously he took that? Since for him the political issue couldn’t be divorced from the moral issue
column10: so then the evaluation of what he's doing shouldn't be either?

column2: but I think they still miss the point in terms of what he was trying to accomplish at Harpers Ferry. It was not a slave insurrection in the terms it's been conceived in most commentary. His son
column3: who's mentioned in the book
column4: had an interesting remark saying that all writers had failed to appreciate that his father was trying to bring about the split in the Union. That was his point of striking at Harpers Ferry. It was not an irrational
column5: ill thought-out thing. He was trying to topple the very foundation of the political structure of the Union which at that time had a huge slavery component
column6: and was undermining the foundations of the republic as he saw. He was kicking the legs out from under the stool.

column1: CWBR: That is very interesting about the perspective that you bring because John Brown is not completely alone in this of course. One thing I found very interesting about the book is that you're always keeping track of the more familiar Civil War narrative
column2: but as the same time this is a story that is often told from the perspective of so-called extremists. You're highlighting the grassroots narratives that are essentially the opposite of those examined by our last guest
column3: Rachel Sheldon
column4: who wrote about this sort of “Washington bubble
column5: ” the fact that a lot of these politicians in Washington
column6: they do conceive of these things as completely political issues with political solutions and they're really surprised by secssion and by the ferocity of the war. In many ways the war is a rejection of them and we're seeing that here too. We're seeing fire-eaters seceding against Lincoln's initial expectations and we see Wendell Phillips echoing John Brown by welcoming secession
column7: because it's going to eventually seal abolition. It’s an intriguing juxtaposition
column8: the sort of a larger narrative that I think a lot of readers will find very familiar
column9: and then this sort of grassroots undercurrent. Would it be fair to say you think the grassroots as not only dragging the nation to the conflict
column10: which I think a lot of historians would agree with
column11: but that consistently the grassroots has to keep dragging laggard military planning and politics throughout the war?

column2: I agree 100% on that
column3: though their defeat is what compelled them to go in the direction the grassroots were pulling them. They weren't able to resolve this war in fact they were on the verge a number of times and people like to point this out that there could have been a Southern victory. It wasn't impossible
column4: or there could have been a victory that was achieved with an independence of sorts
column5: of course things would have continued after that
column6: that wouldn't resolved anything at all. It did come to a revolutionary peak. It was a complete transformation that fact that they accepted these regiments of black soldiers after the Emancipation Proclamation. It's not at all that they had a significant impact on the battlefield. They had an impact and at times an important one
column7: but the underlying fact was the whole direction and the meaning of a confederacy was undermined by that fact
column8: of these black men in arms who have been enslaved in the south. That utterly defeated slavery. It couldn't go on. They had then to throw in the towel even though they continued to fight on
column9: because it was a possibility even as late as Appomattox that there could have been a political compromise. That compromise didn't go away with defeat of the confederacy it reemerged as you note in a Reconstruction and the defeat of Reconstruction.

column1: CWBR: I actually would like to hear you talk about that a little bit more because so much of the second half of the book does show what you were just talking about
column2: how important it is that there are black Americans taking agency in their own emancipation
column3: and it doesn't come down to whether they win or lose individual engagements in which they're deployed
column4: it's the fact that they're there. But then the war does conclude with this disappointment of reconstruction.

column1: King: Well actually I mentioned David Blight earlier
column2: he had suggested the question of when did reconstruction end? He ends with the interesting idea that it never ended
column3: in other words that struggle within our history has continued down to today. It has a very different flavor and balance of forces and dynamic in each succeeding decade
column4: but it's continued to roll on
column5: never with complete resolution
column6: never yet with complete quality and acceptance of the black nation within the United States. We continue to see--I don't need to bring up examples--but Ferguson would seem coincidental
column7: but I don’t think it can be considered coincidental.

column1: CWBR: Do you think that kind of falling short
column2: or perhaps the fact that it never really does resolve in a positive fashion
column3: would lead you to say that [lack of resolution] has something to do with the fact that as powerful as this grassroots impetus can be
column4: it's also very tough to turn into a cohesive structure? Or would you say that really the problem is not that the grassroots impetus for freedom wasn't strong enough
column5: but that there's this continuing and ongoing grassroots kind of counter-revolution in American history that's always trying to push back?

column1: King: In history I would say it continually shows itself in new forms
column2: but also it needs new forms of defeat. There's no promised land and no resolution of struggle in human existence. We should hope
column3: we may be faced with it
column4: but that's extinction I think
column5: a society without history. History is the narration of the struggles. People who study this aren't always aware of it of course or some are
column6: but it is continually re-presented. The Civil War era is a classic case of that. People are stirred by images of combat and in who was there or what canteens they carried or armaments and all of that. I find that I had to pay attention to the strategic and tactical points of these battles. In the writing of it I wrote in terms of what I thought was essential in terms of its strategic importance. I brought to the foreground what had not been present in most histories of the Civil War which was the black presence in it
column7: and that black agency
column8: which was important to the resolution it had in that period. I quote Douglass on one of his magnificent speeches late in the war when they had a convention of blacks to consider he said
column9: ""Come let us reason together. You may not have such an opportunity in 100 years
column10: and that exactly what it took before there was that upsurge that we saw in the 50's and 60's (historians know the incidents and conditions).  Of course there were people and events prior to that
column11: but that grassroots movement come up again in a magnificent way. This is the essential American story
column12: that struggle.  I don’t believe it’s resolved in any one period. The struggle adjourned from the battlefields to other venues
column13: to the social venue and to the courts
column14: and the mass movements. We did neglect poor Fredrick Douglass and John Brown in this discussion
column15: that I think is the key which is why I subtitled the book <i>John Brown
column16: Frederick Douglass and The Making of a Free Country. That was a crucial relationship in our American narrative
column17: and it has been neglected. Of course there’s been recent scholarship The [James Oakes] book
column18: The Radical and The Republic. I based myself largely on Douglass's own writings in his journalism and his speeches which merits a lot more attention than it usually gets. I let him speak in a full sense on many occasions there are actual words and writings. It's interesting to think too that Douglass
column19: his house burnt down
column20: he lost all of his volumes of the North Star
column21: Frederick Douglass’ paper
column22: all of these papers and correspondence
column23: and he remarks in Life and Times if he said or did anything important it was in the period covered in the papers he lost in that fire which was 1845 through 1860. Yet most people study him after the civil war as a figure in that period.

column1: CWBR: Also the period where he knew John Brown.
King: Yes and that was going to be my next statement. All of his work on John brown
column2: so scholars haven't had the benefit of going directly to those papers. I was mentioning Phillip Foner's volumes the Life and Writings of Fredrick Douglass
column3: which is a 5 volume series. I don't know how many people read those
column4: but I've broke the backs of several of them
column5: bent the pages right out the book in find that it is a marvelous history of the period
column6: in the most comprehensive sense. It's not incidental or undeserving of study
column7: and I’m sure many scholars have gone to it
column8: but I don't think it's been quite appreciated to the extent that merits even yet. Brown and Douglass
column9: the meaning of their relationship the depth and contact I try to bring out in the book but the skeleton is based on Douglass's on writings.

column2: for taking your time to discuss your most recent work <i>To Raise Up a Nation: John Brown
column3: Fredrick Douglass
column4:
and The Making of A Free Country.
