No Quarter: The Battle of the Crater
column2: 1864		Slotkin
column3:
Richard "

Interview with Richard Slotkin

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview

column2: what led you to venture away from your three-volume study of the American frontier in <i>Gunfighter Nation
column3: The Fatal Environment
column4: and Regeneration Through Violence to examine the Battle of the Crater during the American Civil War?

column1: RS: Well I’ve always been interested in the civil war
column2: in fact my interest in American history in general really dates from two things: western movies when I was growing up and visits to civil war battlefields and for various reasons having to do with the way my education went that my career developed I wasn’t professionally licensed to write about the Civil War coming out of graduate school but I was so interested in it that it was always in the back of my mind as something I wanted to do. It’s really to me the water shed of American history. It’s the place where the United States turned into the unified nation-state that we’ve got the industrialized nation state and it’s also the moment when our perennial conflict between racialism and belief in equality comes to a head and the issue really takes a modern form.

column1: CWBR: What if any are some of the similar themes that you can trace across your frontier analysis and your look at the crater? It seems to me that you have in part shown a similar trend toward imagery through conflict to detail very differing frontiers.

column2: I see that I focused on the way in which
column3: let’s change this.  The key to the stuff I've done on the frontier is the idea that we've as a culture we've always seen violence as an essential means for producing the nation that we became and in the frontier what makes the United States ""American"" is the conflict with the Native Americans so there is always a racial dimension in there from the start and that combination of racism and violence has a different form but a parallel form in the Civil War where both sides are grappling with the question of: what is the relation between white and black?  Is it potentially a relationship of equality; that is are blacks Americans as well as whites? or is the United States a white man’s republic and that issue
column4: which in a sense begins on the Indian frontier
column5: comes home in the Civil War and it comes home with tremendous violence.  It’s my contention that the South secedes
column6: primarily
column7: to preserve white supremacy; slavery as an institution yes but as an institutional means for the preservation of white supremacy and the North doesn't get it in those terms.  The North thinks that slavery and white supremacy are two different issues and one of the things that happens is as the North confronts the end of slavery and particularly as the soldiers on the battle line confront the question: shall I fight for the end of slavery
column8: what succeeds slavery what comes after is the question of black equality.  And northern whites as well as southern whites are violently freaked out by that notion and the thing about the Battle of the Crater is: it ends with a massacre of black troops
column9: not only by Confederates who are storming the position the blacks are occupying
column10: but white troops on the northern side turn against the blacks and kill them as well.

column1: CWBR: So it’s almost like the Battle of the Crater and the American Civil War are sort of a frontier in itself towards that unified nation-state.
RS: Yeah it’s a frontier in a sort of symbolic sense
column2: the frontier between
column3: or the borderlands
column4: between two different Americas. In one of which white supremacy is assumed and slavery exists and the other slavery is removed and now you have to ask yourself: are you still in favor of white supremacy?

column1: CWBR: Well much of your narrative focuses on the experiences of the United States Colored Troops as you say
column2: and their enlistment in the war following emancipation in the proclamation. Do you think the enrollment of black soldiers altered the course of the war politically and/or ideologically and how so?

column1: RS: I think it altered it in both ways. First of all
column2: just in terms of numbers: I think the statistics show there were something like the North had a little bit over 2 million men under arms during the Civil War.  By the end of the war nearly 200
column3: 000 troops
column4: almost 10% were African American.  That’s very significant and is actually even more significant since their presence is weighted into the last two years of the war and although they don’t take a leading role in most major battles the Crater is an exception in that way.  Their role is absolutely essential; there is a whole corps of black troops in the army of the Potomac by the end of the war so just militarily their entirely significant.  Politically and socially
column5: war is about politics as well as about tactics and the fact that black troops could come marching through slave territory in the South had a tremendous impact on the stability of the slave-based economy even before northern success guaranteed the end of slavery.  And the political issue in the North
column6: by the 1864 election.  In the 1864 election
column7: the Democrats contest Lincoln’s administration with essentially a campaign for white supremacy
column8: arguing that to preserve white supremacy you have got to throw the Republicans out.  When Lincoln is endorsed by popular vote the possibility of something like a movement in the direction of racial equality gets a certain kind of credibility so the role politically
column9: socially
column10: and tactically is highly significant.

column1: CWBR: Well what did the blacks’ fighting experience itself accomplish for African Americans that simple freedom through emancipation could not?
RS: Well you have to remember that the right to serve in the militia or in the army is a fundamental civil right
column2: the famous Second Amendment has not only to do with fire arms
column3: ""the right to bear arms
column4: explicitly deals with the right serve in the national defense and until 1863 blacks were barred from militia service in all the northern states including Massachusetts.  And admission to that civil right has a tremendous symbolic and cultural impact.  Remember also that this is a country in which only men can vote and which the concept of manhood is almost indistinguishable from the concept of political equality or political rights.  So if you admit blacks to the civil right of service as men bearing arms the cultural impact is immense.  Even those blacks who never see combat have their sense of self and their sense of their possibilities of self turned around by military service.  I think studies have shown that blacks who served in the military tended to do better in Reconstruction than those who didn’t
column5: in part because they learned a certain skill as soldiers as well but the psychological impact I think is immense.

column1: CWBR: Well on page 328 you state that the mine explosions seem to be ""an extraordinary escalation in the murderous cruelty and destructive power of the federal war effort"" and Charles Royster has discussed the destructive nature of the war that made the conflict increasingly exhaustive for soldiers and civilians alike. How did the Battle of the Crater change warfare and the psyche or the psychological aspects of both armies?
RS: Well I think you have to put it on
column2: again
column3: a kind of continuum of developments.  The technology of violence gets upped by the Civil War and that’s what the crater explosion is part of.  The Confederate army invented the use of land mines during the Civil War.  A Confederate officer did that. That too was regarded by generals on both sides as un-chivalrous as an illegitimate means of making war
column4: almost as bad as the use of poison gas.  In fact
column5: the use of poison gas was actually proposed by several officers on both sides during the course of the Civil War.  Technology made it impossible but there it is.  Once you go to war the use of violence and violent means to win the war becomes primary over time but part of it takes again this technological form.  The other side of it
column6: the part that Royster talks about
column7: is the willingness to inflict pain and social destruction in order to obtain victory and that’s
column8: I think
column9: the bigger side of it technology is one thing but the will to kill the will to destroy is upped intensively the longer that a war goes on particularly where the issues are so fundamental as they are in the civil war.

column1: CWBR: Well why do you feel that the slaughter occurred to the degree that it did in the crater specifically the inter-racial violence. Is it confederates who are blaming black soldiers for the waning fortunes of the Confederacy or were they afraid that the social hierarchy based on white supremacy was crumbling or was it simpler than that?
RS: Well I think that both of those things are true. That is
column2: they do feel that the presence of blacks is really a major contribution to the overthrow of the Confederacy.  Remember
column3: not only because of the numbers that they are now facing but the fact that the presence of black troops carries with it the implied threat of a slave uprising behind the lines and the intense racial hatred is also a part of it.  But one of the most critical things which I point to in the book is the role of Confederate officials in establishing a framework of law and policy which encouraged racial murders.  The Confederacy had officially taken the position that blacks captured in arms would not be taken prisoner and that the white officers leading these troops should be treated under Confederate state law as persons inciting a slave insurrection which made them liable for the death penalty.  Now fear of Federal retaliation led the Confederacy to back off from officially enforcing the policy but as I quote in the book the Confederate Secretary of War said
column4: yeah we can't do this publicly
column5: but let's do it secretly. Let the killing be done red-handed on the field of battle rather than taking these guys prisoners and then executing them. So what you get then is a kind of uneven enforcement in which local officers and private soldiers even granted permission by their government to do these killings they either do the killings or they refuse to do the killings. So what I think is true here is that the Confederate government sets a frame in which racial murders are approved and soldiers in the heat of battle act in that framework and they regard their actions therefore as not only justified by their emotions but also justified by the policy of their government. In that way I parallel it with atrocities like the My Lai massacre in Vietnam. Some of it is on the troops in the field but there's also this framework of policy which makes murder and indiscriminant killing either inevitable or something that's approved.

column1: CWBR: well you suggest that the result of the battle of the crater may have lead to Lincoln’s failure in the November 1864 election that it could have been possible for him to…

column2: but what it produces is a really bad moment for his political campaign and the battle occurs at the end of July. In August he writes that famous memorandum which he requires his cabinet officers to sign without reading which commits them to win the war before the new president takes office on the grounds that the guy who beats Lincoln will have won on a peace platform that will end the war without victory. So Lincoln is pretty discouraged at that point and justifiably so by the failure of this big battle; other things as well but this was the big fight that had occurred right before that.

column1: CWBR: Do you think that Lincoln’s discouragement and concern over the election results
column2: was that more due to the mounting casualties of Grant's Virginia campaign or is that as a result of the increasing concerns over the enlistment and the use of black soldiers throughout the north in the civilian population?

column1: RS: in Lincoln’s case I think it's more the casualties. He had already taken into account the backlash against his recruitment of black troops and one of the things that I think is remarkable about this period is the uncompromising forthright way in which Lincoln defends the blacks and the use of black troops and even uses the fighting of black troops as an argument for ultimately granting them civil equality. There's a great speech which I quote in the book in which he contrasts the loyalty and service of black soldiers with the disloyalty and foot-dragging of white Democrats.
CWBR: David Blight has suggested that northern and southern whites erased African Americans from commemoration after the civil war leading into the 20th century
column2: focusing instead on the collaborative white memory of the conflict. Why do you think the efforts to the United States Colored Troops at the Battle of the Crater have been ignored and why do they posses as you say ""no monument to the memory of the African American troops who fought and died in the crater""?

column1: RS: Well Blight's book on that subject is absolutely correct. In the case of the crater battle we can actually see that in the speeches that were made during the reenactments that were developed in order to create a battlefield park
column2: that blacks are deliberately excluded from that.  And part of the reason is that at the time that these commemorative movements are really gaining strength and influence this is the Jim Crow era in southern politics
column3: when blacks who had gained civil rights in the post war period have those civil rights taken away by state action and this is when the regime of segregation and the elimination of blacks from the voting roles is taking place in the South and also the great waves of lynching in the South.  So it’s that sort of groundswell shift in southern politics that I think is part of that denial of a black role in the Battle of the Crater.  In a way though from the northern side it's consistent with what happened during the battle
column4: that is to say the northerners in the battle identified more with their fellow whites than with their black comrades in arms and that tendency is carried through in the postwar period as well.

column2: thank you so much for joining me in discussing your latest book: No quarter: The Battle of the Crater
column3:
1864.

" Buman
column4: Nathan Fall 2009 2009-11-01 Interview Random House ""

column1:
5737 978-1-4696-1076-4 $39.95 CWBR Author Interview:
Nature's Civil War: Common Soldiers and the Environment in 1862 Virginia Meier
column2: Kathryn Shively			"<h3>Interview with Kathryn Shively Meier
column3: Assistant Professor of History at Virginia Commonwealth University

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Kathryn Shively Meier
column2: an Assistant professor of History at Virginia Commonwealth University
column3: and discuss her recent book Nature's Civil War: Common Soldiers and the Environment in 1862 Virginia. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: Kathryn Shively Meier (KM): Thank you for having me.
CWBR: What first brought you to this topic?
KM: In reading Civil War common soldier accounts
column2: their letters
column3: diaries
column4: memoirs
column5: I quickly noticed that soldiers discussed nature all the time giving
column6: what seemed like
column7: daily accounts of weather
column8: climate
column9: flora
column10: and fauna. But scholars have never really analyzed why
column11: and I began to wonder if there was more to it than simply bored farmers just sitting around looking at their environment. So when I started investigating it a little more closely
column12: I realized that soldiers believed that environment was responsible for some of the deadly diseases that they were facing. For instance
column13: they believed miasma
column14: bad water
column15: seasonal shifts
column16: the southern climate were causing things like diarrhea and dysentery
column17: and those two were the top killers of the war
column18: as well as some others like malaria and typhoid. And further
column19: a variety of mental unfortunates
column20: like melancholy
column21: home sickness
column22: loneliness. The ending of the Civil War
column23: of all of the mortalities
column24: 2/3 of them would be from disease and yet most scholarly medical histories have been focusing on battle wounds. Also
column25: they had mainly been focused on the top down
column26: like medical personnel
column27: rather than the soldiers themselves. So ultimately
column28: I decided I wanted to focus on mental and physical health through the eyes of the soldiers in this war.

column1: CWBR: What were the challenges you faced in doing your research?
KM: Actually one of the problems was a good problem
column2: which was an overabundance of sources
column3: because as anyone who has read Civil War soldiers’ accounts knows nearly every soldier in this environment and health. So it was the opposite of the needle-in-a-haystack type of research. Which is why it ultimately shows to do a case study. But sort of a problem that I had
column4: and this was one of bigger problems
column5: was in charting mental health because official records really only recorded the most severe mental illness. So things like insanity
column6: suicide
column7: and what was contemporarily called nostalgia
column8: which was a potential deadly case of home sickness. So in order to gain a nuance understanding of soldier's mental landscapes and how they were influenced by the environment
column9: I had to take a more in-depth approach rather than a broad approach. My core study ended up being just a couple hundred individual soldiers because I had to literally map out their daily moves over a course of a year
column10: which I did in an Excel spreadsheet
column11: and I charted each time a man mentioned being melancholy or happy or even when he did not mention it but you could discern the mood shifts in his writing
column12: and I had to figure out why that was happening. Was it linked to weather? Or health? To losing his friends to disease? etc. Ultimately I knew that morale shifts had serious consequences for Army operations because you could see that a soldier who had very low morale starts to unravel
column13: deserts
column14: disobeys orders
column15: drink
column16: and just performs poorly in his job. So I did the same technique then for physical illnesses as well. Even though there are official records
column17: which are much better on the U.S. side than the Confederate side
column18: for physical health
column19: those records are really spotty because the way soldiers reported to sick call in the morning. Looking at their daily physical landscapes as well
column20: I saw how sick they really were. It was very rare to find a soldier that wasn’t suffering from diarrhea nearly every day. The picture that emerged for me was an army that was really struggling to stay well enough to just be minimally adequate to the grueling task of soldiering every day.

column2: what was the state of medical care and knowledge before the war and did this play an important role in how soldiers dealt with their environment during the war?

column1: KM: The state of medical care before the war is best described as chaotic. The Civil War occurred a decade before the discovery of germ theory and about two decades before the discovery of insect-borne illness. Medical profession was not very much influx before the war
column2: as traditional surgeons were still clinging to humoral theory
column3: the idea that the body was made up of fluids in need of balancing and they do so by what we call heroic interventions
column4: these dramatic interventions to balance these fluids. Bleeding
column5: purging
column6: high doses of often mercury based medicine. Some of this was beginning to fall out of favor
column7: but this was still the mainstream of medicine. But for people who become soldiers
column8: they have fairly little experience with professional doctors before the war
column9: and very little experience with hospitals. The preferred being treated at home by family members
column10: usually women. They tended to believe that disease was caused by observable things they could see and feel
column11: so environmental factors. For instance
column12: there was a widely held fear that the South was a more harmful disease environment
column13: and if you lived there you would have to undergo a process of seasoning in order to adjust. So the soldiers who went to war in 1861 and 1862 were products of an antebellum culture that was on one hand suspicious of professional medical care
column14: and on the other hand emphasized self-reliance and environmental explanations of disease. One of the interesting things
column15: at the beginning of the war there were a whole lot of Confederate posturing at how maybe the Yankees would come down South and all die in the southern swamps. Under the circumstances of Army life where you have 50
column16: 000 to over 100
column17: 000 men living together in mobile cities without infrastructures. Well the truth was they all got sick. Virginia was changed by war to become hospital disease environment for everyone. There were dead bodies everywhere
column18: polluted water sources
column19: landscapes ripped up from combat and mobilization. A lot of their pre-held beliefs were tested. Many had assumed that hearty country boys would spare them in the harsh environment of war. Early on
column20: it was city men who spared best because they had already been exposed to crowd diseases when they were young like scarlet fever. So
column21: a lot of conceptions were tested when they went to war.

column1: CWBR: The campaigns you cover in your work are very different
column2: how did each area present environmental challenges to soldiers and how did they deal with these challenges?

column1: KM: So I chose the 1862 Virginia Peninsula and Shenandoah Valley Campaign because they were concurrent and overlapped. Also
column2: because contemporaries viewed these two locations as very different environments. They viewed the peninsula as deadly because of its swamps
column3: and they viewed the valley as hostile because it was mountainous and famous for its beautiful hot springs. The areas were challenging to soldiers in slightly different ways. The valley had more extreme weather shifts
column4: particularly in the spring season. The campaign there required a very quick and grueling case of marching
column5: particularly for the Confederates under Stonewall Jackson. The peninsula alternately took place in swampy areas. It was really bad water
column6: and the pace of the campaign was much slower. Soldiers on both sides were stagnant. The peninsula was more taxing to health in the summer because of the swarms of mosquitoes that spread malaria. The soldiers thought that malaria was being caused by swamp miasma. Even though the campaigns were different and the areas were different
column7: the soldiers protected their mental and physical health in virtually identical ways and diverse locations. Using what I term in the book as self-care. These are techniques to combat environmental causes of disease and mental illness. So things like boiling water
column8: bathing frequently
column9: foraging for fruits and vegetables
column10: eradicating insects
column11: constructing protective shelters
column12: etc. These techniques helped them stay physically healthier but also boosted their morale. The main variation of locations when it came to self-care actually had to do with the pace of the campaign rather than the environment itself. For instance
column13: if you are camping in one area for a while
column14: a soldier could rig a better tent construction to keep it dry and drain his camp of moisture by laying down sand
column15: and that would keep away mosquitoes. However
column16: if you were in an area for a long time that would mean your water source would get fouled from having thousands of soldiers defecating
column17: washing
column18: and touching all in one place. So that is an advantage to a fast pace campaign
column19: so that you avoid the buildup of filth
column20: if you will.

column1: CWBR: How good was the medical care apparatus of each army and how did soldiers react to the care officialdom tried to impose on them?
KM: The state of medical care in 1862 was not so good. However
column2: on both sides it was starting to improve. When the war broke out
column3: soldiers were forced into this official system that was really different from what they had known in the antebellum era. For instance
column4: army surgeons often labeled them lingerers because the men were so sick so often that it seems implausible essentially to surgeons. When soldiers were treated
column5: they despised the medicine they received
column6: these heroic interventions
column7: because they felt these medicines actually made them sicker. Then they were terrified to go to the hospitals because they were unfamiliar with hospitals in general and didn’t want to be treated by strangers. The least of what they had seen in the ranks were the majority of the regiments commanding them to come back home because of how the volunteers in the civil war were raised. So the consequence of this was that soldiers often avoided the official care offered by the medical department
column8: or they supplemented it on their own by addressing what they believed to be the cause of these diseases
column9: environment. They developed their own unofficial networks of care with comrades
column10: civilians around the war front
column11: and the ones back home to provide nursing
column12: comfortable beds to recover in
column13: and also to receive supplies and advice about how to care for their health.

column1: CWBR: Seasoning is something that almost all military histories talk of
column2: but
column3: in your view
column4: what is seasoning and how did the environment play a role?

column1: KM: The traditional military view of seasoning is that citizen soldiers have to undergo a shift being a civilian to learning how to endure combat. Scholars like Earl Hess are fantastic on that type of seasoning. Then there is also another type of seasoning that is recognized by scholars like Joseph Blatter
column2: which is a phase when newer recruits first join an army and somewhere around 50% of them become sick with crowd diseases. That is important because America was so rural at the time. Joining the Army was like moving to the city
column3: but with closer quarters and no infrastructures. In addition to those two phases
column4: I see another
column5: and that is after the initial influx of crowd diseases taxes
column6: soldiers succumb to a phase of environmental seasoning
column7: which would tax physical and mental health during the daily grind of soldiering. This is the phase where they learn to endure days
column8: weeks
column9: months outside with very little shelter
column10: very little food
column11: marching 10-20 miles a day before you found pass and these are little guys
column12: like 135 pounds on average. This was an active process of becoming seasoned to the hardships. Some soldiers practiced self-care and became mentally and physically tough
column13: while others really floundered becoming despondent and often very ill and dying.

column2: straggling is something important to commanders and military historians
column3: could you explain though why it was important to soldiers' self-care?

column2: straggling is conflated with desertion
column3: which preserves a command bias from the time of the war. I think it is very important to draw distinction between temporary abandonment to one unit with the intent to return versus a permanent abandonment. There were many reasons to straggle
column4: but I looked at a reason for the practice that wasn’t covered by the literature before and that is the men often straggled to practice self-care. When they became ill or despondent or the environmental burden of soldiering was too much to bare
column5: they would often slip out of the ranks to seek shelter and recover maybe for just a night or two or sometimes for a little bit longer. In some cases they would actually seek out civilians to care for them; give them a bed to sleep in
column6: give them food. Other cases of straggling for self-care was when rations were really poor.  For instance
column7: they were not being issued fruits and vegetables. Sometimes soldiers would straggle for forage. This helped to prevent scabies. In other cases
column8: if they were not being ordered to bathe frequently enough
column9: which happened on Stonewall Jackson's Valley Campaign
column10: they straggled to find clean water to bathe and keep clean and to drink. From the soldier perspective
column11: straggling could be just the key to staying healthy enough to continue on. But
column12: of course
column13: from the command perspective
column14: generals didn’t really consider that there were benefits to straggling. To them it meant and absence of available men to his campaign. It meant that the discipline in their army was poor. There is this kind of divide between the soldiers and generals here when it came to viewing straggling. Straggling became so pervasive over the course of 1862 that the medical departments were still so weak that command on both sides became to really crack down on the practice as the year went on
column15: and impose torturous penalties. To give a few examples: Stonewall Jackson had four men court marshaled and executed as deserters
column16: who claim they had only been straggling to serve the example because straggling was so bad in his army. Then
column17: I say the most effective punishment in serving straggling was probably just restricting pay. By the end of the years
column18: straggling had somewhat evaded.

column1: CWBR: How did what soldiers and the army learned during these two campaigns effect medical care and reactions to the environment in the rest of the war?

KM: Soldiers continue to practice self-care throughout the war. Discipline did improve straggling and it was evaded. Both sides learned that their medical systems were inadequate to the task of caring for these massive armies
column2: and went about improving hospitals
column3: supplies
column4: rations
column5: etc. The U.S. really had an advantage with the intervention with the U.S. Sanitary Commission who had been investigating soldier camps and making recommendations for improved sanitation and environmental management. As well as providing supplies and nurses since the beginning of the war. In the Army of Potomac
column6: the Union Army looked at a new medical director
column7: Jonathan Letterman
column8: who came in and addressed problems like ambulance evacuation to considerable affects starting in July of 1962. In the end
column9: the Civil War had a much better track record than the Mexican-American War in terms of mortality due to disease. In the Mexican-American War
column10: 80% of mortalities had been from disease and in this war
column11: only 66% by war's end. However
column12: I would argue that it remains very much due to credit of the soldiers themselves and the individual decisions they made caring for one another
column13: and adapt to the environment of war. They were able to mentally and physically preserve here.

column2: I appreciate you taking the time to sit and discuss your most recent work
column3:
Nature's Civil War: Common Soldiers and the Environment in 1862 Virginia.

" Frawley
column4: Michael Spring 2014 2014-05-01 Interview University of North Carolina Press ""

column1:
5122 978-0-7006-1797-5 $39.95 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
A Generation at War: The Civil War Era in a Northern Community Etcheson
column2: Nicole			"<h3>Interview with Nicole Etcheson
column3: Alexander M. Bracken Professor of History at Ball State University

column1: Civil War Book Review would like to congratulate Nicole Etcheson on winning the 2012 Avery O. Craven Award for this title
column2: given by The Organization of American Historians
column3: for most original book on the coming of the Civil War
column4: the Civil War years
column5: or the Era of Reconstruction
column6: with the exception of works of purely military history.

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview

column2: we are pleased to speak with Professor Nichole Etcheson
column3: the Alexander M. Bracken Professor of History at Ball State University and author of A Generation of War: The Civil War Era in a Northern Community. Professor Etcheson
column4: thank you so much for talking with us today.

column1: CWBR: Historians have spent so much time looking at the factory owners and the laborers in the Northeast and slaveholders and non-slaveholders in the South
column2: but you show us the farmers and the wider agricultural community of the Midwest and the Old Northwest.  Of all the counties and all of the northern states
column3: why is Putnam County
column4: Indiana an excellent area to study in order to understand how the American Civil War altered an entire generation of people?

column2: no county is going to be totally perfect and I did choose Putnam County
column3: in part
column4: because of a famous speech that was given there by a Copperhead politician
column5: Dan Voorhies
column6: right before the war began.  But
column7: it seems to me
column8: that Putnam County does a fairly good job of representing the North.  It’s a largely agricultural community
column9: it is divided between Whigs and Democrats (and later
column10: Republicans and Democrats)
column11: in an era
column12: and in a state (Indiana) where the inter-party competition was quite fierce
column13: and a lot of the home front studies of the North have looked at cities: Chicago
column14: Boston
column15: and Philadelphia.  And those are all wonderful additions to what we need to know about the northern home front but we have not had many studies that have looked at the northern home front and that have looked at rural areas
column16: small-town areas that were more typical of the North.  Putnam County comes closer
column17: I think
column18: to being what much of the North was like.

column2: what is the value of a county study in our broader
column3: more complete understanding of the Civil War era?

column2: meaning looking at a very tiny place
column3: although I do take a larger slice of time than many home front studies of the Civil War which will concentrate on 1861-1865.  I look from
column4: about
column5: the end of the war with Mexico through the end of Reconstruction so I think that swath of time is a contribution.  But
column6: in terms of micro-history
column7: I really wanted to get a sense of how the war impacted individuals: soldiers
column8: farmers
column9: women
column10: the black community in Putnam County because
column11: really
column12: this war swept up real people.  And it is hard to get a sense of that when you’re looking at the big political studies we have or the big military studies that we have.   The way that this impacted the lives of real human beings and I would suggest that
column13: even though we are looking at very particular human beings in a very particular place
column14: the kinds of things that happen to them-imprisonment
column15: widowhood
column16: gaining more rights-are taking place all over the country.

column1: CWBR: You very cleverly begin the book with an account of the murder of Martha Ann Sublett Mullinex by her husband Greebury. How does this incident illustrate the inter-party conflict
column2: that you mentioned earlier
column3: in the years leading up to the war?

column2: Martha was murdered by her husband; they had not been married very long and he may have been mentally disturbed.  That is a little hard to tell in the newspaper accounts; he comes across as not quite “all there
column3: ” and he murders her with an axe.  But what interests me about that
column4: it is a turning point in the county history-it is the last execution in the county-but the story is picked up by a young man
column5: Miles Fletcher
column6: who is a professor at the local university
column7: and Miles Fletcher comes from a very prominent Indianapolis family.  And Miles turns
column8: what might ordinarily be a very tragic story
column9: into a revelation about the problems of the Democratic Party because the Mullinexes are Democrats
column10: Fletcher is a rising Republican
column11: and Greenbury drank
column12: and his family manufactured liquor
column13: and they were not interested in education
column14: and the murderer’s uncle had ties to the governor of Indiana who was a Democrat
column15: who managed to get a temporary stay of the execution through his Democratic political connections.   So Fletcher turns this all into a parable about how terrible the Democrats are
column16: the way in which this is politicized
column17: to reveal the differences between the two parties
column18: I thought
column19: was very interesting in the period before the Civil War.  It seemed to me that one of the constants throughout the Civil War period
column20: issues about gender that were there in the marriage
column21: issues about alcohol
column22: all of these things continue through but Fletcher has no interest in
column23: and there is no role played by race in this tragedy
column24: but it will come to be the case over the years that race becomes a more and important of a factor to the life of the county.

column1: CWBR: I was struck by the degree to which Putnam County seems to provide a micro-history
column2: as you mention
column3: in the presidential election of 1860 in which we see residents positioning themselves in four different corners.  It’s not simply a Lincoln-Douglas debate and I wonder
column4: what made politics so complex as the county considered their choices in 1860?

column2: one of the reasons I chose it
column3: is that a state like Indiana
column4: and a county like Putnam
column5: had a substantial migration from the upper South.  So all through the 1850s you see these very strong
column6: loyalties to Kentucky
column7: to the South
column8: that people in Indiana and people in this county feel that the growing Republican Party is picking on the South
column9: that southern rights are under attack
column10: and there is not much sympathy for abolitionism or antislavery.  At the same time
column11: though
column12: you do have the Whigs moving towards the Republican Party
column13: not out of an antislavery sentiment
column14: but out of the sense that it is the North that is the aggrieved party
column15: that the North has been bullied constantly by the Slave Power of the South.  So when we get to 1860
column16: it is mostly Douglas men versus Lincoln me-northern Democrat versus Republicans-arguing about which one of them can best represent the South.  There is a tiny
column17: infinitesimal Constitutional Union
column18: Bell movement but
column19: what I found out and find quite interesting
column20: was that there is a small Breckinridge movement led by some prominent local county officials
column21: a Judge named Delana Eckels went about the county and about the state making speeches for the Southern Rights’ Democrats and John Breckinridge and that the margin that the Breckinridge voters polled in that county pushed the county to the Republicans.  It allowed the Republicans to win the county.  To my knowledge
column22: we have tended to dismiss the Breckinridge movement in the North
column23: but I wonder
column24: if we did these kinds of micro-histories and looked at these results county-by-county
column25: if we might find that some of the Republican margin of victory is owed more to the Southern Rights movement than we have heretofore known.

column2: it seems to me that many of Putnam’s residents opposed Republicans’ use of emancipation as a war aim.  If that is the case
column3: what does that tell us about the long-standing slavery v. union debate? Did Putnam County residents fight a different civil war?

column1: NE: They fought an internal civil war as well as a national civil war. And certainly many
column2: many hundreds of young men from Putnam County went off and they fought with Sherman and they fought with McClellan
column3: and they fought under Grant
column4: and they are owed a great deal for the victory that the Union eventually won.  But the county was very deeply divided and there was a very strong Copperhead
column5: anti-war
column6: Peace Democrat movement within the county.  And it mainly played out over issues of the draft and of emancipation
column7: which is to say that the violent incidents that occurred in the county-draft officers being mobbed and draft officers being shot at-were about the draft.  People were organizing; the Copperheads of Putnam County were organizing.  They were forming mobs
column8: if you want to call them that
column9: that had a consistent pattern of intimidating the draft officials and trying to prevent the carrying out of the draft.  With emancipation
column10: it was much more on the level of rhetoric of party resolutions that this was barbaric of the Lincoln administration to do this
column11: that it confirmed what the Southern Democrats had been saying all along: that the Republicans were really an abolitionist movement.  So
column12: I think there was war at both levels
column13: on the local level and then on the national level.

column2: you seem to show that statewide
column3: Indiana experiences a great deal of debate over the Thirteenth Amendment
column4: and the state is the only one that chooses not to repeal its black laws. Why does Indiana seem so racially conservative?

column1: NE: I think it was that southern migration; that was one of the major divisions for people. I would go back even further to the origin of the black laws
column2: as I talk in the book
column3: to the Constitution of 1851
column4: where Indiana instituted Article 13 of the Constitution which prohibited African Americans from coming into the state.  So
column5: as you say
column6: Indiana was a black law state; it had various prohibitions against equal rights for African Americans and that Article 13 had been ratified by an even bigger margin-it was ratified separately from the Constitution-and it got a bigger margin of victory than the Constitution itself.  So
column7: I think that was due to the strong southern-roots population of Indiana.  And then what you’re referring to is that the state had a lot of difficulty shedding those attitudes and didn’t even get around
column8: until constitutional revision until the 1880s
column9: to repealing these black laws that had been nullified by the Civil War.  But I would also like to point out that
column10: despite those attitudes
column11: amazing things happened in Putnam County with race.  Republicans who
column12: before they were Republicans
column13: back when they were Whigs in the county in the 1850s
column14: did nothing for black rights-actually were opposed to black rights-through the Civil War period and
column15: perhaps for self-interested motives
column16: they actually come
column17: by the 1870s
column18: to be recruiting African Americans to moving into the county.  So there is this legacy of racism but the Civil War era brings
column19: I think
column20: enormous strides.

column2: immediately after the war as you reference
column3: Putnam residents seem as if they want to disassociate themselves from the discussion of race entirely and they focus
column4: instead on economics or their support of or opposition to the war.  I wonder if I’m reading that correctly and
column5: if that’s the case
column6: why do politicians
column7: locally
column8: often push race to the periphery?

column2: there are still these long-standing issues.  One of the things I found was that temperance is always there; it is kind of pushed to the background during the Civil War but
column3: after the Civil War
column4: it emerges and it is just an incredibly big deal.  And women are very involved with the temperance movement so
column5: although I don’t see women seizing upon the Civil War to get their rights-the kind of narrative that we have had
column6: someone like Elizabeth Cady Stanton
column7: who looked at the Civil War as an opportunity to seize political rights for women-Putnam County women don’t want that.  Most of them just want the men to come home and then
column8: sometimes when the men don’t come home
column9: they have to cope with the realities of getting on with life.  A lot of things that had been there before the war
column10: the concern with economic development
column11: the concern about temperance emerge again after the war
column12: but the reality is that the war has changed the status of African Americans.  One of the families that I talk about in the book
column13: the Townsends
column14: are the long-resident free blacks
column15: and for much of the period
column16: the only free blacks in the county
column17: their son serves in the 28th United States Colored Troops; he has a very tragic experience: he never sees combat
column18: he becomes ill
column19: he dies.  But nonetheless
column20: there are people coming into the county
column21: like the Townsends
column22: who have served in the military.  Now that blacks are mobile
column23: people are coming up from Kentucky and from other southern states and some of them have military service and they have the Fourteenth Amendment and the Fifteenth Amendment and they have a status that now has to be recognized.  People in the county have to come to terms with that.  So I think
column24: yes
column25: white people in the county would like to go back to the set of issues that had always preoccupied them but they have had a new set of issues has emerged. And they have increasing numbers of people in the county who are going to push for those rights.

column2: particularly
column3: by how the Civil War changed gender roles.  Women had to work when men went to the war and when the men returned they
column4: often
column5: could not work.  How did pensions serve to maintain veterans’ manhood by enabling them the hope of providing for their family with their service during the crisis.  And
column6: at the same time
column7: how did pensions
column8: on the other hand
column9: alter the gender roles or the traditional role of a dependent woman?  I’m thinking specifically about Jennie Fletcher
column10: whose husband and father-in-law failed to enable her to be an independent woman.

column1: NE: The Fletchers were very wealthy so ultimately Jennie Fletcher
column2: when Miles dies
column3: inherits enough money
column4: and then when her father-in-law dies
column5: she inherits enough from that estate that she is seemingly independent.  On the issue of pensions
column6: pensions had different ramifications
column7: I think
column8: for different groups of people by race and class.  Some of what is interesting is that men who apply for these pensions don’t see it as a hand-out from the government.  One of the things that is interesting about these pension rolls is that
column9: as these men age
column10: they have more and more problems which
column11: I think it would be fair to say
column12: is probably related to the fact that they are getting old; they can’t hear.  Lucius Chapin’s pension rolls
column13: his teeth are falling out
column14: he is getting into his seventies
column15: he is having trouble hearing
column16: he is having some mobility issues
column17: and yet his pension applications take these all back to when he was in the army in Tennessee and Georgia and he had heat stroke
column18: and that is why his teeth are falling out or he had a malarial fever back during the war. So this is the cause of losing teeth and bad hearing. We would probably say
column19: well you’re aging; that’s why these things are happening to you.  The veterans want to see this
column20: not as I’m getting older and I’m asking the government for money
column21: as no
column22: the government owes me this because this is happening to me because of what I did for the country thirty or forty years ago.  The pension file of one of the black veterans
column23: Wyatt James
column24: who was related to the Townsend family
column25: who suffered some terrible-looking wounds in the Petersburg Campaign in 1864 and
column26: on the one hand
column27: historians have pointed out how black veterans can apply for these pensions and they can get remuneration just the way that white veterans do
column28: so it makes white and black manhood equivalent.  On the other hand
column29: Wyatt James is a laborer and the requirement is that he has to be disabled from laboring in order to qualify for the pension.  So
column30: it seems to be a little bit harder for him to be getting a pension than for Lucius Chapin
column31: who is a lawyer and doesn’t
column33: need to work as physically hard to make this case as he is getting older for increased pensions.  The women who get pensions
column35: who is the mother of the black soldier
column37: it is kind of hard to find out what happened.  She apparently filed for a pension and didn’t get anything for a long time and then got a good pension agent who got her back payments-a couple thousand dollars-an extraordinary sum for a poor black woman in that period.  I think that testifies
column39: to the government’s emphasis on equal rights: she is the mother of a soldier who died
column40: she apparently had some difficulty navigating the pension application process at first but
column42: she gets the back payment of a substantial amount.  And then
column47: is the case where the pension allows her to be fairly independent.  Her husband had been a prisoner at Andersonville
column49: he died shortly after the war
column50: and she views this pension as her money and
column52: it becomes divorced from this idea that it is her husband providing for her in perpetuity; she never remarries
column53: she lives largely off of the pension
column56: that is not ever what she wanted; she wanted John to come back from the war and provide for her as a man is supposed to do. So it is an unintended consequence of the pension that she becomes a very independent-minded widow.

column1: CWBR: You mention some of the strides that African Americans are able to make in the years after the war in the way that Putnam County alters the way that its viewpoint on race. I wonder
column2: generally speaking
column3: does post-war Putnam County’s experience help explain African-Americans’ struggle to make social headway nationally leading into the Jim Crow period?  It seems to me that
column4: while they are making strides
column5: many white residents are simply apathetic about race in this period in Putnam County.

column2: some are.  There are two things going on.  One
column3: of course
column4: is that African Americans during the Civil War and during Reconstruction are seeking to better their condition.  So
column5: by the 1870s
column6: in particular
column7: there builds up
column8: in some areas of North Carolina dissatisfaction with the end of Reconstruction
column9: with the re-imposition of discriminatory measures by the state of North Carolina
column10: and so African Americans there start thinking about leaving.  But then there is also a coordinate movement in Indiana
column11: and ultimately in Putnam County
column12: to recruit blacks to come to the county.  And the white Republicans who do this-some of them are self-interested- want cheap labor
column13: so they think former slaves from the South may work for less than white laborers in the county.  Some of it is
column14: this is a very closely divided county
column15: and local Republicans are looking to bring in Republican voters; everyone denies that this is going on.  That doesn’t seem to be how it started.  Local Democrats will say that they went out looking for voters; they’re importing voters.  It does not seem to have
column16: then
column17: the genesis of the movement but it certainly was a nice added side effect.  And so you get these white Republicans who were bringing in
column18: or hoping to bring in
column19: these North Carolina African Americans.  And local Democrats are certainly not indifferent about it; they are mad as hell and we talk about the Exoduster movement to Kansas and there was a national
column20: congressional committee to investigate what was happening with the movement of blacks out of the South.  Because our focus has largely been on the movement from the Deep South to Kansas
column21: we have tended to miss the fact that the whole reason to call this congressional committee into session was that they were worried (Democrats in Congress were worried) about black movement into Indiana.  That was really the origin of the congressional concern and a lot of the testimony was about Kansas but a lot of it was about Indiana as well
column22: and in that local testimony you see local Democrats organizing to drive African Americans out.  Now
column23: ultimately what happens is
column24: a lot of these Exodusters who come to Putnam County
column25: they end up leaving.  Many of them go to Indianapolis
column26: some of it because racial prejudice was stronger in the countryside than they had been led to believe.  I think a lot of it has to do with there being less economic opportunity than they had been led to believe so they go to Indianapolis which is a larger
column27: growing metropolis and there are more jobs there.  But some of these Exodusters stay in the county
column28: some of them marry into the Townsend and form the real beginnings of the black community in the county.

column2: I want to thank once again for taking the time to discuss your book today
column3: A Generation at War: The Civil War Era in a Northern Community.

column2:
thank you very much for having me.

" Buman
column3: Nathan Spring 2012 2012-05-01 Interview University Press of Kansas ""

column2: Social Life
column3: and the Coming of the Civil War		Shelden
column4: Rachel			"<h3>Interview with Rachel Shelden
column5: Assistant Professor of History at the University of Oklahoma

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Rachel Shelden
column2: Assistant Professor of History at the University of Oklahoma
column3: and discuss her recent book <i>Washington Brotherhood: Politics
column4: Social Life
column5: and the Coming of the Civil War. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: Rachel Shelden (RS): Thanks so much for having me.

column2: I'd like to know what first brought you to the topic?

column1: RS: Well it's a great question. I started this project as my dissertation at the University of Virginia
column2: and I had been interested in Washington politics for quite some time.  I had worked for the Library Congress before going to graduate school
column3: and I was very interested in the way that people interacted in Washington
column4: and the difference in the culture of Washington from the inside and Washington from the outside (having not grown up in Washington
column5: I'm originally from Chicago).  So
column6: that was something that really struck me while I was living there
column7: and I was working on a history of the House of Representatives
column8: and I noticed that this was something that was very big in the nineteenth century
column9: this sort of culture of Washington
column10: and this was something that I wanted to pursue long-term.  So although I actually came to the topic a little bit later in graduate school
column11: it was something that was bubbling in my mind for a long time.

column1: CWBR: You say that this was a problem that was very big in the nineteenth century--I'm sure some people would say that it's a problem that hasn't gone away--so what were some of the challenges then
column2: of exposing the nature of that disconnect
column3: and sort of the true culture of Washington when you're talking about people who have a very vested interest in projecting a certain kind of image and a certain kind of rhetoric and representation
column4: when perhaps there's something else beneath the surface.

column1: RS: I think that's something we've struggled with for a very long time. As historians
column2: we have a lot of faith in the documents that we work with
column3: and we worked with the Congressional Globe
column4: which is the official record of the U.S. Congress in the nineteenth century--for most of the nineteenth century.  We had great faith in the Congressional Globe to be able to tell us what was going on in Washington and the ways that politicians engaged in thinking about the major political issues of the period.  And there were no real indicators as to why the Congressional Globe wouldn't have given us a straightforward answer to the ways that people thought and the way they behaved.  But I discovered more and more as I was reading about the politicians and reading their letters and reading—particularly their letters back home to their families—that they didn't have much trust in the Congressional Globe to tell them what was really going on because they didn't pay much attention to the speeches in Washington.  So the more that I sort of peeled back the layers of the Congressional Globe
column5: the more I could tell that it wasn't actually representative of what politicians thought in terms of getting policy forward in the process of politicking in the nineteenth century.  So
column6: I think it's a challenge because
column7: as we all know
column8: as all historians deal with
column9: our sources can only take us so far.  They are only a small portion of what exists out there in terms of what was actually going on.  I had to dig deep to find references
column10: usually not long stories
column11: to the kind of politicking that happened outside the halls of the capital
column12: at places like boarding houses and dinners and parties
column13: and meetings of various associations in Washington.  That was a challenge
column14: but I could tell that something was really not quite right there.

column2: really then
column3: most of the political discussions that mattered the most in reality
column4: you would say
column5: were the ones that took place outside of the halls of Congress?

column1: RS: That mattered to policy making. I would never say that the Congressional Globe was non-important in terms of understanding what was going in the rest of the country
column2: because in a lot of ways
column3: the Congressional Globe was very much representative of what constituents wanted to hear.  That’s who these people were talking to when they were speaking in the halls of Congress.  They wanted their constituents back in Massachusetts and South Carolina and Kentucky and Louisiana to actually hear what they wanted to hear.  It was not
column4: however
column5: representative of what was going on in terms of the actual politicking in Washington.

column1: CWBR: One thing that interests me about that point is this very conscious importance of rhetoric. Especially as we approach the Civil War and rhetoric
column2: especially secessionist rhetoric
column3: becomes even more virulent
column4: even more fiery
column5: it's interesting then that perhaps a lot of those speakers didn't fully believe what they were saying
column6: or is that an overstatement?

column1: RS: I think it's a little bit of an overstatement. This all goes back
column2: as many of these things do
column3: to David Potter
column4: and David Potter's famed article “The Historian's Use of Nationalism and Vice-Versa
column5: ” where he talks about these conflicting loyalties that a person might have.  Loyalty to state
column6: loyalty to family
column7: loyalty to nation
column8: and I think it was possible for a lot of these men to say things about their views on slavery in particular
column9: but also be friendly with people who disagreed with them.  In part because of the personal experience of living in Washington.  It was very hard
column10: if you wanted to have any kind of political role in the city at this time
column11: to avoid interacting with people who are going to have different opinions from you
column12: and that was an acknowledged part of being there.  So you see
column13: for example
column14: slaveholders talking about how most Northerners are antislavery
column15: and not liking those views
column16: but being willing to work with it because they have this understanding that they have those views and those are the views of their constituents.  So I would never say
column17: for example
column18: that they don't really believe what they're saying.  They may say it a little bit more strongly
column19: or in particularly fiery rhetoric to try to get their constituents fired up about the issue
column20: but I would say that much of what happened was really in the context of ""We are politicians
column21: that's what we do
column22: and we all have a sense of what we want
column23: which was to keep the Union together--most of the people wanted to keep the Union together--and to have a successful Federal government.  It didn't always work
column24: but there was certainly a level of respect that existed among the politicians that didn't necessarily extend to the constituents.

column1: CWBR: That issue of respect sort of leads to another question
column2: because it seems like the centerpiece of most narratives of Washington politics right before the Civil War was
column3: of course
column4: Preston Brooks caning Charles Sumner.  It's sort of the image that's been seared into every textbook.  And
column5: a lot of scholars have established the importance of honor and personal politics.  But it seems like part of what you're saying is that this respect and sense of honor
column6: in more cases
column7: helped keep these people together and working together
column8: rather than driving wedges between them. So would you call instances of people like Preston Brooks more of the exception than the rule?

column1: RS: I wouldn't say that it was an exception in the sense that there was an incredible amount of violence in the nineteenth century
column2: and especially in Washington
column3: which was a pretty violent but also just a pretty dirty and disgusting city
column4: which allowed for that kind of thing to happen.  This is part of what I tried to show in that chapter in particular and in my book
column5: that if you understand the caning of Charles Sumner in the context of the violence that existed in Washington
column6: it's not unusual.  What made it unusual is that it got the kind of press that it did
column7: and it became such an incredible tool for people in the North and the South
column8: in thinking about the problems of
column9: say
column10: a slave power
column11: or of an oppressive North.  So
column12: it's usual in the sense that there was quite a bit of violence.  It's unusual in the terms of political tools outside of Washington
column13: but the people in Washington understood it as an example of violence
column14: of things getting out of hand
column15: and one that didn't necessarily mean that we were about to crumble into Civil War.

column1: CWBR: For the politicians that may have witnessed this
column2: or heard about it
column3: it was sort of disconnected from what the nation saw.  In a sense
column4: the nation saw this as a much more important event than perhaps the people there at the scene did?

column2: it was a big event when it happened
column3: and people were upset
column4: but it went away after a couple days.  People sort of said
column5: ""Ok
column6: now we're going to get back to the business of making policy
column7: and that involves talking to my Southern neighbors or my Northern neighbors
column8: and I can't avoid that
column9: nor should I.""  So it certainly was something that really energized people who weren't in Washington
column10: but in Washington
column11: it wasn't such a big deal.

column1: CWBR: One that you've mentioned several times that also sticks out to me is this sense of place
column2: and you mentioned that because of the nature of Washington
column3: that these people couldn't really avoid each other
column4: even if they had wanted to.  I was hoping you could talk about the role of proximity
column5: and how that affected politics
column6: and also what were some of the places that politicians interacted outside of Congress?

column1: RS: I'm happy to. I think one of the most fascinating aspects of Washington in this period is that there are sort of two Washingtons. There's the permanent Washington. There's the Washington that has the people that you would see in any city--in New York
column2: in Charleston
column3: etc.--where you're going to have workers
column4: women
column5: African Americans.  That absolutely existed in Washington
column6: but there was also this more temporary part of Washington that really only existed between the Capital building and the White House on Pennsylvania Avenue
column7: which is not a very large area.  In that area
column8: you had mostly male politicians living in boarding houses
column9: also some hotels.  They spent almost all of their time together.  They were either in the Capital or they were at home
column10: or they were at dinners or gambling houses--maybe some brothels also--in that area.  So they actually spent most of their time together
column11: and what this produced was something of a fraternity.  You might think about it as a giant male bonding session
column12: where you have these men who spend all their time together
column13: not so much with women
column14: and where they're really engaging in conversation in places outside the Capital.  That includes things like dinners.  Lots of people held dinners for their friends.  This would happen
column15: some
column16: with the permanent politicians.  William Corcoran
column17: who was a famous socialite in the period
column18: would host regular political dinners
column19: and he lived right by the White House so you would see
column20: basically
column21: a revolving door of politicians coming to eat with him
column22: but also just people sitting down to have dinner at the end of the day.  There were various boarding houses.  You also had people going to church together.  You had people meeting at Masonic groups
column23: and also other smaller groups that they put together.  One really famous example of this was Abraham Lincoln
column24: who was in a group called the Young Indian Club
column25: which was sort of a political debating group that consisted of himself
column26: one other Northerner
column27: and five Southerners including future Confederate Vice President Alexander Stephens
column28: which made for some really interesting commentary on Lincoln's behalf.  But the two of them became quite friendly in this group and talked politics and this had a real influence
column29: I believe
column30: on Lincoln's thinking on politics in Washington
column31: and particularly the secession crisis.  Thinking about what was possible
column32: the kinds of compromises that could happen
column33: and the way in which you could have a conversation with someone from the South
column34: and not have it lead to Civil War.  So there was a lot discussion that happened outside of the Capital building in these more informal circumstances
column35: but with the same group of people.

column1: CWBR: Would you say that Lincoln's experience in Washington was initially what made him optimistic that war could be avoided?
RS: I do think so. I think he was affected by his time in Washington in a variety of ways
column2: and I point this out in a couple of places in the book.  One of things that was really important to him in terms of his experience in Washington and being in this Young Indian Club was to expose him to John Crittenden
column3: who was very famous politician from Kentucky
column4: someone that he admired very much.  Crittenden was life-long politician
column5: had spent many years in Washington
column6: and Crittenden himself became quite friendly with Stephen Douglas
column7: Lincoln's main rival in Illinois in the 1858 Senate campaign
column8: and Douglas is very happy to get Crittenden's endorsement in 1858
column9: and this had a very big impact on Lincoln's experiences in thinking about who should be in his cabinet once he's elected in 1860.  I believe he never forgave John Crittenden for his behavior in supporting Stephen Douglas.  But it also gave him a sense of this Washington club
column10: and what was possible in Washington.  I think he really underestimated how much secession was going to be a grassroots movement that did not have any kind of real push in Washington.  It was much more a rejection of Washington politicians
column11: and so he misread the South.  He had a misunderstanding of what was actually going to happen when he made his original decision to not speak out
column12: to not say anything
column13: to not support the attempts in Congress to try to come up with a solution--the Crittenden Compromise--again
column14: his anger at Crittenden is something that I think we really underestimate.  In spite of that
column15: Lincoln was smart man
column16: he figured things out
column17: and a lot of historians have shown his thinking in March and April to be quite different
column18: but early on in the process
column19: I think he had a great misunderstanding of what was going to happen.

column1: CWBR: Do you think that this club should be viewed more in the light of having been able
column2: for a long time and with some notable instances of compromise
column3: that they were able for so long to smooth over differences and prevent war from breaking out
column4: or is this more a story of these guys in this ""Washington bubble"" disconnected from what the issues of the war and secession were going to be
column5: really ultimately being unable to prevent something that they didn't really understand?

column1: RS: That's an excellent question. I think what I've tried to do and the historians who read this will recognize this
column2: is sort of turn the old revisionist theory on its head.  So the old revisionist theory being that a blundering generation of politicians pushed toward war because they had a misunderstanding of how serious these things were
column3: and they were particularly fiery
column4: and they ended up pushing us into war; it's their fault.  My point here is to show
column5: to a large degree
column6: that they didn't really have control.  They were not the ones that could have made decisions about this
column7: and they did live in a bubble that made them really unable to understand a lot of what was going on at home.  Jefferson Davis being the best example of this.  He's quite sad when secession comes
column8: and he's sad
column9: in part I think because he didn't realize how serious it was.  In large part because he was so sad that the Union was falling apart
column10: but also because he didn't understand how this could happen so quickly; he was very surprised by it. I would say that my point is much more that they didn't have the tools to fix this problem. The movement toward secession was really a rejection of them
column11: and a rejection of their way of handling politics.  You read the letters during the secession crisis
column12: and so much of what they say is ""these corrupt officials in Washington
column13: they've failed us
column14: over and over and over again
column15: so we need to take matters into our own hands.""  So I think the secession crisis is much more about that
column16: it's not so much about the blundering politicians.  Of course they contribute
column17: because they make all these fiery speeches
column18: but they didn't really have it in their power to fix the situation.

column2: I appreciate you taking the time to sit and discuss your most recent work
column3: <i>Washington Brotherhood: Politics
column4: Social Life
column5: and the Coming of the Civil War.

column2:
I enjoyed talking with you.

" Isenhower
column3: Zach Summer 2014 2014-08-01 Interview University of North Carolina Press ""
