Doctoring Freedom: The Politics of African American Medical Care Long
column2: Gretchen			"<h3>Interview with Gretchen Long
column3: Associate Professor of History and Chair of the Africana Studies Program at Williams College

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Gretchen Long
column2: Associate Professor of History and Chair of the Africana Studies Program at Williams College
column3: and discuss her recent book Doctoring Freedom: The Politics of African American Medical Care in Slavery and Emancipation. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: Gretchen Long (GL): It's good to be here

column2: healthcare and control over healthcare decisions were important steps towards freedom and independence for slaves?
before the war and during the war and after actually.  I had found when I started researching
column3: or not even researching the book
column4: but thinking about this topic
column5: how often medical care came up as a kind of area of conversation between slaves and masters in terms of what kinds of medical care slaves would receive or master's displeasure with the kind of care slaves were giving each other and that just sort of got my wheels turning and I took it from there.

column1: CWBR: How successful were slaves then at controlling their own bodies?
GL: That's a really interesting question because it's something that sources hint at but we never get a complete and full answer. But certainly
column2: I think the level of frustration that slave owners had with and would report in journals or diaries or conversations with buyers or sellers of slaves
column3: the level of frustration they had with slave medical practice
column4: combined with the fact that many white families had black slaves look after them themselves. That to me says there was quite a bit of medical care that the slaves managed to keep under their own purview and did not yield to white authority.

column1: CWBR: How did their roles as soldiers during the war
column2: especially after injury
column3: change the relationship between African-Americans and the government?

column1: GL: The thing about the Civil War is that particularly for slaves who fled toward the Union lines
column2: but even ones that stayed behind
column3: is that both systems of care were really offended.  Both care that the slaves communities provided for one another for fellow slaves and under the systems of white masters control or provision of medical care
column4: both of those kind of have the rug pulled out from under them and in the Union Army so many slaves
column5: slave men who joined the Union Army
column6: showed up at recruiting stations in terrible health.  They had walked a long way they were malnourished.  Their families were in rough shape but they immediately
column7: soldiers at least immediately
column8: see medical care as part of the contract that they have with the Union Army.  That they are providing labor or military service and one of the things that they see the government needing to provide for them
column9: and what the government does provide for white soldiers
column10: is medical care.  So one of the most interesting things I found in terms of letters from black soldiers complaining to the government about the medical care they received because even though the soldiers felt that they were entitled to it
column11: and did get some it
column12: was often substandard and not at the level the white soldiers care was.

column1: CWBR: How did the problems of medicine and healthcare effect African-Americans in their transition from slaves to freedmen?

column2: I think particularly the ideal when you achieve freedom is when you own your own body.  Now how that body is taken care of and who takes care of it then becomes really essential to expressing that freedom
column3: to any expression of that freedom
column4: and giving that freedom meaning.  So
column5: I have been really inspired by a lot of work that you are referring to that kind of puts the school house
column6: or the church
column7: or the polling place
column8: or even sort of different realms of labor
column9: that looks at those places as places where freedom happens
column10: or where black people figured out how to be free in those places
column11: and what I wanted to do is put the doctor’s office
column12: the sick bed
column13: and ultimately the medical school
column14: on that list of places where black people gave their freedom meaning.

column1: CWBR: Why did organically developed black associations and brotherhoods work so much better to harness the efforts of the community rather than government directed efforts?
GL: Yeah that's a really good question too. I think in the associations
column2: and like you said there’s a whole chapter in the book on this
column3: for one thing the black associations I’m painting with kind of broad strokes here
column4: but were better at identifying leaders
column5: of knowing who should be in charge and how things should be organized.  Than when the Freedman’s Bureau came in and sort of ordained certain black men as the spokesmen for the group.  So
column6: and of course
column7: sometimes the black people were terrible at choosing leaders and I have some stories in there of leaders who swindled their associations out of money and this and that
column8: but I think
column9: for the most part
column10: people
column11: black people
column12: knew certain men by reputation or kind of stature in their community
column13: and those were ways of knowing that the white Freedman’s Bureau did not have access too so
column14: and I think it was also a natural selection of the kind of community care that happened under slavery even though those slave communities were upended and disrupted with emancipation.

column1: CWBR: How did African-American attempts to become medical providers relate to the problems faced by the larger African-American community?
GL: I think the one who gives us kind of where the window opens the widest on that period
column2: is one of the doctors
column3: John Hamilton
column4: who lived in Austin
column5: Texas
column6: because he called himself a doctor and what he wants is for the Freedman’s Bureau to help him collect money from freedman that he says he’s treated
column7: and the Freedman’s Bureau also to encourage freedman to go to him for their care instead of to the white doctors.  The Freedman’s Bureau has kind of set up their services and what happens is the Freedman’s Bureau says no way he’s a quack and a conjurer
column8: and what's interesting to me is that a group of freedmen themselves write to the Freedman’s Bureau back in Washington and say yes indeed he is a quack and a conjurer.  So
column9: his case really shows the diversity of opinion among freedmen and how impossible it can be to talk about a free community
column10: or a freedman thought this
column11: or that you know here was real division about who some freedman who thought he was a good doctor but refused to pay him and some thought he was a conjurer and a quack and should give up calling himself a doctor.  So I like that case because partially because it doesn’t really show an answer exactly but it does point to how  those letters happened in 1866 and the kind of the writing on the wall of what happens to folk healers like Hamilton.  They are not going to be able to make livings
column12: or maintain respectability
column13: in the eyes of white authority as we go forward in the decades.  You know his system of medicine is on the way out and the system of the whites Freedman’s Bureau
column14: doctor’s practices
column15: and that more and more black doctors
column16: and I talk about them
column17: want in on them.  They want for more medical training that is what's ascending
column18: not just in the black South
column19: but all over the country.

column1: CWBR: How did the professionalization of medicine by the turn of the century help or hinder the development
column2: political activism
column3: and solidarity of the greater African-American community?

column1: GL: I think that that last chapter in the book chronologically
column2: the last couple of decades that the book
column3: deals with the story
column4: really shifts from a context of slavery and emancipation to a context of Jim Crow and segregation.  So even in scholarly literature we know that the waves of protests
column5: and resistance
column6: and solidarity
column7: happened under those different kind of regimens
column8: is very different by the end of the book.  There are very few
column9: and by the turn of the century there are very few white medical schools that let in African Americans.  By 1910 most black medical schools have been shut down with increasing regulation
column10: which did raise standards for medical education
column11: but also cut off then  most of the avenues by which young black mostly men
column12: could get medical training.  So when the book sort of ends right before World War I
column13: we have a handful of black medical schools that are functioning
column14: that are graduating black doctors
column15: who want to become part of sort of this talented 10th class.  But
column16: they are just a handful
column17: and those doctors have a kind of political consciousness that I talk about.  That they manage to combine medical expertise in an almost urban sophistication with their political activism.  But it’s very different than the kind of challenges to white authority that we see from black soldiers
column18: or from slaves
column19: so the story really shifts when we start talking the kind of era of segregation
column20: the ways in which black doctors and patients are able to mount any kind of protest is really shaped by the kind of larger American order.

column2: in the end then
column3: the role of health care in the black community paints a picture of the entire movement from slavery to freedom?

column1: GL: Yeah that's right and it plays and integral part in the development of the community in the midst of incredibly cynical suffering that a lot of black soldiers
column2: and their families and freed people in contraband camps are really suffering during the war
column3: and just after there the small pox epidemic
column4: there’s a lot of poverty in cities
column5: there’s a cholera epidemic in 1866
column6: but through all this in advocating for the care they do get even though it is scant
column7: and for advocating for medical education even though it is often substandard
column8: they really seize on their rights and their kind of language that helps them present themselves as freed people.

column2: I appreciate you taking the time to sit and discuss your most recent work
column3: Doctoring Freedom: The Politics of African American Medical Care.

column1:
GL: Thank you for having me.

" Frawley
column2: Michael Spring 2013 2013-05-01 Interview University of North Carolina Press ""

5207 9787-0-8078-3542-5 $40.00 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
The Civil War in the West: Victory and Defeat from the Appalachians to the Mississippi Hess
column2: Earl J.			"<h3>Interview with Earl J. Hess
column3: the Stewart W. McClelland Chair in history at Lincoln Memorial University

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview

column2: Professor Earl J. Hess
column3: the Stewart W. McClelland Chair in History at Lincoln Memorial University
column4: joins me to discuss his most recent work
column5: The Civil War in the West: Victory and Defeat from the Appalachians to the Mississippi. Professor Hess
column6: thank you for joining me today.

column1: Earl Hess (EH): You’re welcome and good morning. I’m happy to be here.
CWBR:You focus your study on the western armies and the activity in the western theater. What are some of the strengths and limitations of a geographic study of the Civil War?
EH: That’s an interesting question. I think some of the strengths are that we have a tendency
column2: maybe
column3: to under-appreciate the strength of regional identity in the 1860s in America.  Even though
column4: I think a lot of people are aware of that
column5: but still it is good to understand why we should think about that and have some deep awareness about what were the different characteristics of the regions of the United States and how they conducted the war.  I think there were some real differences between the West and the East and that is why
column6: in the book
column7: I often refer to the “western way” of conducting the Civil War on the part of the Federals.  There are four to five themes that could be discussed in that regard.  One of them was an almost overwhelming self-confidence that the western Federals developed in their ability to handle their Confederate enemy.  That
column8: as many of the readers of Civil War military history know did not exist very well in the East for various reasons.  You have Robert E. Lee in the East
column9: of course
column10: and in the West you had different Confederate commanders and you had a lot of Confederate problems in the West versus the Confederate strengths in the East and a lot of Union strengths in the West that countered-balanced all that sort of thing.  In terms of limitations
column11: of doing something like this
column12: I guess maybe you can lose a sense of cooperation and I try to compensate for that by pointing out the numerous ways in which the East and the West cooperated with each other
column13: not only the Union side but the Confederate side as well.  People know about the 11th and 12th Corps coming to Chattanooga after the Union defeat at Chickamauga in ’63 but
column14: you know
column15: the 23rd Corps went to the East and an awful lot of black regiments that were raised in Kentucky in 1862
column16: most of them were shipped to the East and served in the Army of the James which
column17: I think
column18: is kind of interesting and not very well known. There was an awful lot of regional cooperation. Most of the troops down in the Department of the Gulf were northeastern troops instead of western troops. There were very few troops from the western states down there in the New Orleans area.

column1: CWBR: I wonder how is the focus on the western soldier beneficial? Did he have a unique perspective on the war and the way that he looked at the big picture?
EH: I think there is an argument to be made about that. I think the western soldier
column2: because of Shiloh
column3: tended to feel like they were surprised at Shiloh and in April of ’62 they came close to losing but they persisted; they fought very hard
column4: they defeated the Confederates in battle
column5: at least in their view.  And beginning with that and successive victories after that they developed a really
column6: really striking self-confidence that
column7: I think
column8: historians and readers ought to pay a little more attention to as a major emotional factor in the winning of the war in the West.  Western soldiers
column9: as they continued to be successful also were quite aware that their compatriots in the East (I am talking about Union soldiers) were not being successful.  They read in the newspapers about defeats at Second Bull Run and then Fredericksburg and Chancellorsville and they tended to be kind of disgusted by that and they felt like their counterparts in blue in Virginia were not pulling their weight in terms of winning the Civil War.  And so you can see some very striking commentary in their letters and diaries about that issue.  It is not just the rank and file as Grant and Sherman also paid keen attention to all of that and I think they were getting kind of disgusted by the fact that the eastern Federals were not doing all they could do to keep Lee occupied.  I think that the dispatch of Longstreet and two divisions from the Army of Northern Virginia to help win the Confederate victory at Chickamauga was something of a turning point in the mindset of Grant and Sherman
column10: feeling that after they got the situation righted at Chattanooga in November of ’63 that something really needed to be done to better coordinate efforts East and West.  And when Grant was given a chance to command all Union forces
column11: he really implanted that concept.  If there really was a western way of war in the Civil War
column12: I think Grant brought it with him in March of ’64 to Virginia and
column13: to a large degree
column14: was successful in planting that concept over the whole Union war effort.

column1: CWBR: You mentioned cooperation between East and West and I wonder what challenges did Union officers in the West have to overcome considering their distance from Washington and how did they get the administration invested in a war so far away when they are so concerned with defending the city itself?

column2: I think the western commanders were better off because of the distance from Washington because they had less interference from the politicians and I think they had a bit more freedom to develop a war effort as they wanted to in the West.  Obviously
column3: they needed financial support; they needed other things too
column4: that were basic to conducting the war effort.  It seems like there is a lot less political interference in the Union war effort in the western states than there is in Virginia.  And that may well be a factor in helping to develop this successful western way of war as opposed to the (in a degree in a way) the unsuccessful way of conducting the war in the Virginia theater
column5: at least before Grant got there and kind of changed things around a little bit in the spring of ’64.  I also make the point in the book that I really think that Lincoln
column6: who
column7: of course
column8: was Kentucky-born and lived in Indiana and in Illinois
column9: he was a westerner
column10: through and through.  He seems to have paid a lot more attention to the western theater and was pretty keen about doing
column11: I think
column12: the right thing to support there.  Jefferson Davis was
column13: of course
column14: also western-born in Kentucky too and he lived in Mississippi in the 1850s and et cetera
column15: but he seemed to have paid less attention
column16: or at least-maybe it is not fair to say he paid less attention-but his handling of western generals was less astute than his handling of Lee. And there is an interesting dichotomy there between Richmond and Washington in terms of how they viewed the West and how they handled-and the success with which they handled-the western forces.

column1: CWBR: You speak a great deal about the ways that occupation challenged the western armies. How did this influence their course of war and what did the occupation period indicate about both Confederate morale and the ability of Reconstruction after the war?
EH: There are some big questions here. It is a developing argument in the literature over the past few years. A lot more interest is being drawn to occupation problems in the Civil War
column2: especially guerrilla activity.  I did not have room in my book to get into a really big
column3: detailed discussion of all this but I do not really see guerrilla activity or necessarily civilian problems
column4: in general
column5: as necessarily guiding
column6: in important ways
column7: the general course of the way the North fought the Civil War.  That is an arguable point
column8: of course.  I really focus in my book on things that were integral to the movement of troops across deep
column9: large
column10: expansive enemy territory.  How do you do that?  You utilize effectively available technology like steamboats on the river system or railroad equipment where the rivers do not offer you the same opportunity as steamboats.  And
column11: obviously
column12: commanders have an awful lot of problems to deal with in terms of dealing with
column13: sometimes troublesome civilians or with civilians who take guns and take to the woods and start taking pot shots at Union soldiers.  If you read through the dispatches of Union generals in the West
column14: three-fourths
column15: eighty percent of what they are discussing are issues like this.  And maybe only twenty to twenty-five percent of the time they are discussing how to move troops and how to deal with organized Confederate troops on the frontier between Union-controlled territory and Confederate-controlled territory.  But at the same time
column16: I do not see any clear links between anger over guerrilla attacks translating itself into a greater desire to burn more territory or burn more resources to punish the South.  That effort to try to burn resources
column17: to consume Confederate food yourself
column18: that kind of stuff
column19: all of that is hard war policy and has a half a dozen major origins.  It can range all the way from a simple desire by young Union soldiers who are hungry and they are not getting enough food from their commissary so they want more food so they just naturally go out on their own to take food from civilians.  That is the most fundamental reason why you have this developing and there are other reasons.  There are real limitations to the Union supply system.  The Union resources were not inexhaustible and the ability to transport supplies was not unlimited so a lot of times Union soldiers did go hungry because their commissaries could not provide them with
column20: even their regular
column21: rations.  It is true that some people did get angry at guerrilla attacks and think that they should burn in retaliation; that
column22: of course
column23: did happen too.  But there are many
column24: many different streams of meeting that hard war policy.  I disagree
column25: for example
column26: with Daniel Sutherland argument in his recently-published award-winning book on the guerrilla war in the Civil War that it was a major factor in leading to the hard war policy and in altering the northern war effort.  I am not sure that that is a supportable argument.  But I think that there were two things going on here; I do not think that they necessarily relate to each other.  It is the organization and transportation and fighting of organized forces
column27: won by the Union against the Confederates
column28: but then there is a plethora of problems that commanders had to deal with in terms of occupying the ever-growing area of the South that Union soldiers no controlled.  I think that the Union side of the Civil War did a wonderful job winning that first problem and never really came up with truly effective (consistently effective) policies of dealing with the second problem.  I think they experimented a lot in dealing with occupation issues.  Sometimes it worked
column29: oftentimes it did not.  In the end
column30: it was the ending of the organized war that finally brought peace to the occupied areas and finally that is when guerrilla fighting completely evaporated everywhere by 1865.

column1: CWBR: On the flip side to guerrilla warfare
column2: you do mention
column3: on several occasions
column4: where white southerners throughout the war welcome the invading northern troops. What accounts for this and how common was that occurrence during the war?

column1: EH: The North would have liked to believe that there was a huge reservoir of Loyalists in the Confederacy and
column2: of course
column3: in some pockets there were
column4: especially in East Tennessee.  That
column5: of course
column6: the biggest example.  The overwhelming majority of southerners in the mountainous counties in eastern Tennessee were Loyalist and vigorously Loyalist
column7: willing to die for their beliefs.  You have a lot of Loyalists in northern Alabama  and western North Carolina
column8: here and there.  Even in some of the areas of the South that are overwhelmingly pro-Confederate
column9: you find a few Loyalists here and there.  And
column10: you know
column11: the same was true in the American Revolution where you found Loyalists to the Crown
column12: especially in the southern colonies in the 1770s.  How do you account for it?  I am not sure that historians have answered that question; I do not think that necessarily I have either.  I actually live here in East Tennessee and so the idea of mountain Loyalism is very keen here and people know about it and they are interested it.  I do not think that any historian has yes really dug deep enough to try to deeply understand why that was so and they have a tendency to just
column13: kind of
column14: say that it was so and look at the effects of it in the 1860s.  There are a number of different reasons.  There can be some sort of anti-slave attitude and certainly it is true that the mountain Loyalists detested slavery
column15: not because they were abolitionists but because they hated the fact that the ownership of slaves created an elite caste in southern society and so
column16: to a degree it is a sort of class consciousness going on there.  The East Tennessee Loyalists tended to be very racist on top of that but that does not mean that their loyalism to the flag and the hatred of the planter aristocracy was any less.  And
column17: to a large degree
column18: the Union troops were keen to seek these people out and utilize them and
column19: of course
column20: as everyone knows
column21: an awful lot of southerners served in blue.  Every seceded state contributed troops to the Union army
column22: some of them more than others.  And that did weaken the strength of the Confederacy and its ability to opt for independence.  I do not know that it necessarily was the fatal weakness but it certainly was one of the many weaknesses to CSA defeat
column23: especially in the West.  One point I make in the book is that the key difference in the West is geography; it is a huge
column24: expansive area in the western Confederacy compared to the eastern Confederacy and so it has a lot more different problems
column25: a lot more different aspects to it than the war in the East tended to.

column2: for every stalemate that we have in the eastern theater there is a victory and some headway made in the West by Union forces.  In terms of morale and maintaining foreign neutrality
column3: was the West the Union lifeline to victory overall?

column1: EH: That is a nice way to put it. I agree with you. That is a good way to express it. I am not sure that contemporaries
column2: or certainly contemporaries in the West
column3: were keenly aware that they were winning the war.  I am talking about contemporaries so northern civilians in Illinois
column4: Wisconsin
column5: etc.  The press in the East tended
column6: of course
column7: to be focused on their region so they tended to be focused on the stalemate and etc.  And for some reason
column8: an awful lot of foreign governments like the many people in the British government and the French government tended to focus on what was going in Virginia and probably did not pay as much attention as they should have to what was taking place in the West.  So you often have scares in Washington
column9: D.C. about British recognition and all that sort of stuff.  Henry Halleck wrote a letter to William Rosecrans in December of ’62 when Rosecrans was preparing to lead the Union army out of Nashville against Bragg’s army at Murfreesboro that resulted in the battle of Stone’s River and Halleck informed Rosecrans that Lincoln is very
column10: very concerned that when the British Parliament meets in January that it might recognize the CSA based on the horrible defeats at Fredericksburg and that sort of stuff.  And so they really kind of painted a picture to Rosecrans as if his campaign in December of ’62 that resulted in the battle of Stone’s River might be the turning point in the Civil War.  That is recognition that if the East is doing badly the West has an opportunity to try to take up the slack and
column11: I think that
column12: in the long run
column13: that is exactly what did happen.  To me
column14: that is one more way of seeing the West as the decisive theater of the Civil War.  And certainly it is true that
column15: by early ‘65
column16: the western war is basically won and the eastern war is not yet finished.  That is
column17: of course
column18: a big reason that Sherman decides to lead 60
column19: 000 tough
column20: western Union soldiers
column21: veterans of many successful campaigns and battles
column22: to Virginia to give the final blow to Lee’s hopes of holding onto Petersburg and Richmond.  It is interesting to imagine Sherman and
column23: by that time
column25: 000 (Schofield’s 23rd Corps was added to it)
column26: what would have happened if Lee had stayed at Petersburg and allowed Sherman to join with Grant with those 80
column27: 000 troops.  You would have had an interesting development
column28: an interesting campaign and set of battles to end the Petersburg campaign at that stage.  To me
column29: it is a telling commentary of how successful the West was
column30: that Sherman was able to take such a huge army and march it hundreds of miles to help end the war in Virginia.

column2: how did black enlistment change the war for both northern and southern in the western theater?
that is an interesting point.  In a very superficial way
column3: you could say that it adds 180
column4: 000 troops to the Union army; that is a very; that is a gigantic contribution and even though most of those 180
column5: 000 black troops did not participate heavily in combat
column6: they performed essential roles.  The vast majority of garrisons that were necessary to protect the Mississippi River after the fall of Vicksburg consisted of black troops.  Something like forty percent
column7: I believe
column8: of all black troops raised by the Union army over all in the Civil War were raised along the banks of the Mississippi River and those troops served almost their entire service guarding the Mississippi for northern commerce and Union military logistical support from July 4
column10: until the end of the war.  That is the kind of service that does not get much publicity or credit because people tend to focus on the battlefield instead of this sort of thing but it is fundamentally important.  In less obvious ways
column11: in other words and maybe in ways that are difficult to appreciate
column12: in a kind of fundamental
column13: underlying way
column14: the recruitment of 180
column15: 000 blacks into the Union army
column16: in a practical military sense that had a big import.  You could look at it another way.  Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation
column17: which was the precedent for recruiting troops was arguably unconstitutional
column18: certainly on shaky grounds.  But once you go putting 180
column19: 000 black men into blue uniforms and give them a rifle and train them how to shoot it
column20: that confirms that there is not going to be any backsliding in American history to try to resurrect some form of legal slavery or anything like that.  It was
column21: I think
column22: a necessary important political and morale step intermediate between the Emancipation Proclamation and the Thirteenth Amendment which was passed by Congress in
column23: I believe
column24: late 1864 or early1865 perhaps.  On the Confederate side
column25: the Confederates
column26: as everyone knows
column27: toyed with the idea of possibly raising black troops
column28: finally did so very late.  Whether they would have had success if they had the chance
column29: at the time
column30: to put it more fully into effect no one can tell.  And
column33: the deployment of black Union troops on the battlefield tended to infuriate Confederate troops who oppose them
column34: resulting in infamous massacres of black troops at Fort Pillow
column35: for example which I briefly discuss in the book and in the eastern theater too.  And also maltreatment
column36: even if they are not being massacred
column37: often when black Union soldiers were captured by Confederate soldiers they were mistreated or they were sold back into slavery or they were used as labor instead of being treated as POWs as well.

column2: perhaps with broader ramifications: At what point was the war in the West officially settled in your eyes?
in terms of major activity by mainline forces
column3: with Hood’s defeat at Nashville in mid-December of ’64
column4: coupled with the decision to transfer what was left of the Army of Tennessee to North Carolina.  Conceivably
column5: if Hood’s force had remained in Mississippi after December of ’64 it might have done some more work too but after it was decided to shift Hood’s forces
column6: now under Johnston
column7: over to North Carolina that kind of ended it.  There was the matter of mopping up after that and there are some campaigns.  Of course
column8: there is Wilson’s big cavalry raid going through Alabama and into western Central Georgia by the end of the war and there is Canby’s long
column9: long-deferred major operation to capture Mobile in March and April of ’65.  But in hindsight
column10: you can see that both operations could easily have not happened and the war would have come to an end when it did anyway but nobody could have foreseen that then. But those kinds of mopping up operations are natural in such a huge expanse of theater of operations like the West where there are lots and lots of targets. And you have significant numbers of Union troops around so you might as well use them and wind up the war because you do not know when it is going to end until it does end.

column1: CWBR: You have spent a great deal of time
column2: in general
column3: in studying both eastern and western theaters.  In your mind
column4: was the United States Army of the Tennessee the most effective fighting force ever assembled?

column2: I would tend to say that.  Given the comparatively modest size of that field force
column3: barely going above 30
column4: 000 men at any time period
column5: and given its limited resources in terms of well-trained staff officers
column6: in terms of well-trained engineers
column7: it improvised an awful lot.  It had a lot of tough fighting ability and a lot of stamina
column8: high morale and tremendous faith in their leaders
column9: especially Grant and Sherman and McPherson.  I think they probably liked Howard maybe a little bit less but I would
column10: in fact
column11: argue that Oliver Otis Howard was a better commander of the army than McPherson was.  McPherson made some real mistakes in the Atlanta campaign even though he was a bright guy and a good guy.  So
column12: yes
column13: I would say so and
column14: on the other end of the spectrum
column15: the Confederate Army of Tennessee
column16: Bragg’s force and Johnston’s force
column17: of course
column18: put in the least impressive record
column19: I guess you could say of combat effectiveness and successful campaigns
column20: not necessarily because of any faults that rest on the shoulders of the rank and file but for a variety of other reasons too
column21: I suppose.  And the Army of the Cumberland
column22: I would argue
column23: is one of the more impressive field forces in terms of high levels of professionalism and innovative administrative efforts and all sorts of other things going on there too.  So
column24: I think the western theater really provided some interesting stories and histories of different units from the field armies on down to regiments that are unique in American military history.

column2: thank you for taking the time today to discuss The Civil War in the West: Victory and Defeat from the Appalachians to the Mississippi.

I enjoyed it. Thank you.

column2: Defeat
column3: and Freedom at the End of the Civil War		Varon
column4: Elizabeth R.			"<h3>Interview with Elizabeth Varon
column5: the Langbourne M. Williams Professor of American History at the University of Virginia

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Elizabeth Varon
column2: the Langbourne M. Williams Professor of American History at the University of Virginia
column3: and discuss her recent book <i>Appomattox: Victory
column4: Defeat
column5: and Freedom at the End of the Civil War. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: Elizabeth Varon (EV): It is a delight to do so
column2: thank you.

column1: CWBR: What drew you to this topic?

column2: some years ago
column3: I was asked by the Library Company of Philadelphia to give a talk about Juneteenth:  the moment of emancipation in Texas.  And in the course of researching Juneteenth
column4: I kept running across references in African-American discourse
column5: spanning the immediate post-war era right up through the early 20th Century
column6: to Appomattox as a “freedom day
column7: ” commemorated as sort of a hallmark in the process of emancipation. Those references alluded to an image of Appomattox as a day of liberation for slaves--the exact moment of emancipation
column8: for many…the day that fulfilled the promises of the earlier Emancipation Proclamation
column9: the day that some slaves knew for the first time that they were free
column10: or that others were able to truly experience freedom for the first time
column11: now that the principal institution of the Confederacy
column12: Lee's army
column13: had met its demise.  It was also a day
column14: in African American commemoration
column15: of black liberation at the hands of African American liberators.  This was a key element to the remembrance of the day:   seven regiments of the United States Colored Troops had participated in the final campaign that culminated in Lee's surrender.  They had been instrumental in blocking Lee's escape route
column16: setting the trap that Lee tried
column17: unsuccessfully
column18: to punch a hole through on the morning of April 9. This was understood to have an enormous symbolic importance in the eyes of commentators.  We can see this in African American sermons and speeches
column19: including the landmark studies of George Washington Williams
column20: the eminent historian who was a veteran of the Appomattox campaign:   the treatment of Appomattox as a freedom day
column21: and as a day that proved the fitness of the free people for citizenship.   In this post war discourse on Appomattox
column22: there was an effort to fuse the emancipationist and reconciliationist modes of Civil War remembrance
column23: to argue that the Union victory (and the centrality of African Americans to the Union's victory) were proof of the fitness for citizenship of the freedpeople
column24: and also a moment that heralded a promise of interracial reconciliation. For me
column25: this discovery drew me towards the surrender. And my preliminary research confirmed that our dominant view of the surrender as a “gentlemen's agreement” does not do justice to the complex meaning and legacy of this event.

column1: CWBR: Why was the campaign that led to Appomattox just as important as the surrender itself?
EV: That's right. There has been a tendency
column2: a temptation
column3: to think of that last campaign as a postscript to the great decisive “turning points” of the war. But that was not how the men who participated in the campaign saw it. They believed that the fate of the war effort still hung in the balance in those early days of April 1865. For men on the Union side
column4: it wasn't just the fact of their victory but the way they had won it that loomed large. They would emphasize
column5: in their accounts
column6: that it took enormous skill and courage and discipline to chase down Lee's army
column7: in those last days. For African Americans
column8: the campaign had an additional level of symbolic meaning. Confederates
column9: by contrast
column10: are grappling at the moment of defeat with two competing narratives of these final days of fighting. One of those narratives
column11: enshrined in Lee's Farwell Address
column12: stresses the steadfastness and blamelessness of Lee's men in this moment of defeat. The other narrative
column13: however
column14: is a far more troubling narrative for Confederates. It is a story
column15: perhaps
column16: of a failure of will
column17: and tactical and strategic mistakes
column18: of disillusionment and desertion and disintegration. This is a story that is unbearable for Confederates. It leaves them vulnerable to self-doubt and recrimination
column19: and so we see them push it to the side
column20: and to instead enshrine the story encapsulated in Lee's Farewell Address:  the story of the Confederates having been overwhelmed by the brutal Yankee war machine
column21: a story that fixates on the issue of odds. The Confederates will claim that they faced
column22: in the end
column23: during that last week and on the morning of April 9
column24: in particular
column25: worse odds than they had ever faced before in the war--odds of five to one or even worse--and that those terrible odds had necessitated Lee's surrender.

column1: CWBR: So the ratio of Union to Confederate soldiers at Appomattox was extremely important to how Reconstruction developed?

EV: A numbers game emerges and it has profound political implications. So--we can establish in hindsight that there were roughly thirty thousand Confederates and roughly sixty thousand Union troops in the vicinity of Appomattox Courthouse on that last day on April 9. The Confederates will claim
column2: following Lee's lead
column3: that they had faced much worse odds
column4: in the end:  again
column5: odds of five to one or worse
column6: rather than two to one. (Lee had often beaten odds two to one earlier in the war.) They will claim that
column7: in the end
column8: they had only the eight thousand effective infantrymen that were really ready to fight--and that they faced a Yankee army of one hundred to two hundred thousand
column9: and more
column10: and so on. My point in the book is that Lee's reference in his Farewell Address to the “overwhelming numbers and resources” of the Yankees was political
column11: and has to be put in the context of Confederate ideology:   that the numbers game had political implications. For Confederates
column12: “numbers”--the very phrase--conjured up images of the Yankee army's ruthless mercenaries and hirelings. “Resources” conjured up the dark satanic mills of northern capitalists. The numbers game
column13: in other words
column14: was part and parcel of an indictment of the North
column15: an indictment that had its roots in proslavery and secessionist ideology
column16: and that was translated during the war into the charge that the Yankees did not fight fair.  This was important politically because Lee knew
column17: as those who rallied around his “overwhelming numbers” interpretation of Confederate defeat knew
column18: that by denying the legitimacy of the North's military victory
column19: they could deny the North the right to impose its political will on the South after the war.

column2: as the importance of the surrender document
column3: Lee's Farewell Address
column4: the correspondence between Lee and Grant
column5: and other writings show
column6: during the Appomattox campaign itself the war shifted from one of bullets to one of words.

column1: EV: Yes and no. I do think the war effectively ends at Appomattox. We will sometimes use war as a metaphor to describe the political battles of the postwar period--and we should be careful not to push that too far. The surrender does end the massive bloodletting of these two giant armies; although there is fighting after Appomattox and the surrenders that follow in its wake
column2: the hopes for Confederate independence
column3: I think
column4: died at Appomattox. In some important sense
column5: the war ends. But a war of words does begin. You are right about that. A big argument of my book is that we tend to see the artifacts of the surrender--the letters Lee and Grant exchanged
column6: the terms themselves
column7: the parole passes that are issued to Confederates
column8: the Farewell Address of Lee--we tend to see these things as transparent in meaning. I am trying to make the case that these artifacts of the surrender as all sources of contention. The parole passes are sort of a perfect case in point
column9: speaking about this emerging war of words. So Lee and Grant meet a second time on April 10. Lee requests of Grant that each of Lee's men be issued a printed parole certificate confirming that that soldier came under the Appomattox terms. Grant accedes to this request.  Grant does so in part because he imagines that these certificates will remind the Confederates of the obligations attendant upon their status as paroled prisoners of war--that is what they are-- and remind them that their freedom was contingent on their good behavior. The parole passes contain a clause that ends up becoming quite a troublesome clause. In keeping with the language of the terms themselves
column10: the parole certificates vouch that if a soldier observes the law where he resides
column11: then that soldier was not to be “disturbed.” While Union men imagined that these parole certificates would be a reminder of their obligations
column12: the Confederates interpreted the parole certificates
column13: and the very language in them--the not to be disturbed clause in particular--as a kind of promise that honorable Confederate men would not be treated dishonorably but the Yankees. In other words
column14: the paroles
column15: in Confederate eyes
column16: imposed conditions on the North.

column1: CWBR: Lee has come down to us today as a person who stayed out of politics after the war
column2: clearly though this was not the case
column3: why is our perception so different from reality?

column1: EV: Our perception is grounded in two facts. First of all
column2: Lee did technically observe the terms of his parole.  And he did accept military defeat and reject the option of guerrilla warfare.  But we miss the subtlety and dissonance in Lee's post war comportment
column3: and I think generally it is underrated how political a man and how savvy a man Lee was. Lee was not a symbol of submission in the eyes of Confederates after the war. He was a symbol of defiance. In all of the artifacts to which I have alluded
column4: and also in a postwar interview that he does with the New York Herald
column5: and congressional testimony he gives in February of 1866
column6: Lee is pointing the way to the restoration of the South's power within the Union. Restoration is Lee's political keyword. For him it reflects the nostalgia
column7: not uncommon for the men of his background
column8: nostalgia for the days of the early republic
column9: which in his mind are halcyon days before the Union had fallen from grace
column10: before African Americans had been imbued with false hope--a time when the rest of the nation seemed to assume that Virginia would lead the nation. Lee was nostalgic for this kind of imaginary period of equilibrium. In his mind
column11: a just peace will undo the “grievous effects” of the war
column12: as he puts it
column13: and sort of restore the old virtues. Now
column14: in the service of this vision of restoration
column15: Lee behaves politically. He denies the existence of anti-black violence in the South. He makes this denial quite brazenly as he testifies before the congressional committee. In his interview with the New York Herald
column16: he essentially argues that if the North gives up the policy of magnanimity—if it turns to vengeance or to vindictive or arbitrary policies--Southerners would consider the surrender terms as breached.   Indeed there is this notion
column17: I think
column18: on the part of Confederates
column19: that Lee had drawn a line in the sand at Appomattox--that Lee's position was
column20: ""You can ask us to surrender our arms
column21: but you shouldn't ask anything more from us. We will yield
column22: but we will do nothing more."" This is a sort of defiance
column23: and again we can come back to the artifacts of the surrender. The parole passes
column24: that “not to be disturbed” clause
column25: will reverberate in political debates. As Republicans will try to give freedpeople a measure of civil rights and civil protections
column26: and begin discussing the possibility of African American suffrage
column27: Confederates will turn to them and say that this radical agenda is a contravention of the Appomattox covenant
column28: if you will--of the promise that white southern men will not be disturbed. They will literally say the prospect of black citizenship “disturbs” the South and therefore represents a betrayal of the Appomattox terms. There is a very complex political dynamic here. My point is that the terms and the artifacts of the surrender were a touchstone for these political debates during Reconstruction and that Lee is very much implicated in these debates.

column1: CWBR: Grant and Lee then were representative of their societies
column2: one looking to the future and the other to the past?

column1: EV: I think that that is right. Grant has an entirely different interpretation of the surrender than Lee does. In Lee's mind
column2: the surrender was a negotiation in which he secures honorable terms for his blameless men. In Grant's eyes
column3: the surrender is a vindication of the cause of Union
column4: of the ability of citizen-soldiers to out fight the conscripts and dupes of an autocratic society. It is a vindication of freedom:  and it will clear and open the way for the Union's ethos of moral and material progress to enter the South. Grant's terms are very much intended to effect a sort of mass conversion on the part of Southerners. He believes that the terms should foster a spirit of repentance and atonement. Again
column5: Lee's position was that the Southerners had nothing to atone for. Grant's position was that the Union's magnanimity and its mercy were emblems of its moral authority
column6: its moral superiority even
column7: and that mercy should effect atonement and repentance. These are fundamentally different views
column8: but in the book I stress that these debates over the terms don’t simply pit Union against Confederacy or North versus South. They pit those who favor a transformation of the South against those who oppose it
column9: and you will find Northerners and Southerners on both sides of that divide. The Peace Democrats
column10: for example
column11: “Copperheads” in the North
column12: are loath for the Lincoln administration
column13: Republicans
column14: to interpret the surrender as a mandate for the Republican party.  So the Copperheads embrace Lee's interpretation of the surrender:  the “overwhelming numbers” interpretation of Southern defeat
column15: Lee's notion that the Union victory was a victory of might over right. Southern Unionists
column16: African Americans obviously
column17: and some white southern Unionists
column18: too
column19: embrace Grant's view of the surrender:  the Union victory as a victory of right over wrong.  So we see fault lines
column20: but we have to be very careful when acknowledging divisions within each society.

column1: CWBR: Did the assassination of Lincoln magnify the meaning of Appomattox and make it much more important than it would have been had Lincoln lived?

column2: in a sense
column3: in regard to the assassination
column4: is on continuity. I try to show the heated debate about the meaning of the surrender begins before Lincoln died. Its interpretive lines persist after his death. If we look at Civil War historiography
column5: we can see quite plainly that the assassination has utterly overshadowed the surrender. There has been an assumption in studying the assassination that Booth turns Northerners away from magnanimity and towards vengeance. I found something a little different. First of all
column6: Northerners interpret the assassination as a direct response to the surrender. They believe that Booth is trying
column7: through his deed
column8: to undo or undermine the Union victory. We do see many Northerners call for vengeance in the wake of the assassination
column9: but we see many others
column10: in a sort of call-and-response
column11: answer that cry for vengeance by upholding magnanimity and mercy--Lincoln's policy
column12: Grant's policy--on the grounds that the best way to honor Lincoln's death is to uphold this idea of mercy. In other words
column13: this notion that mercy was an emblem of the North's moral authority proves very potent and popular
column14: and I found that was true even among Radical Republicans
column15: many of whom thought the best fate for the likes of Jefferson Davis and Robert E. Lee was to have to live in the brave new world that the Union victory has created.

column1: CWBR: Why did Appomattox become a ""golden moment lost"" so quickly? Was there any real chance it was the golden moment many hoped it was?

EV: This “golden moment lost” phenomenon is really quite fascinating. Each of the three interpretations that I just outlined--the notion of the surrender as a vindication; the emphasis on the part of Southerners like Lee on restoration; and then the variation on vindication
column2: the emphasis of African Americans on liberation--each of these interpretive modes came to incorporate an argument about the lost promise of Appomattox. For Lee and his followers
column3: as I have suggested
column4: Radical Republicans betray the true meaning of the surrender by imposing a regime that contravenes the promise that southerners won’t be “disturbed.” For Grant and his followers
column5: it is Andrew Johnson who is the arch betrayer
column6: as he seems to capitulate to Lee's idea that the peace must bring the restoration of power to elite southerners. In the eyes of African Americans
column7: whites on both sides--both those who oppose and reject black citizenship but also those who give up the fight for it--let this moment of promise
column8: of Appomattox
column9: fade unfulfilled. I am trying to make two arguments about this. First of all I am asserting that there is never a moment of unity in this story. There is never a moment of shared reconciliation. There is never a moment when Southerners in unison mourn their lost cause and northerners in unison rejoice. There is never a moment in which Confederates are prepared to concede that their ideology has been discredited. In essence
column10: Northerners who embrace Grant's terms said to the South
column11: ""We don’t want to punish you any further
column12: we want you to change."" Southerners
column13: Confederates
column14: turned back and argued that the demand for change was a form of punishment. Northerners said “here is your chance to atone
column15: ” and Confederates responded that they had nothing to atone for. I don’t see much evidence of a true golden moment there. The battle lines were drawn very quickly. The terms became politicized very quickly. On the other hand
column16: I am trying to account for why the golden moment interpretation
column17: despite the fact that it was kind of wishful thinking
column18: why it had such power and resilience.  I observe that it tapped a strain of American exceptionalism:  that even as they grappled over the surrender terms
column19: Northerners and Southerners could
column20: and did
column21: congratulate themselves for ending their Civil War in a more civil way than any other nation had ever done before. I also try to account in other ways for the resilience of this golden moment idea. I stress
column22: for example
column23: as I have stressed in our talk here today
column24: that African Americans have had their own reasons for upholding the surrender as a golden moment. They believed that they had
column25: at the moment of the surrender
column26: won something
column27: and earned something
column28: and proven something that should never be taken away. So all of the various stakeholders had their own reasons for being intensely invested in the idea of the golden moment--and for charging their political rivals was having betrayed it.

column2: I appreciate you taking the time to sit and discuss your most recent work
column3: Appomattox: Victory
column4: Defeat
column5:
and Freedom at the End of the Civil War.

" Frawley
column6: Michael Winter 2014 2014-02-01 Interview Oxford University Press ""

column1:
4755 978-0-8078-3426-8 $35.00 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW
God's Almost Chosen Peoples: A Religious History of the American Civil War
Rable
column2: George C.			"<h3>Interview with George C. Rable
column3: Professor and holder of the Summersell Chair in Southern History at the University of Alabama

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): I’m here today with George Rable
column2: author of God’s Almost Chosen Peoples: A Religious History of the American Civil War. Professor Rable
column3: thank you so much for joining me.

column1: CWBR: You seem to give a very even-handed treatment of as many religions as possible in addition to looking at soldiers and the homefront
column2: men and women
column3: and white and black. How important was it for you to include this balance throughout your religious history of the Civil War?

column1: GR: Well my purpose was to write a comprehensive religious history of the war and I must admit
column2: as the project proceeded
column3: I was approached by a number of people asking me: “is my group going to be included” or “is my group going to be included
column4: ” so I was under a little bit of pressure even as I was working on the project but I thought if it was going to be a religious history of the war it should include as many groups as possible including non-believers.

column1: CWBR: So often we focus on what made the North and South dissimilar. Does a recognition of an “American” understanding of the war through religious avenues bring northerners and southerners together in this narrative; at the end of the day were they really very different religiously?

column2: in some ways
column3: they were not very different.  They both used similar religious frameworks to interpret the causes
column4: course
column5: and consequences of the war. They both put a great deal of emphasis on providence and judgment to explain what was happening to them and what was happening to their enemies as far as that goes. So I think studying religion actually does somewhat narrow the differences between the two sides though obviously I think they would disagree with that.

column1: CWBR: I was especially struck by your discussion of some of the Mormons in the West too who wondered about the South believing that God fought on their side and
column2: at the same time the North did
column3: and if both sides were correct that would lead to total annihilation. How did they reconcile that fact?

column1: GR: well I’m not sure they saw that particular contradiction or at least most people didn't see it. Occasionally you'll get comments from people saying “well you know the other side is praying just as hard as we are
column2: that may present a problem.”  More commonly
column3: the assumption was that the Lord could not possibly allow their enemies to win
column4: or could not possibly allow their country to fall
column5: could not allow the Union to be destroyed
column6: could not allow the Confederacy to be subjugated.

column1: CWBR: You seem to suggest a new point of contention
column2: the split of northern Methodists and southern Methodists
column3: and the Baptists as well in leading to secession.  How did these splits help to affect the coming of the Civil War
column4: and looking forward then
column5: how did the North-South split of these denominations influence post-war churches? Was it a legitimate and long-lasting influence for them?

column1: GR: Well both Henry Clay and John C. Calhoun thought that the divisions of the churches were quite ominous in the 1840s leading up to the heighted sectional conflict of the Civil War itself and I think that they were right. Now I’m not sure one would argue that the split in the churches was a cause of the war; it was more a symptom of sectional tensions over slavery than anything else. And of course the Presbyterians had split earlier and they did not split primarily over slavery. But the fact that the churches are divided at the beginning of the war certainly does not lend any encouragement to sectional compromise. In fact
column2: one of the more interesting things I discovered in the research were the comments of Catholic editors who pointed out that “well this is what you get when you have a Protestant nation
column3: when you have schism and division.”  If you had had a Catholic nation there would have been no sectional conflict and Civil War; the church universal would have been able to take care of that particular problem.  Now in terms of long-lasting impact
column4: obviously these religious divisions persisted a long time among the Methodists
column5: the Presbyterians
column6: and of course the Baptists are still divided to this day.

column1: CWBR: For a nation that was so seemingly well-churched in the antebellum period
column2: why do we see the debauchery and casting away of church services in camp during the early months of the war?

column1: GR: Well they're heavily churched but also remember that probably only a minority of Americans were actually members of churches in part because the bar of church membership was pretty high at that time especially in some of the evangelical denominations. On a typical Sunday you might have many more people in attendance than actual members of the congregation so I think that’s a factor. Plus you’re talking about young men and these are not the most religious segment of the population
column2: usually in that time or in our own
column3: and plus these are young men removed from the influences of home and family and so it’s not surprising that under the stresses of camp life and battle and war in general you would find a great deal of what the people of the time would certainly describe as absolute debauchery. Although I suspect they exaggerated the degree of that from time to time so it’s interesting. I think many of the more devout soldiers are absolutely convinced that a lot of their comrades are heathenish and I sort of take them at their word.

column2: President Lincoln officially calls into order the Emancipation Proclamation.  I wonder how this altered the message delivered by the southern clergy and
column3: in turn
column4: the message being given by the northern clergy to northerners on the homefront?

column1: GR: Well let’s start with the northern clergy first. Many of the northern clergy had been pushing for such a measure all along. The northern clergy of course had been divided
column2: some of the more conservative denominations like the old school Presbyterians had not been especially eager to embrace abolition or emancipation
column3: but once Lincoln issues that final proclamation even the more conservative churches come around.  They naturally interpret the war itself and the fact that war has continued
column4: a lot of them interpreted
column5: as God’s judgment on slavery and once you cast off
column6: what one minister called the Jonah of slavery
column7: maybe the Lord would bless the nation with victory.  So again it’s interpreted as this sort of cycle of sin and judgment and then redemption.  The southern clergy continually embraced the institution of slavery during the war as the biblically sanctioned institution.  What changes for the southern clergy during the war is that the southern clergy become increasingly critical of the behavior of slaveholders.  In other words
column8: slavery is not sinful in and of itself
column9: in the fact that they scripturally sanctioned institution
column10: but they become increasingly critical of the behavior of slaveholders for breaking up slave families through sale
column11: for neglecting the religious instruction of the slaves
column12: for not teaching slaves to read so that they were unable to read the scriptures.  So there’s a kind of reform movement that takes place during the war; the southern clergy advocate reform of the institution of slavery.  I don’t think they see this reform as leading to abolition and it’s interesting
column13: however
column14: that this reform gets absolutely nowhere.  Not a single one of these measures even reaches the floor of the state legislature or the Confederate congress; there’s some consideration committee
column15: but that’s it.</p.

column2: you speak increasingly of the revivalism that takes place throughout some of the southern armies but you suggest that it’s less common among the western armies in the Confederacy and I wonder is it too much of an oversimplification to wonder if this fact helps explain the consistency of the Army of Northern Virginia and the canonization of the Army of Northern Virginia in Civil War memory?

column1: GR: I think it certainly helps explain part of the canonization of the Army of Northern Virginia in the Civil War memory. Now if we could ask Stonewall Jackson that question
column2: I think he would certainly say the revivals would mark a blessing of God
column3: not only on the soldiers
column4: but on the army itself. And I think you could certainly argue that religion is quite important in sustaining the morale of armies but also keep in mind that there were revivals in the western armies as well they just came a little bit later and perhaps with less intensity and I think less organization.

column1: CWBR: What does the study of religion say about Confederate nationalism and also war support or war weariness in the North?
GR: Well I think religion is important part of Confederate nationalism. In fact
column2: you see such intense civil religion on both sides; you have presidents proclaiming days of fasting
column3: humiliation
column4: and prayer; presidents declaring official days of thanksgiving after victories; you have countless sermons preached and published on both sides on these special occasions as well as other occasions.  And I think religion is an important component of Confederate nationalism and it’s also an important component of American nationalism in general.  I don’t think the old thesis that somehow southerners were guilt-ridden and lost the will to fight and thought that God had turned against them really holds a great deal of water.  I think that there’s this persistent belief that God will somehow save them
column5: even at the last moment.</p.

column1: CWBR: Spending so much time with this topic
column2: would you maybe suggest that the war changed America’s outlook on religion or did their religious beliefs and spiritual outlook change their interpretation of the war as they were fighting it?

column1: GR: Well I think religious interpretation shaped their interpretation of the war
column2: there’s no question about that.  When you interpret battles in terms of divine favor and divine chastisement I don’t think there’s much doubt about that.  How much the war actually itself changed religious beliefs
column3: of course
column4: is a very difficult and complex question and I think a very debatable one.  Historians over the years have tended to emphasize a kind of disillusionment in the aftermath of war
column5: a disillusionment in civil religion
column6: though they focus most of their attention on intellectuals.  It seems to me that most Americans
column7: northerners and southerners in the aftermath of this war
column8: sought to rebuild their lives obviously in every way you can conceive and sought to rebuild their spiritual life as well and rebuild their church lives
column9: and were not so much interested any more in looking back at the issues of the war but they were simply interested in rebuilding their religious lives. And I must say I do not see the same amount of religious disillusionment in the aftermath of this war that some other historians have argued for.

column1: CWBR: Would you maybe suggest that the religious fervor and the rate at which Americans used religion to cope with the conflict
column2: is that unique to the American Civil War or might this simply be a traditional wartime response for any people?

column1: GR: I think the way religion was used during the Civil War
column2: if not unique
column3: was certainly more intense than any other war.  I know
column4: at one point in the book
column5: I do say that the American Civil War was the holiest war in American history and I certainly can’t think of any other war in which religion played such a large role.  Now obviously religion came into play in the American Revolution; religion comes into play in the War of 1812
column6: the Mexican War
column7: World War I
column8: World War II
column9: etc. but not nearly in the pervasive and all-encompassing sort of way as it did during the American Civil War.  I think it was a confluence of a lot of things
column10: first of all
column11: the Civil War itself was unique in the annals of American war and
column12: secondly
column13: it comes at a time of great religious expansion and fervor in America in general.

column2: and we touched on some of this earlier
column3: I’ve always been struck by the influence of Lee and Jackson’s piety on post-Civil War memory. How did their religious beliefs influence their role in the Lost Cause mentality and why don’t we find more of a sense of the Union generals’ piety in post-Civil War memory?

column1: GR: Well I think their religion was very important in Lost Cause memory because Lee and Jackson become kind of the ultimate Christian martyrs. In fact Jackson’s death leads to all kinds of soul-searching about why the Lord had taken Jackson away from the Confederacy just when they needed him most. And many pious Confederates simply concluded that
column2: first of all
column3: they might not be able to understand why God had done that and
column4: secondly
column5: perhaps they had put too much faith in Jackson or
column6: as they put
column7: it “too much faith in an arm of flesh” and God was punishing them for that reason.  Now I suppose the flip answer to why religion has not been as important in the memory of northern soldiers is
column8: perhaps
column9: that the more pious northern soldiers were not nearly as successful in the battlefield as Lee and Jackson.  O. O. Howard who probably
column10: in some ways
column11: is the ultimate Christian soldier in the North had a very rocky career in the eastern theater and a somewhat more successful career in the western theater.  George McClellan
column12: I must say somewhat to my surprise
column13: was remarkably religious as well and wrote things that could have easily been written by Robert E. Lee.  General Rosecrans was a very devout Catholic who loved to stay up late into the night discussing theology with various people including James Garfield
column14: the future president of the United States.  So I think there are certainly Christian generals on the northern side as well
column15: but they just weren’t as successful as lee and Jackson were.

column2: thank you so much for joining me and taking the time to discuss your recent book
column3: God’s Almost Chosen Peoples: A Religious History of the American Civil War.

column2: Nathan Winter 2011 2011-02-01 Interview University of North Carolina Press ""

column1:
4245 9780813927862 $29.95 hardcover "CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
""What Shall We Do with The Negro?"": Lincoln
column2: White Racism
column3: and Civil War America"		Escott
column4: Paul D.			"<h3>Interview with Dr. Paul D. Escott
column5: Reynolds Professor of History at Wake Forest University

column1: Click here for the audio version of the interview
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Your latest book is titled ""What Shall We Do with The Negro?"": Lincoln
column2: White Racism
column3: and Civil War America. Now in this book
column4: you attempt to revise what is really a celebratory depiction of Abraham Lincoln as the great emancipator by noting his reticence in many ways to ending the institution of slavery by force. How have historians
column5: in your opinion
column6: erred in chronicling Lincoln's record on the slavery issue?

column1: Paul D. Escott (PDE): There is a deep celebratory impulse in American popular culture in terms of the way we view our history. And historians have been emphasizing Lincoln’s racial progressivism and racial egalitarianism
column2: overemphasizing it I would say
column3: quite a bit in recent decades.  This has not always been the case. There were earlier periods in American history which people praised Lincoln highly because he was considerate of white southerners and did not push for rights for black people.  But it's notable that in the last couple of decades
column4: the emphasis on Lincoln as someone who worked for racial equality has gone a little too far. There are quite a number of things about Lincoln's policies that needed a careful reconsideration. I'll start
column5: I think
column6: by mentioning just a couple of them.

column1: One would have to do with his expectation on what might follow freedom; and another might have to do with the Thirteenth Amendment and where he stood on the process of ratification for it at the end of the war.  It's well known that before Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation
column2: he had repeatedly proposed plans of gradual
column3: compensated emancipation that could be voluntarily undertaken by the states
column4: acting on their own. He always linked those to colonization.  What people have said less about is that after the Emancipation Proclamation was issued
column5: he repeatedly talked about what he called temporary arrangements or apprenticeship.  Now apprenticeship may bring to mind Benjamin Franklin back in the 18th century
column6: and we may think of it as something that would give people an opportunity to rise in society.  But that kind of apprenticeship had almost completely died out in 19th century America.  This idea of apprenticeship would be a way for slaveholders to hold onto the labor of younger slaves for a period of time.  That was always a part of his plans for gradual emancipation.  After he proposed the Emancipation Proclamation
column7: he continued to talk about apprenticeship or temporary arrangements.

column1: What Lincoln had in mind comes through very clearly in the letter that he wrote to General John McClernand in early 1863.  In that letter
column2: he said to McClernand that if the southern states that are covered by the Emancipation Proclamation would adopt measures of apprenticeship
column3: they could be nearly as well off as if this trouble had not occurred. He would be trying to provide financial aid from the federal government
column4: and that would help them as well.  Lincoln continued to talk about apprenticeship or temporary arrangements as something that southern whites could expect once slavery came to an end.  And in his Amnesty Proclamation
column5: the one setting up the Ten Percent Plan for reestablishing southern governments
column6: he again talks about these temporary arrangements or apprenticeships that would be looked upon with favor by the president.  So I think that he was not expecting (and there's no evidence that he was pushing for) any drastic
column7: immediate change in the social and political situation of black people once slavery came to an end.

column1: What is also notable about the Thirteenth Amendment
column2: is that although Lincoln deserves a great deal of praise for pushing Congress to propose the Thirteenth Amendment and to put in place a measure that would be a part of our Constitution to bar slavery (not just a war measure as the Emancipation Proclamation was)
column3: the prospects of ratifying the Thirteenth Amendment without force or a requirement by the executive were very troubled.  It would take ten states to block the amendment.  The Confederacy of course claimed thirteen. There were eleven southern states that had actively participated in the Confederacy.  There were also three Union states that had voted heavily Democratic in 1864
column4: were not at all in Lincoln's camp
column5: and were likely to oppose ratification of the Thirteenth Amendment.

column1: Historians have not questioned that at the Hampton Roads Conference in February of 1865
column2: William Seward told southerners about the proposal of this amendment but also mentioned that he expected it not to be approved.  Up to the very time of his death
column3: Lincoln was still not insisting on ratification of the Thirteenth Amendment.  He was trying in various ways to offer incentives to white southerners to ratify the Thirteenth Amendment.  But he had not at all come to the point of requiring that.  And I think that that needs to be kept in mind in order for us to have a better understanding of what Lincoln's approach was and what his policy was.  He seemed very interested in first
column4: pursuing the priority of getting the Union back together
column5: and second
column6: in order to do that
column7: to offer incentives and means of conciliating white southerners so that they would participate in the process and take an active role in it
column8: rather than be coerced into reunion.

column1: CWBR: You contend in this book that the true legacy of the Civil War regarding race relations is what you call ""a sobering future of segregation and racial exploitation.” And yet the answer you just gave
column2: and in fact much of what you talk about in the book
column3: seems to suggest that there is a continuity of racism and troubled race relations from the antebellum years to the Civil War and into the years of Reconstruction. Did the legacy of racism from the antebellum period ease in any way or do you just see a fundamental continuity over the years of the Civil War and Reconstruction?

column1: PDE: I do see a tremendous amount of continuity. Racism was a very deep problem in the entire nation—North as well as South. My last chapter points out and analyzes the action of three northern states after the war came to an end. These states voted against proposals to let the small numbers of black people in their state vote as citizens following the end of the war. Racism did continue and there's a great deal of continuity there. The war really posed two problems or two questions. One was: what was going to be done about slavery. Following upon that was the next question
column2: which many newspapers and magazines were asking
column3: “What shall we do with the Negro?”

column1: You can see in the way that the question was asked that it was flawed by racism.  The white people asking that question were assuming that they could dispose of the Negro problem
column2: that they could decide what would be done with African Americans.  They weren't looking upon African Americans as members of the polity who would have a normal role to play.  It is striking that there was some change in racial attitudes in the North during the war. I was really surprised as I turned to a more careful study to the North (since most of my work had been done on the South) to see how quickly many magazines came around to the idea not only that slavery must be destroyed
