column16: as property thieves; they’re going to come and take my slaves and my livestock and my land and my senses and leave me a poor man.  That’s the issue that really crops up.  So
column17: in terms of doing these comparisons
column18: I really did start to see patterns and more and more it struck me that these patterns were pointing back toward home even in areas that I did not expect.  In looking at religion
column19: for example
column20: how many men did not participate in those great revivals that we are always reading about in the winters of 1862-1863 and 1863-1864.  For so many of them their religious experience was taking place among their comrades in their messes or in their letters as they were writing back home still trying to maintain that position as head of family worship.  Comradeship was certainly important but it was a comradeship that was with men from home
column21: relatives
column22: and kin and I was surprised to find that they seemed to have trouble making new bonds with men that they had met in the army.  So again and again the numbers and the words as well were pointing me back toward home and away from what I think is the dominant interpretation right now of soldiers in general
column23: which is that they were fighting for ideas.

column1: CWBR: Let’s talk about these ideas and the political ideology. What do your findings contribute to the long-time historical debate about Confederate nationalism? And I wonder how you might account for
column2: it seems to me you suggest a stronger
column3: more committed nationalism among the early enlisters in 1861 than we see later; you suggest that that nationalism did not wane and other scholars have suggested so. Why couldn’t this Confederate nationalism build within these later enlisters as they spent more time in the army and among the veteran soldiers?

column1: KN: Well it’s an interesting question. It doesn’t seem to. I think
column2: like the soldiers that Jerry Prokopowicz talks about
column3: their loyalty was more to company and to a certain extent regiment than it was to army or much less nation.  They just don’t write about nationalism that much; 61 out of my 320 mentioned any sort of political ideology but of those if you break it down
column4: and bear in mind some men are in several categories because they are writing about 3 or 4 different things
column5: I have about 10% who write about their country and as I said a few minutes ago most of them mention it once.  I have 5 or 6 fervent nationalists who write a lot about their country but for most of them it’s a passing phrase that pops up in a passage about something else.  We’ve read that the American Revolution was tremendously important to the Civil War generation.  Reid Mitchell was the first person who wrote about that and yet
column6: out of my 320
column7: only 9 of the men in my sample ever mentioned the American Revolution.  Nine percent
column8: 29 out of 320
column9: mentioned independence as a goal
column10: as a fact in some manner
column11: and most of them mentioned it once.  Subjugation is a word that James McPherson pointed us to
column12: this notion of being forced to knuckle under to the Lincoln administration and its political ideas including abolition.  They don’t write much about subjugation; I think I have 17 of them that mention the word once.  And finally states rights
column13: I mean growing up in Virginia I was taught year after year that Confederate soldiers had fought for states rights
column14: not for other issues
column15: and certainly not for slavery.  But in fact out of my 320
column16: I only had a dozen who ever mentioned anything that looked like states rights.  These men were not nationalists; they weren’t ideologists.  I suspect (I can’t prove it; I don’t have enough men who write about why they did not enlist in 1861 to do more than suggest) but I think that it was that lack of political fervor
column17: that lack of interest in those sorts of ideas that may have kept most of them out of the army when the war began.  But as the war dragged on and as the Union Army became more of an immediate threat to their homes
column18: their neighborhood
column19: their livelihood
column20: they were spurred to enlist.

column1: CWBR: You spend a great deal of time talking about the later enlisters and how they viewed their comrades and how they viewed the veteran soldiers who had joined in 1861. I wonder if the early enlisters write about their opinions of later-enlisting comrades. Were they considered equal on the battlefield and in camp or were they something of a newcomer
column2: not as dedicated to the cause.

column1: KN: Well I tended to look at these issues from the later enlisters point of view. I really didn’t spend a lot of time reading primary material from the earlier enlisters as they wrote about the new ones. I have looked at those sources for other projects from time to time and yeah I think there was a sense
column2: in many cases
column3: that these were men who were not as good as us
column4: not as fervent as us.  You know a lot of them are here for the bounty.  These are expressions that I have seen in both in Union sources and in Confederate sources.  The way the later enlisters saw it though
column5: when they arrive in regiments they are arriving in most cases as men who know where they are going.  They’re coming to particular companies and regiments when they can and various legislation makes that possible for them where they know people.  They are coming to this company and this regiment because their brother is there
column6: or their neighbor is there
column7: or somebody is there.  And I suspect that these transitions into those units
column8: to an extent that men going to brand-new regiments are certainly conscripts would not find when they came to the army.  As far as the later enlisters saw
column9: it they were just as good of soldiers as anyone else once they got there and they don’t really write about being shunned or unwelcome.

column1: CWBR: During your discussion of the widespread shift later in the book
column2: the shift away from card playing and rabble rousing in the southern armies
column3: these sorts of sinful acts as those morally-concerned soldiers call it.  On page 133
column4: you state that “what later enlisters now added to the mix was a pronounced family orientation that kept them mentally and spiritually connected to home.”  Is this shift away from these licentious acts
column5: is that simply due to an increasing likelihood of older
column6: married enlisters and the maturing of the veterans or is it just a general shift as the soldiers realized that war was not a party?

column1: KN: Well in a way I think it’s both. Yes in a way you are dealing with an older cohort; my men are a few years older than that average we always hear of 21 or 22 but I think that it’s important to look at when they come to the army. When we read these accounts of how wild and crazy camp was
column2: Steve Woodworth has done this beautifully
column3: we’re really looking at 1861 and 1862; we’re looking at men coming to the war without really knowing what the battle is going to look like.  My argument is that
column4: by the time later enlisters start showing up in Confederate ranks in February-March of 1862
column5: they’re joining a veteran army that has already by itself
column6: to an extent
column7: gone through that transition.  I mean yes there are some pious later enlisters who write about all the sinful acts they find in camp but I found a lot less of that than I expected and my sense is that the army itself
column8: that army of earlier enlisters
column9: had already made that transition because of the combat experience that had sobered them up.  So later enlisters
column10: yes they’re older men
column11: but they’re also arriving in
column12: to an extent
column13: more sober camps than those that had been in existence a year earlier. So to that extent the army was never as wild for them as I might have been for people who joined up.

column1: CWBR: In part of the larger discussion of maturing of the forces
column2: what caused the widespread shift toward religion that began in Stonewall Jackson’s Corps in the Army of Northern Virginia and its subsequent spread westward?  Was it
column3: as some scholars have suggested a conscious desire for southerners to legitimize their cause and give it a moral foundation?

column1: KN: Well I think there probably was some of that. For later enlisters
column2: in particular
column3: because they’re the ones I know the best it was a lot more personal.  I think it really was
column4: these are men who had a hard time leaving home.  By and large they did not want to be in the army.  They did enlist
column5: they were willing to fight
column6: they were certainly literally willing to fight but they wanted the war to end.  They loved to use that phrase “this cruel war.”  This was not a marvelous moment in their life
column7: for most of them it was a terrible thing that happened; they wanted to go home.  When they got to the army they were faced with the reality of death: death in camp
column8: death as a result of battle
column9: they saw men dying
column10: they saw their friend dying
column11: they knew that they might not get home.  And I think that shaped their religious response.  If you go back to the time of the American Revolution
column12: Americans (westerners in general) have a sort of vague sense of the afterlife.  They’re not really sure what heaven is going to look like.  It’s going to be good but there’s no real sense of well it’s going to be just like life on earth.  For a lot of reasons during the Jacksonian period
column13: by the time we get to 1860
column14: there is a sense among American Protestants
column15: North and South
column16: that heaven is going to look a whole lot like home
column17: that when a Christian dies and goes to heaven that man is going to live in a small nuclear household with his wife and with his kids if they too were saved and if they too were able to get to heaven and that life was going to go on pretty much as it had before only better.  So what happens with a lot of these men is that they start using the same phrase over and over.  They start writing their wives and their children to an extent and they say “let us meet in heaven
column18: if we do not again meet on this earth
column19: let us meet in heaven” and they spend a lot of time trying to convince their wives and their children to live good Christian lives.  I think it was the ultimate way of getting home for men who weren’t sure that they were going to get back to their earthly home in North Carolina or Alabama or wherever
column20: there was still that hope that belief that their families would be reunited in a home in the afterlife.  And so again for them religion tends to be very
column21: very personal.  They don’t write very much at all about the Confederacy as a Christian nation
column22: that they are Christian soldiers that they are fighting against godless abolition; I mean there are a very small number of them that do.  Their religion for them I think it was for antebellum southerners as a whole was very personal and very
column23: very family oriented and
column24: to an extent
column25: individual and that’s really what drives their religious expression through the war.

column2: do we have some sense of what happened to these 320 soldiers from your sample that you built your study around?  Do you know how many died during the war?  And I wonder how
column3: I know you wanted to focus on their writings during the war
column4: but I wonder how their post-war memories or reflections might have differed from their feelings during the war?

column1: KN: It’s a wonderful question. Those who survived
column2: and some of them did
column3: I mean how did they look back on the war 30 and 40 years later and that’s probably another good study to be written but that’s not something that I looked at.  I wasn’t interested in their memories so much as I was interested in their experience so I would certainly encourage anybody who wanted to take my sample and track these men down in the published literature of the 1870s and 80s and 90s to see how they regarded the war experience.  I think that would be interesting; it’s not something that I did.  A lot of my men died in the hospital.  I was shocked at how many of them actually spent time in the hospital and
column4: as I think is the case for every Civil War historian and as I think you are working through the collections of letters and diaries
column5: there’s always that moment when the collection ends and you know that the soldier has died and that happened a lot
column6: you know they are writing these letters from hospitals “I think I’m getting better” when in fact they weren’t. The memory question is an interesting one and it certainly memory is certainly something I’ve been interested in over the years but it’s not something that I did with this project. What I really wanted to do was make a contribution to the soldier motivation literature that we have out there and in the same way that say McPherson did not look at their memories 30 or 40 years later or Chandra Manning didn’t look at those I didn’t either what I was really trying to do was fit my work into that literature.

column2: thank you for joining me and discussing your most recent book
column3: Reluctant Rebels: The Confederates Who Joined the Army after 1861.

column1:
KN: Thank you; I enjoyed it.
